title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: 2,443 words 20 December 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company In 1995, Bill Gates of Microsoft wrote an impassioned memo to his lieutenants stirring them to confront the challenge of ''The Internet Tidal Wave.'' That wave hit corporate America as a whole in 1999, when companies large and small recognized that the impact of the Internet would not be confined merely to Silicon Valley or to the proliferating dot-com start-ups. ''Every business now knows that it faces the opportunity and threat of being transformed by the Internet, and this was the year that happened,'' said Daniel Yergin, a business consultant and author.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The Internet has also become a powerful symbol of society's expectations about the future -- a future of fast-moving, disruptive technology that is shifting the terrain not only in business, but also in politics and culture.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The truth, of course, is that it is probably too early to judge whether an Internet revolution is truly under way.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Historians say the Internet should be viewed mainly as the latest advance in communications, a successor to the telegraph and the telephone, more a technological step than a leap forward.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Still, whether labeled a revolution or an evolution, the Internet's impact on the economy seems destined to become greater and greater.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: When people speak of the ''Internet economy,'' they do not really mean that Internet businesses themselves suddenly loom so large in the nation's $9 trillion economy.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: They are talking of a technology and a pattern of business behavior that feels like the future.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The Internet is seen as a technology of borderless free markets.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: It is a global network with open technology standards, not owned or controlled by a single company or nation.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: And it is magic on Wall Street these days, driving the shares of many Internet companies to astronomical heights.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Because it is such a low-cost communications technology, the Internet holds the promise of drastically reducing transactions costs.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: This opens the door to what Michael Porter of Harvard's business school has called ''atomistic competition,'' as market forces and entrepreneurial ways are driven further down toward the individual level.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Organizational bureaucracies of every kind -- corporate, government and union -- suddenly look vulnerable to the Internet's decentralizing powers.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Even the power of nation states, already eroding, seems at risk.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Yergin, the co-author with Joseph Stanislaw of ''The Commanding Heights,'' a history of the rise of the global marketplace, observed: ''Nothing so symbolizes globalization as the Internet, a technology with the power to leap across the geographic borders of nation-states and across time zones.'' Prediction tends to be a humbling, hit-or-miss endeavor even for the gifted or lucky.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: In the late 1960's, for example, Sir Arthur C.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Clarke, the science fiction writer, predicted that by 2000 a vast electronic ''global library'' would be developed -- and the Internet and the World Wide Web could arguably qualify as one.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Then again, Sir Arthur also predicted that the planets would be colonized by next year.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But technologists, economists and futurists say that some questions are worth asking when thinking about how the Internet economy might evolve over the next few years.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: What was the mixture of technology and policy decisions that created today's Internet?

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: What key technology and policy issues are likely to affect the Internet over the next few years?

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: And, finally, since the future is usually the past with a twist, what can be learned from earlier technology-driven transitions?

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The Internet has been embraced by libertarian free-marketers as the embodiment of their values, but, to be sure, it began with government financing.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Yet liberals who point to the Internet to support a pro-government stance -- at least in any conventional sense -- are ignoring certain facts.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The early money for the Internet -- as well as for pioneering research in computer graphics and speech recognition software -- came from an elite, the Pentagon's Advanced Research Projects Agency.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Its money came from the military's largess, and ARPA's leaders spent it pretty much as they pleased with little accountability.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: From the mid-1960's to the mid-1970's, the agency's leaders displayed an uncanny knack for backing long-term winners in technology.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: For two decades, the Internet was developed gradually in the distinctive milieu of the nation's research centers by scientists who believed in the free sharing of information and in open technology standards.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The next major policy pronouncement about the Internet did not come until 1997, when the Clinton administration released its ''Framework for Global Electronic Commerce.'' Written by Ira C.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Magaziner, a senior White House adviser, the report called for a market-driven Internet. ''Business models must evolve rapidly to keep pace with the breakneck speed of change in the technology,'' the report said. ''Government attempts to regulate are likely to be outmoded by the time they are finally enacted.'' So the pattern of policy to date: shrewd government seeding of research followed by benign neglect.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But as the Internet increasingly becomes a main thoroughfare of commerce, a host of new policy issues loom -- how to deal with taxation, privacy, security and international trade in a global networked economy. ''The Internet has given us the greatest rate of return on a public infrastructure investment ever,'' said Robert Litan, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution. ''And it has flourished because we have not yet taxed or regulated it to death -- though those are live issues.'' Technologically, the Internet is almost an economy unto itself -- a network, yes, but also a complex and interacting set of technologies.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Today's Internet is a result of a torrid pace of improvement in recent years in computer networks, processing power, data storage, software, display technology and user interfaces like the Web browser.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The sheer firepower of computers, experts say, is certain to race ahead to startling effect over the next few years.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Data storage technology, for example, is advancing at a particularly rapid rate.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: By 2003, personal computers may well come with terabyte hard drives, which are roughly 100 times the capacity on new PC's today, featuring about 10 gigabytes on average.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: A terabyte drive would be able to hold every conversation that even the chattiest person has had in a lifetime.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Think of a supercomputer on every desktop, in terms of giving individuals the ability to mine personal or business information.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: In every field of academic and scientific research, computing will increasingly be used for simulation and analysis.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The real payoff from the Human Genome Project, for example, will come not from identifying the complete DNA sequence, but from understanding how these complex proteins work.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Such knowledge, medical experts say, will be the basis for everything from developing personally tailored drugs to discovering new ways to treat disease.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The main tool for stalking that breakthrough knowledge is computational biology -- microbiological simulations run on powerful computers.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The real technical challenge to the Internet economy will not come from any shortcoming in raw computing power, but from the difficulty of building up the global network to meet demand.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The next-generation vision of the Internet is of a high-speed global network to which billions of devices are connected, from TV set-top boxes and hand-held computers to refrigerators and washing machines that would be able to do everything from optimizing fuel use to requesting a repair call automatically online.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But that kind of global nervous system of commerce and communication will require far more than adding computers and laying more wire.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The Internet, after all, was originally designed as a computerized ''party line'' for a small community of researchers -- who knew and trusted each other -- to send e-mail.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: And network complexity can increase exponentially -- that is, a network with 200 million users is far more than twice as complex as one with 100 million because each user, each computer and each line of code can interact with others in the network in unpredictable ways, just as in a biological organism.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: A presidential advisory group of leading computer scientists concluded earlier this year that new research, fresh approaches and more government money were needed to cope with the problem. ''Scaling the Internet to handle the expected growth over time is a major challenge,'' said Irving Wladawsky-Berger, general manager of the Internet division at I.B.M. and a member of the group. ''And the current infrastructure can't scale up.'' The group's report to the White House warned that there would be ''catastrophic failures'' in the computer networks that increasingly support the nation's defense and economy, unless those networks were retooled.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Wladawsky-Berger predicts that the technical challenge can be overcome, provided the government and industry make the needed research investments. ''It should not be a showstopper,'' he said.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Indeed, given the track record of success in computing, the visceral optimism of the technologists seems justified. ''Sure there are some tough problems, but it'll work,'' said Rick Rashid, head of research at Microsoft. ''We can do it.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: In information technology, that is the way it's always worked.'' That information technology is delivering a problem-solving payoff has been an article of faith in the corporate world for years, far more so than among economists.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Business investment in computer hardware and software is running at $380 billion a year, up steadily from the annual rate of $110 billion five years ago.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: And corporate America is expected to keep increasing such spending..

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: By the end of 2001, Macroeconomic Advisers, a research firm in St.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Louis, projects that business investment in computer hardware and software will be running at a yearly rate of $513 billion.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Economists expect the nation's extraordinary growth to continue next year, though at a somewhat slower pace.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The consensus among the 50 forecasters in the Blue Chip Economic Indicators survey is that the economy will expand 3.9 percent this year, with inflation at 1.4 percent.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: For 2000, the consensus is growth of 3.2 percent and inflation of 1.7 percent.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: In February, the economy should set the record for the longest expansion, surpassing the 106-month record set in the 1960's.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Just what impact information technology has had on the economy's uncommon run of growth, productivity gains and low inflation is a subject of heated debate within the economics profession.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: It is probably too early to tell, but Mr.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Litan of Brookings, who is leading a yearlong study on the issue, sponsored by the Internet Policy Institute, said, ''My instinct is whatever we find the economic impact to be, it will be a lot greater five years from now.'' The sense of being at the start of a business and economic transformation, of course, has fueled the Internet start-up fever.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: It seems a speculative bubble, but such periods of investment mania foster a rapid pace of business experimentation.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Thomas Eisenmann, an assistant professor at the Harvard Business School, notes that from 1900 to 1925 there were more than 3,300 automobile start-ups in America turning out cars of many types -- some sporting three wheels, some six; one model featuring a shiplike tiller for steering; others trying electricity or steam as power sources. ''We'll see the same kind of winnowing in e-commerce,'' Mr.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Eisenmann said. ''Some will succeed, but most will fail.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: We'll repeat the past again, only faster.'' For established companies, the Internet challenge is to adapt to an accelerated technological shift.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Gates was sketching out in his 1995 memo: Microsoft was threatened by the rise of Internet software; yet if it scrambled, he wrote, the company could benefit from the Internet.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The speed of Microsoft's response is regarded as an exceptional case of a big company's moving nimbly to change course, but the tactics it used became the subject of the government's sweeping antitrust suit against Microsoft.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The Internet's openness, low-cost use and speed are its distinctive features.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The telegraph, historians note, had many of the same qualities -- it was an electronic network that transformed many business practices and was a new medium of informal communication for many.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Yet the telegraph was expensive in contrast to the Internet.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Sending a message was a household budgeting decision; firing off an e-mail message today is not. ''The Internet is the telegraph for the rest of us,'' noted Paul Saffo, a director of the Institute for the Future.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The speed at which the Internet is spreading across the globe, pushing both the tools and values of high technology onto people, could prompt a backlash.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Peter Schwartz, a leading futurist and business consultant, is a technology optimist.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Along with Peter Leyden and Joel Hyatt, he wrote, ''The Long Boom: A Vision for the Coming Age of Prosperity.'' Yet Mr.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Schwartz, while predicting that the pace of technological change will not slow, adds that the willingness of people to accept new technology could reverse sharply if companies and governments do not make the right policy choices.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The Internet economy carries the potential for creating ''a deep divide between those who have the skills to prosper and those who don't,'' he said. ''That's why education policy is so important,'' he added.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The advance of nuclear power in the United States, he said, came to a standstill because the public fears after the Three Mile Island accident were not allayed.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The recent resistance to genetically altered foods and the protests in Seattle over the World Trade Organization's global influence on environmental and labor protections, he said, are warning signs. ''An inadequate appreciation of either the losers in this new economy or of the people with legitimate concerns could be real problems,'' Mr.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Schwartz said. ''If you don't address those groups early on, it will come back to bite you.'' hardware and software is running at a $380 billion yearly rate, up steadily from the annual rate of $110 billion five years ago.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The corporate world is expected to continue investing in information as spending passes a projected $500 billion by the end of the year 2001.

author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Business/Financial Desk; Section A Computing Centers Become The Keeper of Web's Future 2,628 words 19 May 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company SCHAUMBURG, Ill. -- As Walt Grom tours his domain row upon row of hulking black computers -- he speaks of the importance of ''fundamental engineering disciplines'' and ''brute force experience.'' The vast room is spotless, brightly lit and chilled by air-conditioning, an austere interior designed for the care and feeding of big computers.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The huge data center, run by I.B.M., is one of the engine rooms of the Internet, powering the World Wide Web sites and electronic commerce operations of some 400 companies and organizations including Bank of America, Macy's, Goodyear and the National Hockey League.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Such computer centers, known as server farms, are the unglamorous side of the Internet revolution -- a world apart from the young, urban culture of Web design artists with their tattoos and earrings.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Here, a no-nonsense style prevails, and the hallways tend to be populated by big, beefy men with beepers. ''We're happy to do the plumbing,'' said Mr.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Grom, who runs the International Business Machines Corporation's server farm in Schaumburg.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Big data centers are sprouting up across the country, offering expertise and economies of scale to corporate customers and housing the proliferating Internet-based services that cater to consumers.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: It has become a billion-dollar business, doubling annually, and represents a sure sign of the trend toward once again housing information and computer power centrally -- a reversal of the last two decades of computing.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The personal computer has defined the industry's recent history and how computers were used.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: As personal computers spread rapidly in the early 1980's, they were seen as engines of individual empowerment and decentralization of information.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Millions of islands of information were suddenly stored on desktop machines -knowledge residing in the spreadsheet, word processing and data base programs of individuals.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: It was a technical and social repudiation of the previous three decades, dominated by mainframes and minicomputers, a computing formula based on ''big iron'' machines that held all the information.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But in an odd alliance, the Internet -- hailed as the technology behind a new economics, tearing down old hierarchies and flattening corporate organizations -- is fueling a recentralization of information and a revival of big iron computing.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The Internet holds the promise of anytime, anywhere access to information and entertainment delivered over powerful networks to an array of information appliances like handheld devices, cell phones with screens and television set-top boxes.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: They will join personal computers more than replace them anytime soon.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: That makes the present round of information centralization very different from the old days.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The data centers of the 1960's, housed in glass, were controlling gatekeepers with information rationed from the center.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Today's modern server farms, by contrast, are powerful nodes on the Internet, making information more readily available to individuals.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Large computer centers, to be sure, could be vulnerable to breakdowns, though they typically have their own backup power supplies and data recovery systems.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: And there are clearly privacy concerns raised by the prospect of creating increasingly larger digital storehouses of personal information.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Those concerns, technology experts say, require clear-cut corporate and public policies to protect privacy.    ''In a society where knowledge is power, centralized knowledge is centralized power,'' said Richard Sobel, a fellow at the Berkman Center for Internet and Society at the Harvard Law School.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Still, even personal computer pioneers generally regard the shift to Internet-based computing as an irreversible step toward efficiency rather than a retreat from the information democracy they sought to foster. ''People want to own their own information, but they don't want to maintain it, and that is driving the shift toward centralization,'' said Adele Goldberg, a member of the team at the Xerox Palo Alto Research Center in the early 1970's that created the founding concepts of personal computing.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: A Basic Shift Back to the Future In a Post-PC World Because of the Internet, companies are starting to embrace centralized computing again for the first time in decades. ''A real mind shift is under way in corporate America,'' Scott Winkler, an analyst at the Gartner Group, a research firm, said.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: In some ways, corporate America is following the Internet leaders.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: For behind an America Online or an Amazon.com is a huge arsenal of computing power.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: America Online Inc. supports its service to more than 16 million subscribers -- with a million people using the system simultaneously on many evenings -- with two vast server farms in Virginia and a third one planned, a $520 million project announced in March. (Such data centers are known as server farms because they are veritable crop rows of big computers that send, or serve, data out to users.) ''The good old economics of scale really do apply when it comes to server farms,'' Marc Andreessen, the chief technology officer of America Online, said.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The new model of computing -- a proliferation of information appliances linked by the Internet to server farms -has been called the ''post-PC era.'' For the post-PC vision to be fully realized will take years and billions of dollars of investment to build ultrafast digital networks, wireless technology and new kinds of hand-held and other devices.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: And to say that computing appears to be heading toward a post-PC era is not to say the PC will become obsolete.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Indeed, the PC industry has benefited from the rise of the Internet because the PC today is the principal way to get on the Net.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Desktop alternatives to the PC like the ''network computer,'' or NC, running only a Web browser -first proposed in 1996 by Lawrence J.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Ellison, chairman of the Oracle Corporation -- have not yet slowed PC sales.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But the evolution toward the Internet model, most analysts agree, represents the most significant change in the industry since the PC replaced the mainframe as the center of gravity in computing two decades ago.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The shift represents a daunting challenge to the big winners of the PC industry, the Microsoft Corporation and the Intel Corporation, whose software and microchips are the essential technology in most PC's.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Their high profit margins could erode as consumers increasingly use simpler, lower-cost devices to tap into the Internet.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Both companies recognize the challenge and are responding.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: As one step, Intel announced in April that it was planning a big move into Internet services by building and running server farms.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The move seems a big departure for Intel, whose microprocessors serve as the electronic brains of most PC's.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But Intel sees the server farms as part of its future of moving beyond the personal computer to become a ''building-block supplier'' to the Internet economy. ''The PC industry is changing drastically,'' Andrew S.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Grove, the chairman of Intel, said, ''and when it's over it probably won't even be called the PC industry.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: It will become the Web infrastructure industry.'' Waking Giant Microsoft Is Moving Beyond Software Microsoft is preparing for the day when people may keep much of their personal and professional information on large servers with an initiative called Megaserver.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Using such a service, a person would be able tap into a large central data base via the Web to get E-mail, personal schedules, news, weather updates and other information anywhere, anytime.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Even Microsoft concedes the access device will not always be a PC. ''While the PC will stay central, we realize there is demand for computing on non-PC devices,'' Steven A.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: An early model for the Megaserver concept is Hotmail, a Web-based E-mail system, which Microsoft bought for an estimated $300 million in January 1998.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Since then, the number of users of the free E-mail service has jumped from less than 10 million to 40 million.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: With Hotmail, a person can retrieve E-mail from anywhere with any PC or other device equipped with a Web browser instead of being required to use a particular machine loaded with one's own E-mail software. ''Hotmail has served as a big wake-up call for us, and we're delighted that we bought it,'' John Ludwig, a vice president of Microsoft, said.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Hotmail is supported by four large data centers, and Microsoft is using them as incubators for developing the heavy-duty software needed to run server farms, thus improving the capabilities of Windows NT, the company's most powerful operating system.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Ludwig notes, is also working to improve the software the user sees, making it easier to use. ''There's more software to write than ever before -- that's the good news for us,'' he observed.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Microsoft added another centralized information service in April when it acquired Jump Networks Inc., a Web-based calendar and datebook system.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Microsoft's move came a few weeks after America Online purchased an Internet calendar service, When Inc., for an estimated $150 million.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The start-up, which stores personal scheduling information on a Web site, started its fast-growing service just four months earlier.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Both companies are headed in the same direction, though from different starting points, one a software giant, the other an online service.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Clearly, the line between software and services will blur as the shift to Internet-based computing proceeds.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: In an internal memo last fall titled ''The Era Ahead,'' William H.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Gates, the Microsoft chairman, pointed to the opportunity as software becomes more a services business. ''We get a closer relationship with customers and a predictable revenue model because they pay us a regular fee for the service,'' he wrote.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Gates also warned of the threat to some Microsoft products likely to come from on-line services. ''A company such as America Online is in competition for all our information-management software, because they can do it through their servers,'' he observed.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The Playing Field Building the Engines To Run the Servers In Silicon Valley, dozens of start-ups have been created to provide centralized Internet services for personal information.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The new companies mostly focus on E-mail, calendars and backup file storage to insure information is not lost when an individual's PC crashes. ''Many of these applications should be moved onto the Internet because it is more reliable, available everywhere and cheaper,'' said Eric Brewer, a computer scientist at the University of California at Berkeley who is a co-founder of the Inktomi Corporation, a Web software company.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Building and running the computing engine rooms behind these Internet services promises to be good business for years to come.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Yet this behind-the-scenes technology business -- like the market for Internet appliances -will most likely be more diverse and competitive than the bygone mainframe era, whose dominant supplier was I.B.M, or the current PC era, ruled by Microsoft and Intel.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The start of the trend back to central computing has already been rewarding for the established producers of ''big iron'' machines like Sun Microsystems Inc., a leader in computers running the powerful Unix operating system, and I.B.M., whose mainframes have been retooled as Internet servers.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The big Unix and mainframe server computers range in price from $100,000 to millions of dollars. ''The big growth for us has been in everything dot com -- the revolution in Internet commerce in all its forms,'' said Edward J.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Indeed, as more and more companies begin to view the Internet not as an experiment but as a technology on which they run their businesses, they need Web sites, E-mail networks and Internet order-processing systems to be up and running around the clock, seven days a week.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: That kind of reliable, industrial-strength computing is the traditional bailiwick of mainframes and Unix systems.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Still, PC technology is improving steadily and PC servers -- typically using Intel microprocessors and Microsoft's Windows NT software -- are increasingly tackling heavy-duty computing chores.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Some heavily trafficked Web sites, handling huge amounts of business, are backed up by server farms using mostly PC technology.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The Dell Computer Corporation, a direct marketer of PC's, says that sales from its Web site are now running at a pace of $5 billion a year. ''Look at our Web site,'' Michael Dell, the company chairman, said. ''It's Dell servers running Windows NT.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR

author: STEVE LOHR

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: That kind of information -- along with sales reporting -- is being transferred to the Web site.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: A third of Goodyear's North American dealers are on line and using the Web site, and Mr.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Hargreaves is already impressed by the results.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The call center is reporting fewer routine calls, he says, and dealers say they are getting more timely information, which helps them sell more tires and improve customer service.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The weekly mailings will end at the start of next year.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: For all the attention understandably focused on the meteoric rise of on-line retailers and auctioneers, like Amazon and Ebay, the biggest economic impact of the Internet in the next few years is expected to be inside old-line companies like Goodyear -- raising productivity by electronically automating back-office transactions.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Though Goodyear has an in-house data center, it chose to let outside experts provide the computing power for its Web site -- a role known as hosting -- and run its electronic commerce network.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Many companies are making the same choice.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: That is why the Web services business of both established companies like I.B.M. and AT&T, and newcomers like Exodus Communications Inc. and Verio Inc., is projected to grow from $696 million last year to $10.7 billion in 2002, according to the International Data Corporation, a research firm.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Internet companies like America Online will have their own server farms.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But others increasingly view computing as a utility, a service to be purchased like electricity.

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet

title: Businesses and Society Confront the Inescapable Challenges of High Technology and the Internet
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Later, regional utilities were created and sold electric service to the factories.

author: STEVE LOHR

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Its customers have long been its corporate peers on the Fortune 500, not tiny upstarts.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Until a few years ago, that is, when the Internet took off and I.B.M. went with it in new and innovative directions.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: I.B.M. itself shows another side of the new economics of the Internet -- how a big, old-line company can turn the challenge of technological upheaval into a rejuvenating opportunity.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: I.B.M. has embraced the Internet in its products, practices and marketing -- from overhauling its mainframes into Internet computers to refashioning itself as an Internet leader with its giant ''e-business'' advertising campaign.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The result has been a startling revival in I.B.M.'s prospects and image.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: A few years ago, I.B.M. was stumbling as the mantle of leadership in computing seemed to have passed to the Microsoft Corporation and the Intel Corporation, the technology standard-setters of the personal computer era.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But the Internet changed the landscape again.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The rise of the Internet -- a vast global network -- played to I.B.M.'s traditional strengths.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: It required powerful centralized computers to serve up data to millions of viewers.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: And I.B.M. adapted its big-iron computers to Internet protocols, recasting them as giant Web servers and the transaction-processing workhorses of electronic commerce.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: As the Internet moves beyond the experimental stage, as more and more companies actually run their businesses on the Internet, those systems must be robust, secure and up and running 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: That level of reliability is second nature to I.B.M., and it is why airline reservations systems, national defense systems and the like depend on I.B.M. ''We were moving in the right direction and, frankly, we were lucky as well,'' said Nicholas Donofrio, the senior vice president for technology at I.B.M. ''The industry moved our way.''   Today, I.B.M. is a leading supplier of technology and know-how in the Internet era.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The well-known names of this new world may be America Online, Amazon.com and Yahoo, but I.B.M. has emerged as the quiet giant of the Internet by serving as a kind of arms supplier for this new economy to companies of all sizes.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: In that role, it has plenty of competition from a wide range of companies, including Sun Microsystems, Hewlett-Packard, Microsoft and others.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But none has risen as fast from what seemed to be so far behind not long ago. ''I.B.M. is getting a real bounce from the Internet,'' said Stan Dolberg, a senior analyst at Forrester Research, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. ''It seemed a moribund company three or four years ago.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But I.B.M. jumped on the Internet instantly, and it's been an innovator.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: It has surprised a lot of people.'' THE company estimates that roughly one-quarter of its revenue -- or $20 billion -- is driven all or in part by E-business demand.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: It defines E-business as companies grappling with Internet-related projects, from setting up a Web site to reach customers to handling most of its procurement over the Internet.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: I.B.M. has helped thousands of small companies get on the Web, and it runs their sites for fees that range up to $200 a month.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: By 2001, it hopes to have two million small-business customers.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Yet it is the larger companies that remain I.B.M.'s bread-and-butter business.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: They often hire I.B.M. to help them use the power of Internet technology to revamp the way they deal with suppliers, customers and employees in an effort to lower their costs, focus their marketing and eliminate mountains of paperwork.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: These can be multimillion-dollar projects.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Most of this work involves the economic infrastructure of companies dealing with one another -- known as business-to-business commerce.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: It is the business-to-consumer commerce of Amazon.com, Ebay and others that understandably gets the most attention.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But streamlining business-to-business transactions will ultimately have the greatest effect on consumers in terms of prices and quality of service.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Business-to-business dealings, analysts say, represent the biggest opportunity for Internet commerce over the next several years.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Forrester Research estimates that consumer sales over the Internet will jump to $108 billion by 2003 from $3.9 billion last year.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But that impressive increase is dwarfed by Forrester's projection for business-to-business commerce on the Internet, rising to $1.3 trillion by 2003 from $45 billion last year.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: And it is industry's ''back office'' -- procurement, accounting, order-processing and the like -- that economists are watching most closely for evidence that the spread of the Internet is leading a technology-based productivity payoff in the nation's economy.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The evidence on that front is still inconclusive, but that could be because the use of powerful computing and Internet technology has not gone very far yet.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Gerstner Jr., the chairman of I.B.M., made that very point in a speech before industry analysts and professional investors in May.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: He bemusedly observed all the attention lavished on ''these new dot-com Internet companies'' by the media and Wall Street, before proceeding to his theme. ''But I think of them as fireflies before the storm: all stirred up, throwing off sparks,'' Mr.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Gerstner said. ''But the storm that's arriving -- the real disturbance in the Force -- is when the thousands of institutions that exist today seize the power of this global computing and communications infrastructure and use it to transform themselves.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Gerstner, I.B.M. has undergone its own internal transformation.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Much of its sales, service, procurement and training are now handled on the Web.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: I.B.M. estimates that $3.3 billion of its sales last year were over the Web, or roughly five times those of Amazon.com.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: This year, I.B.M. plans to have Web sales -- mainly to corporate customers -- of $10 billion to $15 billion.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The company figures it will save $600 million this year by letting customers find answers to straightforward service and technical support questions on specialized I.B.M.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Web pages, thus freeing the time of its human support staff for more complex problems.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: And by procuring $12 billion worth of goods over the Web this year, I.B.M. says it will do away with about 5 million pages of paper forms.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: TO position itself as a company on the cutting edge of electronic commerce, I.B.M. began a major advertising campaign in the fall of 1997, promoting the notion of ''e-business.'' The term was new then but has since become routinely used in newspaper and magazine stories and in the marketing campaigns of other companies.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The I.B.M. ad campaign -- budgeted at $550 million worldwide this year -- has featured customers of all kinds, from body-pierced Web designers to Ms.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Its implicit message is that the Internet is not about   just putting up a Web site, it is the technological starting point for a complex rethinking of how business is done.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Big companies like Ford, United Parcel Service, Charles Schwab and Bank One have chosen I.B.M. as their technology partner as they try to exploit the Internet to transform their businesses.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web

author: STEVE LOHR

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The chemical business is a $250-billion-a-year industry in the United States.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: E-Chemicals is betting it can make its fortune by streamlining the industry's fragmented distribution system, a jury-built setup based on industry directories, phone calls, faxes and relationships with distributors.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Its on-line chemical marketplace lists 20 suppliers, including Dow Chemical and DuPont, more than 1,000 products and 600 registered customers.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: For suppliers, E-Chemicals offers a low-cost way to sell to small customers, right down to sales of a couple of 55-gallon drums.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: For smaller buyers, E-Chemicals promises to substantially level the playing field by offering the kind of lower prices usually available only to distributors' big customers.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: E-Chemicals can do that because of its lower expenses, operating as a kind of ''virtual corporation'' that uses subcontractors for much of its basic work.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web
author: STEVE LOHR

''For what we are doing, we're not talking about some on-line billboard where how it looks and the user interface are all that matter,'' Mr.

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web

title: Big Blue Casts Itself as Big Brother to Business on the Web

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: 1,300 words 7 March 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company SAN FRANCISCO, March 6 -- The Microsoft Corporation moved to defuse a potentially explosive privacy issue today, saying it would modify a feature of its Windows 98 operating system that has been quietly used to create a vast data base of personal information about computer users.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Microsoft in effect conceded that the feature, a unique identifying number used by Windows and other Microsoft products, had the potential to be more invasive than a traceable serial number in the Intel Corporation's new Pentium III computer chip that has privacy advocates up in arms.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The difference is that the Windows number is tied to an individual's name, to identifying numbers on the hardware in his computer and even to documents that he creates.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The combination of the Windows number with all these data, the privacy advocates said, could result in the ability to track a single user and the documents he created across vast computer networks.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Hackers could compromise the resulting data base, or subpoenas might allow authorities to gain access to information that would otherwise remain private and unavailable.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Privacy advocates fear that availability will lead to abuses. ''We're definitely sensitive to any privacy concerns,'' Robert Bennett, Microsoft's group product manager for Windows, said. ''The software was not supposed to send this information unless the computer user checked a specific option.'' Mr.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Bennett said the option to collect the information had been added to the software so that Microsoft support employees would be able to help users diagnose problems with their computers more accurately.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: He said the Redmond, Wash., software giant had never intended to use the data for marketing purposes.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Microsoft said it would take the steps after a computer programmer in Massachusetts discovered the numbers attached to documents that he had created.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Smith, told Microsoft he believed the practice created a potential threat to privacy.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Bennett said Microsoft would alter the way the registration program works in the next maintenance release of Windows 98.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: He said the company's technicians would look through its data bases and expunge information that had been improperly collected as a result of earlier versions.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The company is also exploring the possibility of creating a free utility program that would make it possible for Windows users to delete the serial number information from a small data base in the part of Windows known as the registry, where it is now collected.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Smith, who is the president of Phar Lap Software Inc., a software tools development company, contacted Microsoft earlier this week after discovering that the Microsoft Office business software was creating unique numbers identifying his personal computer and embedding them in spreadsheet and word processing documents.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Smith discovered that the hardware identifier was sent to Microsoft even when he instructed the registration program not to send it.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Bennett contended was a programming error.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Smith said that the number created a ''digital fingerprint'' that could be used to match a document created by a word processing or spreadsheet program with a particular computer.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: On Thursday, after further studying the ''registration wizard'' -- the software module that enables customers to register their copies of the Windows 98 operating system for support and updates -- Mr.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Smith discovered that the number, known as a Globally Unique Identifier, was being transmitted to Microsoft as part of a list of registration information that generally includes the owner's name, address, phone number and other demographic information as well as details about the hardware and software on or attached to the user's computer. ''Microsoft never asked me if it was O.K. to send in this number, and they never said it was being sent,'' Mr.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Smith said. ''They are apparently building a data base that relates Ethernet adapter addresses to personal information.'' Ethernet adapters are cards inserted in a personal computer that enable it to connect to high-speed networks within organizations and through them to the Internet.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The controversy erupted just weeks after Intel, maker of the most widely used processors for machines that use the Windows operating system, agreed to change a small software utility that came with the new Pentium III chip so that a serial number on the chip would be inactive unless the computer user switched it on.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Privacy activists have been attacking both companies, arguing that identification numbers can be easily misused to create electronic monitoring systems.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Such systems could track a computer user's behavior in cyberspace or create dossiers of personal information about individuals.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The issue has sparked a heated debate over the fundamental technology of modern computer networks and software systems, which routinely employ serial numbers to identify individual computers and software modules, known as ''objects,'' that can be shared by a number of programs.

author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: But the Intel number only identified a computer.

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
author: JOHN MARKOFF

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns

title: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
