The key catalyst for putting together information, according to editors and media critics, was the satellite phone and, more broadly, satellite communications -- which first came into their own during the three-year siege of Sarajevo in the Bosnian war, which ended in 1995.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Broadcast radio was the device that broke new communications ground in World War II; the evening television news show was the medium that most directly brought home the violence of the Vietnam War, and CNN's 24-hour cable TV news coverage first caught hold with the Gulf War.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: This time around, the satellite uplink was the information medium of the moment. ''Instantaneous communication has changed things,'' said Andrew Rosenthal, the foreign editor of The New York Times. ''The ability of a reporter on the Macedonian border to call a reporter on the Albanian border or to call a reporter in Brussels or Washington instantly made a huge difference.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Newspapers were able to put together groups of reporters to do joint efforts in a way that was previously impossible.'' The same satellite technology, said Ted Koppel, host of ABC's ''Nightline,'' can cut two ways when it comes to television.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: The technology, he noted, allows a profusion of images to be transmitted at great speed.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: When those images reflect something like the fate of Kosovar refugees, or the Serb troop pullout from Kosovo, the medium's emotional power is at its peak -- for better and for worse, in Mr.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Koppel's view. ''Television in particular is a medium that allows people at home to become violence voyeurs,'' he said, speaking from Pristina by, yes, satellite telephone. ''The more they see, the more it takes to gain their interest the next day.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: And it's all happening so fast and such an enormous volume is being churned out, that people become very jaded by what they see very quickly. ''The great danger is that there will be a reaction from American television viewers that 'we've seen it all, and last week it looked better.' '' S.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Robert Lichter, president of the Center for Media and Public Affairs in Washington, said that television coverage -- by doing what it does best -- buttressed the humanitarian justification for the hostilities. ''Early on, the human suffering of the refugees provided a natural story line that fit very well with NATO's rationale for the war,'' Mr.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Lichter said. ''To sell a war in a democracy when you're not attacked, you have to demonize the leader or show that there are humanitarian reasons for going in.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: We did something of the same with Milosevic.'' When the refugee crisis came, he said, ''the need of TV to have human beings and an ongoing story and the need of the Administration to have a rationale for the bombing melded very well.'' His words have an echo in those of Mr.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Bacon at the Pentagon, who said that ''the refugee crisis, along with the atrocity stories, was an indication of why we were fighting.'' But, Mr.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Lichter said, he and his staff noticed in the conflict's first few weeks that electronic news organizations and print journalists weighted their coverage very differently, with much more critical coverage found in print.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: The initial television news coverage ''was so highly positive,'' he said.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Many cable and some broadcast shows -- particularly the weekend wrap-up and analysis programs from Washington -- are driven by debate, and they amplified the criticisms of President Clinton's decision to rule out ground troops.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Milosevic did not quickly accede to NATO demands, criticism also grew that NATO had badly miscalculated.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Night after night, strategy and tactics were debated by journalists, Congressmen and former generals in a forum whose lifeblood is ''the journalism of assertion'' -- a term coined by the media critics Bill Kovach and Tom Rosenstiel in ''Warp Speed'' (Century Foundation, 1999), their book on the pitfalls of instantaneous journalism and the argument culture of cable television.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Some media coverage found this coverage tendentious -- journalists reflecting unrealistic expectations about an early end to the war and reinforcing dubious assumptions about the limitations of bombing. ''One fundamental issue arose early in the coverage and was never challenged to the end of the war,'' said Marvin Kalb, the director of the Shorenstein Center at the Kennedy School of Government of Harvard University, ''and that was that this war could not end through the application only of air power, that somehow or another you're going to have to send troops in.'' In addition, Mr.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Kalb said, there was an early expectation that if the bombing did not quickly sap Mr.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Milosevic's resolve, then it had failed. ''This is a conviction perhaps sired by the quick end of the gulf war and perhaps by the American psyche that can't hold its attention on anything for more than a week,'' he said.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Rosenthal, The Times's foreign editor, said that ''the fact remains that the analysis of the war's having gotten off to a slow and clumsy start was accurate.'' He added: ''The press reflects what is going on.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: If the Administration is sitting on its hands and not explaining itself, we have to go to other analysts.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: And dissenters are always more willing to talk.'' Some reporters, however, were able to see things first-hand.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Some did it with the Pentagon's sufferance, like Steve Komarow of USA Today, who flew with a B-52 crew in the first days of the war, but was not allowed to use the names and hometowns of the pilots in his dispatches.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Others, like Steven Erlanger of The New York Times, worked from Belgrade, reporting on bomb damage and Serbian morale while working in and around a web of Serb censorship.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Still others, like Paul Watson of The Los Angeles Times, got inside Kosovo and covered bombing damage and ethnic violence close up.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: And Jack Kelly of USA Today reported from a dangerous vantage point alongside a Kosovo Liberation Army unit.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Some critics, however, see serious remaining flaws in war coverage, even in the age of a thousand sources and a thousand outlets. ''All wars are imperfectly covered,'' said John R.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: MacArthur Jr., the publisher of Harper's Magazine, who wrote ''Second Front: Censorship and Propaganda in the Gulf War'' (Hill & Wang, 1992) about the Persian Gulf War. ''All wars are a mess.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: You can only hope to get shards of information.'' And while he said that the reporting of the Kosovo conflict had been ''vastly better than the Gulf War,'' he said that reporters still take too much official information and pass it on as fact. ''I didn't see the word claim or claimed used nearly enough,'' he said. ''It's a useful discipline not to let the Pentagon or NATO get away with loose talk.''    Market Place Business/Financial Desk; Section C Technology Bankers Work To Give Merrill A Silicon Shine 1,562 words 27 December 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company WHEN the Goldman Sachs Group and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter announced upbeat earnings news last week, a cheer could be heard in Silicon Valley.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: There, both Wall Street investment banks have flourished, riding the wave of dot-com companies that have enriched themselves by offering shares to a rapacious public or selling out to each other.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: But in recent years, another big Wall Street name has been conspicuously scarce in the Silicon Valley gold rush: Merrill Lynch.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: The firm's sideline status has been puzzling, given that as much as one-quarter of the revenue generated by investment banking departments these days comes from advising technology companies on mergers and public stock offerings.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: So why has Merrill largely missed out on technology bankers' big bull market?

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: To hear Merrill Lynch explain it, the firm has not missed out at all; it simply got a late start.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Tom Davis, executive vice president of Merrill's corporate and institutional client group, said the company was only three years into a multiyear effort to expand its technology presence worldwide. ''We are at the beginning of what is a long secular shift in the economy,'' Mr.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Of Merrill's strategy, in particular, he said, ''I think we are at the early stage of this game.'' Of course, technology executives have heard that before.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: When Merrill set up an office in Palo Alto, Calif., in 1996, it was the third attempt to crack Silicon Valley's clubby community, after abortive efforts in the 1980's and early 1990's.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Davis said the company had been too busy expanding other departments to focus much on technology in those days.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Given its relatively late start, Merrill has made a respectable showing this year.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: According to Thomson Financial/Securities Data, Merrill ranked fourth in taking new technology companies public in 1999, as measured by the amount of money raised.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: That is a far cry from 1997, when it did not even rank among the top 20.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Merrill's total of $2.2 billion in technology underwriting this year, as calculated by Thomson, gave the firm a market share of 7.8 percent through Dec. 22.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Those numbers do not tell the full story, though.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: That is still only about half the market share of more influential rivals like Morgan Stanley, Credit Suisse First Boston and Goldman Sachs -- which rank first, second and third, respectively, in Thomson's lineup.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: And with the exception of the Internet Capital Group, a Merrill loyalist that invests in Internet concerns and which Merrill took public in August, Merrill has yet to attract the roster of superstar companies that their larger competitors have.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Investors in Goldman and Morgan have been handsomely rewarded this year, in part, because of their prowess in the technology sector.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Goldman's share price is up 53 percent since the firm went public in May; Morgan's is up 85 percent for the year.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Merrill's share price, though, is up only 17 percent. ''It is not clear to me that they are going to make strides quickly enough,'' Steven Galbraith, an analyst at Sanford C.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Galbraith said, is that by the time Merrill might catch up in technology, the market will have moved on to the next hot sector.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Some analysts have said that when merger talks between Merrill and the technology investment boutique Hambrecht & Quist broke down two years ago, Merrill missed a ripe opportunity to increase its presence in technology underwriting.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Merrill suffered blows, too, with the loss of high-profile executives like its president, Herbert M.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Allison Jr., a favorite in Silicon Valley who left the firm earlier this year and joined the ranks of political fundraisers, and, more recently, Scott Ryles, head of technology investment banking, who had helped build that practice.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Ryles left last month to become chief executive of a new online investment bank backed by Charles Schwab.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: What is more, Merrill has not been a believer in the ''star system,'' Mr.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Having a name-brand stock picker, like Mary Meeker, the celebrated Morgan Stanley analyst who helped put that Internet practice on the map, is essential, he argues.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: On that count, though, Merrill may now be trying to cultivate a rising star.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: In February, it hired a 33-year-old CIBC Oppenheimer analyst, Henry Blodget, who went way out on a limb last year by predicting that Amazon.com would hit $400 a share -- a target the stock not only reached but surpassed.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Blodget, who has quickly gained a Silicon Valley following, is simply one indication of the way Merrill Lynch has expanded its technology research effort, said Steve Milunovich, the firm's global team coordinator for technology research. ''I'm a big believer that changing perception is hard,'' Mr.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Milunovich said. ''Our perception is probably better outside the valley than in the valley.'' Certainly, Merrill's perception problem was not helped by comments one of its top executives made about the Internet last year.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: A Merrill vice chairman, John Steffens, was criticized after newspapers quoted him as saying that online trading was akin to gambling and a ''serious threat to Americans' financial lives.'' Some in Silicon Valley took umbrage, suggesting that if Merrill did not understand the impact of theInternet on its own business, how could it understand theirs?

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Steffens, who is known as Launny, subsequently began extolling the Internet, the perception that he was scrambling to recover from a faux pas only seemed to make matters worse.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Davis said that Merrill had not lost a piece of business because of Mr.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: But others at the firm wonder how much potential business landed elsewhere. ''We got tarred for that,'' Mr.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Milunovich said. ''There's no question that Launny's comments hurt.'' One of Merrill's best technology credentials has been serving as a mergers-and-acquisitions banker to the networking giant Cisco Systems.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Merrill got the job because it is one of Cisco's largest equipment customers.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Cisco has an in-house team that does most of the heavy lifting on its transactions, but Merrill has retained the client on merit. ''They do a nice job and we've been pleased with the level of service,'' said Mike Volpi, Cisco's senior vice president for business development.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Still, Merrill's career as a merger adviser has hit some snags.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Merrill had a very close relationship with the At Home Corporation, a provider of high-speed Internet service for cable television subscribers.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Merrill had helped take At Home public and arranged for subsequent financings.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: So it was not surprising the firm was tapped to advise At Home on its $6.7 billion stock-swap merger in January with Excite Inc.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: But the night before the Excite@Home merger was to be announced, executives at Excite noticed a problem: the total that At Home would pay in stock was lower than the agreed-to price.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: In effect, a miscalculation had been made in the documents, and At Home's board of directors had to be reconvened to vote again on the correct amount, according to George Bell, president of Excite@Home and the former chief executive of Excite. ''We were up until 4:30 a.m., they fixed it, and we announced that morning,'' Mr.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Bell said. ''Because it wasn't our company, I can't say it was the bankers' fault.'' Whoever was to blame, industry executives say such last-minute mishaps are rare.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Thomas Jermoluk, who had been At Home's chief executive, could not be reached for comment.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: But people involved in those talks say he and executives from the AT&T Corporation, which owned a large stake of At Home, were enraged at the time.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: And when the merged Excite@Home, led by Mr.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Jermoluk, announced its acquisition of BlueMountain.com recently, it was not Merrill that was hired to advise on the deal.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: Mark Shafir, who is in charge of Merrill's technology merger department in San Francisco, was hard pressed to comment on the mixup with Excite and At Home except to say the terms were ''discussed and vetted'' with executives and their lawyers. ''Unfortunately, there must have been some misunderstanding,'' he said.

title: A New War Drew New Methods for Covering It
author: FELICITY BARRINGER
chunk: If the technology boom continues, as many analysts expect, Merrill may now bear watching.

chunk: And if the company can transform indeed itself into the stock-offering powerhouse that it is in other industries, the next few years could improve Merrill's standing in Silicon Valley. ''Perception,'' Mr.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: 4,921 words 9 May 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company An article last Sunday about the growing dissatisfaction of pop artists with major record labels omitted the given name of a musician who has established her own label.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: CORRECTED BY THE NEW YORK TIMES SUNDAY MAY 16, 1999 THERE are two great pop music dreams.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: And they usually follow each other, like marriage and divorce.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: The first great dream is to get together with friends in a basement or garage, write songs, make music, feel the magic and perform at local clubs until a big record label rushes in waving a contract.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: And then the label takes care of the rest: hit singles, arena shows, limos, parties, a new house for mom.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: But the dream, even for those few who actually get to live it, has usually been a nightmare.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: That's when the next great dream kicks in.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: This is the dream of independence, of breaking away from the record label and going it alone.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: It's about rethinking the first dream, remembering that the most exciting part of being in a band was when you did it yourself.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: There was the joy of selling the first three copies of a CD or cassette you made on your own.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Back then, you actually made a few bucks off those sales.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Now, under a record label, promotional costs are so high that you may see no actual money, even if you're lucky enough to sell a million albums.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: And then there are the long tours spanning four continents, the executives that keep sending you back into the studio asking for hits despite the fact that you considered your album finished months ago, and the three-year gap between the release of each record.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Signing to a big label suddenly doesn't seem like a step up anymore; it seems like a sacrifice. ''There's no contract you can sign in modern life that resembles a recording contract; they're absolutely unconscionable,'' said Bart Bull, the manager and husband of Michelle Shocked, the singer-songwriter who spent four years extricating herself from her contract with Mercury Records after the label rejected her new songs for being inconsistent with her style. ''You take those 48 pages of a typical contract and hold it in front of anyone familiar with other types of business contracts, and they think it's insane.'' A slew of recent events -- from the panic at major labels over the distribution of music on the Internet to the bloodletting following large music company mergers -- has made it clear to musicians that the structure of major record companies is not conducive to either their financial or, more important, their artistic goals.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Talking to everyone from up-and-coming bands to those who have been signed for more than a decade, from artists with low sales to superstars, from lawyers to former executives, there is a growing dissatisfaction with a system that has been building its fortress for more than 100 years -- since a company called Columbia sprung up to challenge Thomas Edison's exclusive distribution of prerecorded cylinders to be played on the phonograph he invented.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: This dissatisfaction stems less from the fact that the companies are owned by multinational conglomerates than from the belief that the labels are simply too big, numbers-driven and inefficient.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Artists who could be much farther along in their creative work get bogged down in the bureaucracy.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Waiting for the new record from Perry Farrell of Jane's Addiction?

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: It's already been rejected by his record label, Warner Brothers, several times.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Her label hasn't liked her new material either.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: The label made the band write dozens of additional songs for its next album in search of a new hit.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: He has just been sued by his record label over a contract dispute.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: And this is how the labels treat their favored artists.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Today, we are at an important moment in music history.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Thanks in part to the rise of the Internet and music-business consolidation, a window has opened, one in which making this sacrifice of artistic freedom for   commercial success may no longer be necessary.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: In the next few years, either a lot of best-selling musicians are going to climb through that window or the window is going to slam shut, tighter than it ever was before.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Manufactured teeny-bopper bands are dominating the pop world, corporate mergers are squeezing hundreds of musicians out of the business without even giving them the rights to their recordings, and executives of major record labels are meeting behind closed doors to develop a way to police and control the distribution of music on the Internet.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: These events are pointing the way to an exit from the status quo by fostering dissent and inadvertently giving musicians the freedom to act on it.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: In recent years, several people have stepped up to try to make the business work better for musicians and their fans, among them the musician, computer whiz and virtual-reality pioneer Jaron Lanier and the progressive rock guitarist Robert Fripp of King Crimson.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: They are developing new companies in hopes of chipping away at a business that loses money on far more records than it profits from.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Despite the rhetoric on the Internet about an on-line music revolution bringing down the record establishment, it is not the Internet per se that is going to grant musicians their freedom.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: It's the idea of the Internet -- in other words, the knowledge that there is an alternative to the system.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: The golden age of the Internet -- as a freewheeling, chaotic world where all information is available free of charge and everybody is equal -- is fast coming to an end.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: There's too much money at stake for it not to be transformed into a new revenue stream for corporations.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: It may seem as if they are running scared because recent technological advances have made it very easy for Internet users to copy and distribute their favorite CD's on line without authorization, but the truth is that the labels have already found a way to turn this new technology to their financial advantage.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Most major labels have added what's called a new technology deduction clause to the contracts they offer bands.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: What it does is subtract 15 to 25 percent of the royalty rate of 12 to 13 percent that a new band receives for each record sold.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: The labels maintain that the clause is necessary because of the costs of Internet-related technology.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: This rationale seems strange because the distribution of music on the Internet is supposed to save record labels money in CD manufacturing, packaging and shipping costs. ''Even the lawyers with the most power can't get rid of those clauses,'' said Ken Freundlich, a top music-industry lawyer. ''It's the same mind-set the labels have had since the CD: bring on the new technology, cut the royalty rate.'' The head of a record company, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said he wasn't worried about artists releasing their CD's independently on the Internet. ''How are they going to compete with someone putting $10 million into another Web site?'' he asked. ''Do you know how big the Internet's going to be?

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: You're going to need infrastructure.'' Putting control of the Internet in the hands of the corporations means that a utopian musical vision may be dying.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: The vision is of a level playing field where all bands regardless of their record label or financing have equal access to the ears of the consumer.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Instead, the chances of a dystopian world are increasing, one in which record companies have even greater control over music distribution, and new bands are signed not because of how they sound but because of how many visitors come to their Internet site each month.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: At present, record companies have a great deal of control.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: A record deal is basically a service contract that puts the musician in the employ of the record company.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: In all but the rarest cases, by signing a deal musicians forfeit their ownership of any music they make under that contract.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: And, from the outset, the musician is put in a position of accepting debt.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: That tantalizing million dollar advance, for example, must be paid back to the record label at an interest rate far higher than that of a bank loan.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Because the debt is paid out of the small royalty that musicians make, most acts never see a penny from their record sales.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: The record company executive said: ''A lot of lawyers and artists don't understand how the record business works.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Artists don't have $50 million in overhead.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: We don't make money on their T-shirts and concerts that we market and promote.'' For the music fan, far more disturbing than the financial toll record labels exact from artists is the creative one.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Except in the case of an extremely slow, laborious songwriter like Leonard Cohen, artistic creativity moves at a much faster rate than the current system allows.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Even in hip-hop, in which musicians tend to turn around albums quickly to take advantage of shortterm trends, there is frustration over inertia on the part of the record labels. ''Years ago, there was a 9- or 10-day turnaround after an artist turned in a record; now it takes 9 to 10 months because the record labels can't handle the traffic and need a year to set up their marketing and promotion systems,'' said Chuck D of Public Enemy, a pioneering rap group that left a major label in January and will release   its next record through an Internet company called Atomic Pop. ''If the majors cannot adapt to change, they become solely banking systems.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: If they could sell Brillo pads with a slice of cheese on them, they'd do that, because the music is irrelevant to them.'' There are many musicians who probably belong in the major label system, particularly those using music as a route to money and fame or those who see their calling not in artistic achievement but in mass entertainment.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Then there are songwriters like Aimee Mann, the former singer in 'Til Tuesday, who has a strong fan base and is an accomplished songwriter.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: But her experiences trying to release records have been soul-crushing, and as a result she has only put out two albums in eight years.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Her first label, Giant, got cold feet and canceled her contract before releasing her first album.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Her second label, Imago, folded before her second record came out, and, just after Ms.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Mann completed her third album for her third label, Geffen, the company was consolidated into Interscope as a result of the merger of both labels' parent company, Universal Music, with Polygram.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Mann thought she had finally caught a lucky break when she became one of the few artists whose contracts were not dropped in the merger.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: But soon after, she was told that Interscope -- her fourth label -- wanted her to continue working on an album. ''I'm officially at the end of my major label rope,'' she said.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Labels have built their business on hits.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: If they had developed a model that could profit from a record that sold 200,000 copies, the way many independent labels do, they could have made money by putting out the five or so records that Ms.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Mann -- or the scores of other performers in similar situations -- might have released.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: This mishandling doesn't just happen with serious artists.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Another merger casualty was the English teeny-bopper band Boyzone, which suffered a setback in its chance for success in America when, to meet a quarterly quota, its label, Mercury, quietly released 30,000 copies of its album before the merger instead of waiting to set up the record properly.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: A spokeswoman for Mercury said that the record had been released to get ''a running start'' for the band's promotional campaign this summer.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Another problem is that labels judge with weekly sales reports and not their ears, giving up on a band that doesn't do well in the short term but may generate future catalogue sales.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: History has proved over and over that one decade's failures (whether it's the Velvet Underground's proto-punk or Joni Mitchell's redirection into jazz) can become the next decade's classics.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: But the history of the music business is one of inefficiencies, dating back to the late 19th century, when less than half the sheet music released paid back the high cost of marketing the music, despite the tactic of paying well-known performers to include the song in their repertories. ''For an artist like me, who is somewhere in the middle saleswise, I've maybe had a couple of records that once made the record company money,'' said David Lowery, formerly of Camper Van Beethoven and now in Cracker on Virgin Records. ''But now, I doubt a gold record could make them money anymore.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: They need a platinum.'' Here is one more story, a common tale with a new twist: Josh Clayton-Felt, formerly of the rock group School of Fish, spent three years working on his second solo album for A&M Records.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Every time he thought he was finished, label executives sent him back into the studio with the four words that have become anathema to working musicians, ''It needs a hit.'' Mr.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Clayton-Felt turned in a total of 22 songs, then waited for executives to set a release date for the record.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: But after eight months, A&M was taken over by Interscope.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Clayton-Felt was one of some 250 artist dropped after the Universal merger.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Clayton-Felt asked if he could release the music he had recorded during that time elsewhere: the label said no.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: He asked if he could buy it back and release it himself, and again the answer was no.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Label executives said they would negotiate only with a major label.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: So he decided he would rent a studio and record new versions of the songs.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: But Universal still said no: a clause in his contract prevented his rerecording the songs for five years.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: BOB BERNSTEIN, a spokesman for Universal, said that Mr.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Clayton-Felt had been told that his album could either be released independently for a limited term or shopped to a major label. ''If he garnered interest from a major, Universal would be willing to negotiate a sale of that record,'' he said.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Clayton-Felt wrestled with the label and with himself. ''I started to look at why it has gotten to this point, that record labels have so much power,'' he said. ''And the reason is because artists have given them far too much control.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: We need to start looking out for each other.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: But we so badly want a piece of the pie that we've knocked each other down in the process of pursuing it.''    Mr.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Clayton-Felt considered changing his name to record the songs or performing them in a concert that his audience was encouraged to bootleg.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Finally, he realized that there could be as many as 100 artists in similar situations because of the merger.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: And, legally, he could bring together a dozen or so of them and record an album on which musicians take their best songs stuck in the Universal machine and give them to another performer to record.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Clayton-Felt is working on the compilation and hoping to use the proceeds to start an artist-run cooperative label. ''God, I never thought I'd say these things,'' he said after explaining his plan.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Clayton-Felt is only echoing sentiments held by Chuck D, Ms.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: What is more surprising is that a large number of popular musicians -- even lawyers and label executives -- are agreeing with them.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: No one wants to give the system another chance.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: The idea of the Internet, the alternative, is much more tempting.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: There are three things musicians want from a major label: money for recording and touring, national marketing muscle and wide distribution.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: If another system could be developed that offered musicians this trinity, then perhaps when their contracts expired they would think twice about remaining with major labels.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Especially considering that when asked, many artists said they would rather sell 200,000 copies of 10 records each than 7 million of 2. ''If we didn't have a record deal, I would explore manufacturing the records ourselves,'' Mr.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Lowery said. ''I'd make an arrangement with an independent distributor, maybe hire some Internet marketing firms, make deals with MP3 sites and run the business more like a software company.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: I would like to see if doing it that way is going to afford us more creative control and make us more money and get our music to the people we think would like us.'' (By MP3, Mr.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Lowery is referring to a popular technology that enables music to be converted into relatively small, high-quality computer files that can be easily distributed on line.) As for alternatives, there are a few different possibilities.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: The first is simply doing the work yourself.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Lately, being on their own label has paid off for musicians like Ms.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Brooke, Kristin Hersh, Jane Siberry, Ani DiFranco and, most popular and dramatically of all, the artist formerly known as Prince.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Not only did he sport the word slave on his cheek while under contract to Warner Brothers, but he also announced that he would be rerecording all 17 of his records for the label to spite it for not giving back his master tapes when he was released from his contract in 1995.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Just as it is unfortunate for artists to waste away creatively while waiting for a record label to put out their music out, it's also a shame when they spend more time doing business than making music. ''I'm swamped with the business side of things,'' said Ms.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Brooke, whose independent record has sold more copies than her major-label ones did. ''So it's very hard to put on the other hat, close the door and start banging on my piano again when I feel like I should be calling up the indie promoters and publicists working the record.'' ANOTHER alternative is a holdover from the 70's: setting up a label based on a set of artist-friendly principles and trying to get other musicians to join the collective struggle.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Fripp, the British guitarist, formed a company called Discipline Global Music.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: There is little chance that it will even cause a blip on the radar of the current music business, but its ideas could inspire a related movement that will. ''Any culture whose artists are directed or controlled by commercial interests is in mortal danger,'' Mr.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Fripp begins one section of his company's manifesto, going on to declare: ''Any record company who asks an artist, 'You want to sell records, don't you?' should be avoided.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Any A&R man who tells the artist to record a single because their album can't be promoted without one has just told the artist to change labels.'' Then there's a third, more ambitious alternative: to devise an entirely new way of doing business.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Recently, he drew up a five-point strategy, formed a musicians' collective called Musicisum with Kristen Stavola and signed up more than 45 artists to begin a noble experiment that involves the Internet, subscription fees and music filling stations.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: The plan provides that giving artists equity in the companies that market their work would motivate them.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: They would receive dividends, a much larger share of royalties, the rights to their master recordings and short, standardized contracts so that everyone would be aware of the risks and rewards in the deal.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: On a more radical note, the proposal suggests that successful musicians be asked to take a stake in new acts to help them get started.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: In turn, so-called music pirates would be encouraged to become mini-retailers instead and sell CD's and concert tickets on their own Web sites for a small profit. ''The hacker kids are the indie retailers of the future,'' said Ms.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Lanier, cautiously optimistic, predicted: ''If we do it and get crushed like bugs, we'll still have shifted what the business does so it will be better for fans and artists.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: There will just be a variety of different businesses in place -- the supertankers and ours, which will have the best music.'' There are several other schemes similar to Mr.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: What they all involve is finding a way for musicians to finance the release and marketing of their albums that does not involve their signing away their rights.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: In such proposals, it is the artists who hire the companies that promote, publicize and distribute their music.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: This way if any company isn't doing its job, it can be dismissed without serious consequences.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: And it is the Internet that serves to market -- and help distribute -- an artist's music by building up a network of dedicated fans not unlike the way the Grateful Dead did in the real world.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Of course, the best of the plans don't rely entirely on the Internet, since its capabilities to distribute music lie in the future and a large portion of music sales will take place outside the home for years to come.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: The main problem with most such approaches is capital: where does the start-up money for groups to record and promote their music come from?

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: The solution requires building better banks: Mr.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Lanier suggests having ''musician-friendly entities'' or more successful artists serving as guarantors on a loan for start-up bands.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Others suggest having financiers invest in a band in exchange for a percentage of the royalties but no other involvement, though this could create a new set of business problems.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: As anyone who's studied European revolutions knows, the revolution often becomes as tyrannical as the establishment it overthrows.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Or, as the Who once sang, ''Meet the new boss, same as the old boss.'' Public Enemy's Internet deal with Atomic Pop may be revolutionary because it will result in the first new album by a major artist available for direct download on the Internet before it is in stores.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: But look who is running Atomic Pop: Al Teller, the former head of two major labels, MCA and Columbia, for which Public Enemy recorded its first albums.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Of course, the problem in the business is not necessarily the people in charge; it's the system they're entrenched in.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: The anti-major-label sentiment expressed by Mr.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Fripp and others is nothing new in pop music.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Periodically, popular music veers into a period of stagnation and major labels shut their doors to new talent and innovation.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Those shut out develop their own voice, usually through independent labels.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: This happened in the mid-50's with rock-and-roll, what's now called classic rock in the late 60's, punk rock in the late 70's, alternative rock in the late 80's and gangsta rap in the mid-90's.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Of course, the next step is that once the major labels see the success of outsiders, they embrace them and bring them into the system.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: The result is that the alternative becomes the mainstream, demoted from rebellion to trend.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: It is then diluted with successively cheaper imitations until the myopic gatekeepers slam the doors shut again, allowing the next band of renegades to gather their forces as the labels once more focus their resources on the superstars.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: This means that today we stand at the threshold of a revolution or a repetition.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Making and Ally of Piracy Since January, major labels have been meeting to develop a system of distributing music on the Internet to combat what they see as piracy.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Jaron Lanier, a virtual-reality pioneer and a musician, sees things differently.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: He is developing what he considers to be a more sensible plan for the emerging digital economy, and here is an excerpt from his manifesto, ''Piracy Is Your Friend.'' Piracy is a phony issue that record labels are hyping to rip off artists.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: That's why there's a mountain of blank cassettes in any big electronic store.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: When someone decides to buy your music instead of copying it, they're doing it for a lot of reasons.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Maybe they like the convenience of not having to hassle with the uncertainty of copying something -- Will it come out right?

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Maybe it's their way of expressing good will to you.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: But face it, if your music wasn't available for free in some form, no one would have a chance to hear it to decide to buy it in the first place.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: The old form of ''free'' music was radio (which is often taped by pirates) and MTV, but eventually the Internet is going to take over everything.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: There will still be TV and radio, but they'll be implemented digitally.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: When that happens, the idea of not giving away music for free will be exactly the same thing as never promoting music at all.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: The real question should not be, ''How can I keep my fans from hearing my music for free?'' It should be, ''How can I best make money from my fans?'' Those are two different questions.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: But you also lose money to a label that isn't doing anything for you.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: It used to be that a label was needed to finance, manufacture, store, ship and market your music.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: If the music business wasn't shrinking before our eyes, it would still make sense.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: But in the digital era, it costs nothing to ship your music over the Internet to a fan.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: So the biggest reason for labels just went away.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: As for financing, well, if advances were stacked up against finance deals in other industries, they'd look a lot like usury -- except that they aren't even loans: once they're paid back, the label still owns the master.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: There is simply no worse conceivable form of financing.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: We can do better if we take charge of our own careers.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: But once you are established, your own Web site connects with your fan base better than the label can.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Even if you are a huge artist, think whether in the course of your whole career, not just the next couple of years, you lose more money to pirates or to labels who will be taking most of your money for no reason at all?

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: When somebody in a dorm room buys thousands of dollars' worth of gear and stays up all night hacking MP3's just to get ''free'' music, that's what you call an opportunity, not a problem.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: You have found yourself a new generation of fanatics.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: The only problem is that computer companies are making the money right now instead of musicians.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: I know computers as well as anyone on the planet, and I promise you, kids will break whatever copy protection scheme the labels come up with.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: In fact, the easier it is to copy music, the less of a threat piracy will become.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: When piracy gets easier, professional pirates have less to offer.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: And there are lots of ways to make money from fans.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: The reason the Recording Industry Association of America and the labels are pushing anti-piracy laws and technologies has nothing to do with preventing piracy.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: They're doing it so that they can control the new digital music channels.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: To keep anyone else, like you, from sharing the power.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: You can make more money in the new era of ''free'' digital music.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: But only if you break free of label mind control.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: Photos: SIGN OF DEFIANCE -- The artist formerly known as Prince wore the word slave on his cheek while under contract to Warner Brothers.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
author: NEIL STRAUSS
chunk: He also announced that he would rerecord all 17 of his albums for the label when he was released from his contract in 1995. (Stills/Retna)(pg. 1); Chuck D of the rap group Public Enemy, above, and Kristin Hersh were dissatisfied with the restrictions of their major-label contracts. title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: 1,505 words 24 May 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts by Bertelsmann, the media company, to increase its public recognition misstated the name of a women's human rights group for which the company held a fund-raiser last week.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: CORRECTED BY THE NEW YORK TIMES TUESDAY MAY 25, 1999 In a drive to become a dominant force in the digital world and take advantage of investor enthusiasm for Internet stocks, the sprawling media conglomerate Bertelsmann A.G. is laying plans to take more of its on-line operations public.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Bertelsmann is already expected to offer stock later this week in its on-line bookselling joint venture with Barnes & Noble Inc., Barnesandnoble.com.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: And it has announced plans to issue shares in its Berlin-based Web site and software design concern, Pixelpark.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: But those only presage other Bertelsmann stock offerings in coming months, according to Thomas Middelhoff, the company's chief executive and chairman.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Middelhoff would specifically cite only Springer-Verlag, a professional book publisher that offers more than 400 technical and medical journals through an information service called Link.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: The company's Internet operations also include the music site Getmusic.com and an expanding group of on-line bookstores in Europe called BOL.com, for Bertelsmann Online.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: As part of its Web push, Bertelsmann, which is based in Guetersloh, Germany, also hopes to make Internet access more affordable in Europe, where users complain bitterly about having to pay not only for connection time but also a separate rate for use of the underlying telephone line.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Middelhoff said last week, the company plans to switch to a package of fixed monthly rates for subscribers of America Online Inc.'s Europe operation, in which Bertelsmann owns a 50 percent stake.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Middelhoff also said that Bertelsmann and the Microsoft Corporation were considering joining in a bid for Deutsche Telekom A.G.'s cable television operations, so that Bertelsmann ultimately could sell music titles over the Internet through those high-capacity cable lines. ''We are having preliminary discussions,'' he said, ''very preliminary.'' With projected revenue of $18.5 billion next year, Bertelsmann is the world's third-largest media company, behind Time Warner Inc. and the Walt Disney Company.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: But it is a private company, and so Bertelsmann has not had publicly traded stock to use as a currency for making deals in this age of stock deals.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Nor has Bertelsmann had the kind of high profile and brand recognition that lend instant cachet to a public stock offering. ''In this Internet world, we compete with companies that are public,'' said Mr.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Middelhoff, who is intent on competing with nimble rivals like Amazon.com. ''How do we compete with such cash-rich, aggressive Internet companies?

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: We decided that the only way to handle that competition is we have to bring our Internet companies public.'' Mr.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Middelhoff discussed the plans in an interview in his 44th-floor office above Times Square, in the headquarters of Bertelsmann's United States operation, where he typically works at least one week a month.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Since becoming chief executive last year, he has been intent on raising the profile of Bertelsmann, which spans more than 50 countries with almost 60,000 employees in 300 subsidiaries -- including the top trade book publisher in the United States, Random House Inc.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Bertelsmann's plan to take more companies public in the coming months is part of a broader corporate trend, according to David R.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Brodwin, an associate partner at Andersen Consulting, a management and technology consulting firm. ''They're in the first wave, one of the pioneers,'' Mr.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Brodwin said. ''All the major media companies are wrestling with how to compete with the Internet and how to compete with start-ups.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Most of these companies are public and they simply can't afford to spend the kind of money that the competition is able to spend based on their initial public offerings.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: They can't afford to do the kinds of deals that they can for stock.'' Such ''spin-outs,'' as Mr.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Brodwin called them, can present potential problems in large companies.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: One is that managers in the parent corporation's core companies may resent the stock options that managers in newly public companies receive.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Another is that it could heighten tensions and divisions between rival divisions of a far-flung organization.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Middelhoff seems ready to take that risk with companies like Springer-Verlag, in which Bertelsmann acquired a majority stake last year for $597 million.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Springer, which has offices in the Flatiron Building in Manhattan, is seen as having particular appeal for investors because of its Link advanced electronic network.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Middelhoff was reluctant to identify other companies that could be offered to the public, other than indicating they would probably be Internet plays.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: He took pains, though, to say the list would not include Random House, which Bertelsmann acquired last year. ''Random House?

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Never, never, never will this jewel ever be brought public,'' he said. ''Unthinkable.'' As he spoke, Mr.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Middelhoff's comments were interrupted occasionally by the throbbing vibrations of a band performing in a nearby room for executives from Bertelsmann's music business, whose labels include Arista, RCA and Windham Hill.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: But he pressed on, repeatedly stressing that the company must move rapidly. ''We have to become No. 1 in all our content businesses and we have to be No. 1 as far as the media and E-commerce business is concerned,'' he said. ''Worldwide.'' This week's offering of Barnesandnoble.com, he said, is an example of that new aggressiveness.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: The two partners are planning to sell 25 million shares, or about 18 percent of the company.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Each will retain about a 41 percent interest in the new company. (Barnes & Noble has a business tie to The New York Times, selling books through links from the newspaper's Web site.) Mr.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Middelhoff is also tending to the political aspects that will come with owning a publicly traded company.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: He is considering offering some sort of stock options to all Bertelsmann managers to avoid creating two classes of executives within the corporation.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: He is also expanding the seminars offered through ''Bertelsmann University,'' a business training program done in conjunction with Harvard University that seeks to increase cooperation among the company's managers. ''The only way to achieve the changes we want is through the brains of our executives,'' Mr.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Middelhoff said. ''And they really have to understand that they're going to have to change their minds.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: If you have a corporate culture, which believes that they don't have to change, then with such a culture we will not survive.'' But perhaps his most difficult problem is promoting the image of Bertelsmann, which will be an important part of attracting investors for the various spin-outs.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Bertelsmann may be the third-ranked media company in the world, but its brand name does not have the widespread recognition of a Disney or Time Warner. ''I think they're very concerned about their image as Germans,'' Albert N.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth

chunk: Greco, an associate professor of business at Fordham University who studies media management. ''There's no brand recognition.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth

chunk: They did that on purpose for a long time and now when they're thinking of branding the company they have to have a different strategy.'' And yet, even as as Mr.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth

chunk: He has also started to dabble with charities.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
