title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: 1,286 words 19 April 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company Each time a revolutionary new technology has arrived, the governments of the day have been leery of its capacity for mischief and criminality.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Centuries ago, there were calls for giving the authorities the power of prior restraint lest the printing press become an instrument of sedition and slander.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Later, there were qualms about selling automobiles to the public because crooks could use them to escape the police.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: As the designated representative of this rich and checkered tradition, Philip Reitinger, a prosecutor for the Justice Department, knew he faced a tough crowd last Tuesday in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: He was speaking at a conference to mark the 35th anniversary of the founding of the Laboratory for Computer Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a gathering of technology's true believers.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Reitinger, square-jawed and pin-striped, opened with a bit of dry humor, laced with sarcasm. ''It may come as a shock to many of you, but people commit crimes on the Internet,'' he said.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: So began a spirited discussion and debate on a seemingly narrow subject, ''Should the Laboratory for Computer Science Anonymous Remailer Be Shut Down?'' But the discussion focused on some of the broadest social and legal issues involving the Internet: identity, privacy, anonymity and free speech.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Reitinger's opposite number on the panel was Nadine Strossen, a professor at the New York Law School and president of the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: They were joined by Frans Kaashoek, an associate professor at M.I.T., who has been in charge of the anonymous remailer since it began operating in 1996.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: An anonymous remailer, a type of data-network relay, is essentially a technological buffer, offering confidentiality to its users.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: It can be used to mask the origin of a piece of E-mail or the computer from which a person is browsing the World Wide Web.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: It does this by stripping off the identifying information on an E-mail, for example, and substituting an anonymous code number or term.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Sophisticated remailers, like the one at M.I.T., also route messages through many different relay computers around the world, leaving no record of the path an anonymous message traveled after leaving the remailer.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But computer experts have occasionally tracked messages from remailers, either because a person used an anonymity service incorrectly or because of security flaws in a remailer.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: There are about 40 anonymous remail services worldwide.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: They are used by, among others, dissidents and human rights representatives in nations with repressive governments, whistle-blowers in companies or government agencies, minority groups fearing discrimination and people simply wishing to avoid the bulk E-mail advertising that marketers increasingly send over the Net.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: In Kosovo, some people with on-line connections have started using anonymous remail services to try to maintain confidential communications and avoid detection by the Serbian military.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But anonymous remail services, Federal prosecutors say, are also used by child pornographers, extortionists, software pirates and drug dealers.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Though not illegal, remailers are often viewed with suspicion by law enforcement agencies.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: They occupy a gray area in cyberspace, and Mr.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Kaashoek good-naturedly underscored that fact by wearing a black ski mask for much of the panel discussion.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Reitinger turned to his theme. ''Anonymity has a down side to it,'' he said. ''It's hard to put a pseudonym in jail.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: There are not a lot of indictments that say, United States of America versus John Doe.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: If people are truly anonymous, there can be no law enforcement.'' Mr.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Strossen have debated these issues in the past, so their early exchanges had the practiced rhythms of old sparring partners.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Her opening salvo: ''We've got to make sure that freedom of speech, freedom of the press and privacy are as protected in cyberspace as they are in the rest of life.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Certain individual rights cannot be sacrificed because of the panic and fears of abuse of a new technology, or because it creates problems for law enforcement.'' Mr.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Reitinger, a senior counsel in the Justice Department's computer crime and intellectual property division, agreed that the Internet had made his life more difficult.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Trying to trace a path of criminal communications often involves working with authorities in 8 to 20 nations, he observed.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Anonymous remailers can make that tracing far more difficult, if not impossible.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Kaashoek said M.I.T. had received several subpoenas from state and Federal authorities since the university's remailer was set up in 1996.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: M.I.T., he said, has answered the subpoenas but he noted that typically the tracking information it can offer involves only one leg of a many-legged path of communication. ''If a person is using our system correctly,'' Mr.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Kaashoek said, ''law enforcement isn't going to find that information very useful.'' As a medium, the Internet does seem unique in the way that it magnifies the issues of privacy and anonymity. ''The problem is that this technology is just so darned powerful,'' said Paul Saffo, a director of the Institute for the Future. ''It makes it easy to be anonymous, but it can also make it far easier to track people down and invade their privacy.'' Mr.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Saffo did not attend the debate, but both Ms.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Reitinger addressed the point that Internet technology has raised the stakes on matters of privacy.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Both agreed that the technology poses difficult challenges, though they approached the subject from understandably different vantage points.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Strossen said she was ''very concerned'' that new software technology allows corporations or governments to track a person's every mouse click and to assemble vast digital dossiers on individuals. ''It can include all your personal financial transactions and your medical records,'' she observed. ''I don't think our laws adequately protect individual privacy anymore.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The technologies of anonymity and cryptography may be the only way to protect privacy.'' To which Mr.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Reitinger replied: ''I think we are perilously close to a lose-lose situation in which citizens have lost their privacy to commercial interests and criminals have easy access to absolute anonymity.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: That's not a world we want.'' There was scattered clapping for various remarks made during the debate, but that comment from Mr.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Reitinger was greeted with sustained applause.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Sophisticated criminals, of course, will always have access to the latest technology, whether cars or software.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Reitinger told the audience of computer scientists, ''I'm just asking that you help law enforcement to capture the stupid criminals.'' use anonymous remailers to send E-mail messages, trying to mask the identity of the original sender.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: There are about 40 remailers around the world. 1.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Messages can be sent to the anonymous remailer by anyone, from anywhere.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Some remailers assign I.D. number to users, a list of which is kept by the remailer administrator. 2.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: A remailer receives an incoming message, automatically strips off all traces of the sender's identity and then forwards the message -- to a single electronic mail box, or to thousands of addresses or to other remailers. 3.

title: Privacy on Internet Poses Legal Puzzle
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Because the messages are remailed in a random sequence different from the order in which they arrive, people who may be monitoring the remailers cannot match the outgoing messages with the incoming messages to identify who sent which message. title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: 1,680 words 2 June 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company Merrill Lynch, which grew to be the nation's biggest retail brokerage house through an army of 14,000 stockbrokers who mixed advice with salesmanship, bent to the pressures of the Internet era yesterday, announcing that it would add a low-cost service for people who want to trade on line.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: Like leading firms in many industries, Merrill has been struggling to find a way to compete with cheaper on-line upstarts.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: From bookstores to travel agencies, companies must decide how much to risk their existing large and profitable businesses in order to do battle with small, unprofitable but rapidly growing Internet competitors.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: Merrill, which has more brokers and assets than any other such firm, has for years held the line, arguing that customers would be willing to pay its higher fees for superior service and in-depth analysis.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: But ultimately it decided that Internet trading was neither a fad nor a small segment of the market.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: Indeed, 6.3 million households trade stocks over the Internet, and they account for one in every seven stock trades in the country.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: Beginning in December, Merrill, which now charges $80 to $100 for an average trade, will let customers trade on line for $29.95, matching Charles Schwab & Company, the largest brokerage firm on the Internet.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: But those customers will not get access to research or guidance from a broker.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: Alternately, customers can pay an annual fee of at least $1,500 for unlimited trading and advice, either on line or through a broker. ''We could see just by observing the growth of Schwab's asset base that there was a segment of the market that wants to use technology and only technology,'' said David H.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: While a few of the other traditional full-service brokerage firms have introduced on-line trading in one or another form, analysts say that most of them will have to go much further to match Merrill, along with Schwab and the on-line brokers. ''This puts a lot of pressure on other full-service firms to respond in kind,'' said Bill Burnham, an electronic commerce analyst at Credit Suisse.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: The full-service brokers have mainly tried to offer trading on line while forcing customers to use and pay for a broker.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: Prudential Securities, for example, introduced an account similar to Merrill's new flat-fee program that combines on-line trading with advice.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: Burnham said that the full- service brokers would also have to compete head to head with a low-cost Internet offering, as Merrill has done. ''Merrill is two years late to the game, but you have to hand it to them; they didn't get half pregnant,'' he said. ''They looked at Schwab and said if you can't beat them join them.'' Two other full-service firms have low-cost Internet units -- Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter -- but they have segregated them from their full-service operations.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: Merrill's approach, by contrast, invites clients to have both traditional accounts and discount Internet trading accounts at the same time, with trades from either reported on one statement.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: Merrill considered a separate Internet unit as well but decided it needed to reach out to its existing customers because an increasing number had already opened an account with an on-line competitor to try Internet trading on their own.    ''I think that it will be the rule that people use multiple forms of accounts with us,'' Mr.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: He also said he believed most Merrill clients would stick with the current broker-client account at least for the near future, with both the Internet and flat-fee accounts attracting new customers.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: The biggest losers from all of this may not be the brokerage firms but the brokers themselves. ''This isn't about E*Trade saying, 'Boot your broker,' '' said Christos Cotsakos, the chairman of E*Trade group, a big on-line broker. ''This is Merrill booting their own brokers.'' Merrill argues that while some brokers may lose business in the short run, the move is necessary to attract a new generation of clients for the firm.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: Since much of the trading at on-line brokerage firms represents an increase in activity, traditional firms are not seeing declines in their business.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: But their growth is far slower than that of firms like Schwab and E*Trade.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: Solotar, a brokerage stock analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said, ''On-line trading raises a new threat, but the retail brokerage business is still extraordinarily profitable.'' Even so, she said Merrill was risking some medium-term profits to increase its growth rate.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: As customers move from full commission to the discount program, she predicted that Merrill's profits could be cut by as much as 10 percent in two years.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: And she expressed skepticism that people would choose Merrill simply as a discount broker. ''Most likely, the Merrill Lynch client will continue to use the services of a financial consultant, but they may also decide to do some trading on line,'' she said Beyond the impact of the Internet on trading, Merrill's announcement yesterday tries to answer a longstanding criticism of the traditional broker-client relationship -- namely, that the broker's fees for each transaction mean that his or her advice is often inspired as much by salesmanship as by objective analysis.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: This issue will be addressed with the new Internet service and with a new pricing plan for traditional brokerage services.

title: LOW-COST TRADING ON LINE IS PLANNED BY MERRILL LYNCH
author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: Many full-service brokers, including Merrill, are hoping Internet trading will shift clients from per-trade commissions to flat annual fees.

author: SAUL HANSELL
chunk: They have been offering these so-called wrap accounts for more than a decade, using brokers for trading, but the appeal has been limited.

chunk: For example, only 2 percent of Merrill's customers use its current flat-fee account, which had higher annual fees.

''I stayed longer than I intended to, and I really get angry at innuendos that the board booted me out, or that Dan staged a palace coup,'' said Mr.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Fisher, who will remain Kodak's chairman until the end of 2000. ''I should be getting high marks for managing a succession plan that was smooth as ice, yet everyone is looking for subplots.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The fact is, some board members just didn't want me to leave, period.'' Indeed, in a conversation in his Rochester offices, as a bright winter sun bathed his face -- ''I'm a child of the sun, I'll take the window side in a plane just to enjoy the glare,'' he said with a laugh -- Mr.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Fisher seemed anything but shaken or contrite. ''I never believed the hype about me going in, and I don't believe the bad things people say now,'' he said. ''I never deserved to be put on a pedestal, but I also didn't deserve to be knocked off it so inappropriately.'' As Mr.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Fisher tells it, when he was persuaded by Roberto C.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Goizueta, then chief executive of Coca-Cola and a Kodak board member, to take Kodak's top job in 1993, the company was a mess.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: It had haphazardly diversified into pharmaceuticals and other areas it knew little about.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Its growth, save the revenues it added on with ill-starred acquisitions, was flat.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: It was a high-cost manufacturer, with a bloated staff and a sleepy culture that was slow to make decisions.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: And it regarded digital photography as the   enemy, an evil juggernaut that would kill the chemical-based film and paper business that had fueled Kodak's sales and profits for decades. ''This was a great American icon that was going the wrong way, fast,'' Mr.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Fisher said. ''Roberto said, 'You've got to do this for God and America, you've got to get it directed into the next century, to make Kodak's own people understand that this company has a future.' '' Mr.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: He notes that today, Kodak is focused on pictures, nothing else.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: It is nearly 20,000 jobs lighter, and a lot nimbler, thanks in part to a set of culture-changing incentives that reward managers for fast decisions and even faster execution.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Roughly a third of its senior managers are new in their jobs; the board includes many more outsiders.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: And the company has a huge presence in China and other emerging markets, where most experts think consumer use of cameras is poised to explode.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Finally, this year, Kodak started growing again, with sales up about 5 percent.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Its per-share earnings are rising, while its debt is shrinking.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Kodak also has a new ''digitization strategy'' for using digital technology to enhance, not replace, conventional film.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Through Internet partnerships that let customers receive electronic versions of their photos by e-mail, through kiosks that let them manipulate and reproduce old photographs, and through archival services that let users store their photographs on CD-ROM's or on the Internet, Kodak has managed not only to salvage its profitable chemical-based photography business, it has added a technological veneer to it.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: He has already sold his Rochester home, a 15-room house on 15 acres that Mr.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Fisher, an avid horticulturist, said has the most beautiful trees of any place he has lived in.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: He and his wife, Ann, will move into a small apartment after the sale closes in March, but come 2001, it will be goodbye to Rochester. ''Sure, I feel sad, I loved that house, and I'll miss many Kodak people, but I always knew I'd leave town when the job at Kodak was over,'' Mr.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Fisher said. ''It would have been too difficult to stay on after being head of Kodak, you become such an icon.'' Following are other excerpts from a nearly three-hour reminiscence session: Q.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: There are those who view your tenure at Kodak as a terrible disappointment.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: I remember telling Roberto it would take three years to get Kodak on track.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: He said it would take five, and O.K., it's taken closer to seven.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But the fact is, I've accomplished everything I set out to do.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: I get angry when I get mail from people complaining about my performance, or when members of the press select the quotes they use to paint negative stories.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: We're going to have the best financial year in the history of the company, and a lot of analysts do have buy ratings on Kodak stock these days.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal

chunk: I got Kodak pointed in the right direction, and if the new team gets all the credit for that, well, godspeed to them.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Smart people will recognize that I laid the fundamentals.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: When you write the history of these last six years, you'll find that one of my greatest contributions was changing the culture here.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But it was supposed to be turning Kodak into a digital profit machine.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: In 1993 no one, not even Bill Gates, understood the impact of theInternet.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Maybe my real failure is that I haven't communicated how powerful our digitization strategy really is.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But you are losing $100 million a year in digital, and shareholders are clearly unimpressed.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: You call it losses, I call it investment.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: If this were a stand-alone start-up company, I'd be a hero on Wall Street.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: I'm growing the business 40 percent a year, and if I were losing $100 million as a start-up, investors would say ''big deal.'' There are 117 dot-com companies out there who keep saying they'll eat Kodak and Fuji up.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: It amazes me how many smart people believe such stupid statements.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: I wish I could get investors to sit down and ask good questions, but some people are just too stupid.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: I remember a time when Motorola's stock was down, and Bob Galvin, the chairman, asked me three things.

author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Am I doing the right things in the right way?

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: As you look back over the last six years, are there memories that make you wince?

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: We lost the World Trade Organization decision [regarding Japan's market for photographic film]; the currency went south; the health organizations got aggressive in purchasing medical films; our CD-ROM prices collapsed; our leading film competitor got aggressive in pricing.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Even our race car started losing all its races!

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: There were days I wondered whether there was some gravitational field from the outer universe impinging on us.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: I never doubted myself, but there were times I wondered if I could handle one more piece of bad news.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: I had no choice but to promise we'd take $1 billion out of costs.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: I'm a nice person, a good person; I don't like hurting people.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: I'd spent my first few years traveling all around Kodak, and I knew these people personally.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: These were people who really trusted me, put their faith in me.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Cutting all those jobs, all at once and in such a harsh way, was one of the most painful things I've done in my life.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: More painful than knowing that many people think that you, too, were thrown out of your job against your will?

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The main problem seems to be the perception of the press.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The press doesn't understand how companies run.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: And yes, I was really caught off guard, and very hurt, by the negative perceptions that came out in so many articles when the succession was announced.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal

chunk: But I have the confidence of my brain, of knowing I can think and move in real time.

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal
author: SETH SCHIESEL

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal

title: Lucent and Level 3 Reach $1 Billion Phone Gear Deal

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: 1,769 words 24 March 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the transmission of voice calls using Internet technology misstated the location of the headquarters of Vocall Communications.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: It is in Mountainside, N.J., not Philadelphia.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: CORRECTED BY THE NEW YORK TIMES WEDNESDAY MARCH 30, 1999 SAN JOSE, Calif., March 20 -- When John T.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Chambers, chief executive of Cisco Systems Inc., walks into his windowless, cubicle-like office here each morning, he sees a dinosaur on his desk that he is intent on driving to extinction.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: It sits to the left of his laptop computer's docking station: a standard office telephone made by Lucent Technologies Inc., the former equipment arm of the AT&T Corporation and North America's largest maker of traditional telephone gear.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Chambers likes to think of Cisco, the No. 1 maker of equipment for data networks, as the Anti-Lucent; his favorite two expressions are ''new world'' (read Cisco and the Internet) and ''old world'' (read Lucent and traditional communications).

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: So just about every time he uses that phone he bristles. ''The dinosaur on my desk, or at home, I want gone in the next 12 months,'' he says.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: What he means is that by this time next year he wants Cisco to be deploying phone systems based on Internet technology rather than on traditional communications systems.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: If nothing else, he wants almost all of Cisco's 17,000 employees using them.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Chambers may exaggerate the gap for effect, there certainly are new and old worlds in the communications equipment business, and they are locked in a struggle to control the networks of the future and the tens, perhaps hundreds, of billions of dollars that will be spent to build them.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: No part of that battle is more intense than the fight to control how standard voice telephone calls will be transmitted using the technology known variously as Internet telephony or voice-over-I.P.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The I.P. stands for Internet protocol, the language of cyberspace.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The challenges of that battle are clearly evident right there on Mr.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: After all, Internet phones do exist today -- Cisco makes them -- but for now, Mr.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: It is a battle between the reliable, pin-drop quality of today's telecommunications technology and the largely experimental, often garbled but fantastically promising Internet-based technology of tomorrow. ''This is about the hearts and minds of the network,'' said Howard Anderson, managing director of the Yankee Group, a leading high-technology consulting firm based in Boston. ''For consumers, it's probably going to mean cheaper costs.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The consumer is going to be using voice-over-I.P. without even knowing it.'' Yet, for all of the promise, most of the communications industry agrees that Internet phone calls are not quite ready for prime time.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: While I.P. systems are selling well in niche phone markets, they are still too unreliable, often deliver low sound quality and are perhaps even too expensive to become the underlying network language for mainstream phone calls.    ''There's a lot of hype,'' said Howard McNally, president of the AT&T unit that includes the company's small Internet telephony operation. ''It's just not there yet.'' The Sprint Corporation and MCI Worldcom Inc. are not offering voice-over-I.P. calls at all.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: That is not to suggest that the long-distance giants are happily stuck in the old world.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Each of the major carriers is getting set to upgrade the core of its network to use a technology called asynchronous transfer mode, which, like Internet protocol increases efficiency by breaking communications down into small pieces.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But while it may sometimes not be as efficient as I.P., it has the advantage of being more reliable.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: One strength of I.P., in addition to the allure of being the language of the Internet, is that it is relatively simple to deploy.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But what makes it even more appealing is that it can be used on the millions of existing corporate and institutional networks based on Internet protocol and with the tens of millions of personal computers and other consumer devices for which Internet protocol is already a lingua franca.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: For all these reasons, the belief in many parts of the communications industry that Internet phone calls are not ready for the mainstream right now is matched by an equally strong conviction that if Internet phone calls do not move to the mainstream, the mainstream will eventually come to Internet phone calls.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Today, Internet phone calls often require the use of prepaid calling cards.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: And generally their primary purpose is to avoid high international charges for conventional phone calls as well as the fees imposed by local phone companies for beginning and ending long-distance calls.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But companies are also starting to embrace Internet technology as a way to save money by transmitting calls among branch offices using the computer networks they already have.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Chambers is ever to feel that his entire office has migrated to the new world, Cisco will have to come up with I.P.-based office phone systems that offer conference calling, call waiting, voice mail, call transferring and other features office workers take for granted.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But ultimately, Internet-based phone systems could offer services that no one takes for granted today, like easy integration with personal computer applications.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Users could easily manage voice and E-mail messages or, where legal, digitally record and transcribe phone conversations. ''We feel that I.P. telephony services, as they develop multimedia and other capabilities that I.P. enables, are going to be the clear winner in the next two to three years,'' said David Greenblatt, chief operating officer of Net2Phone, the Internet telephone subsidiary of the IDT Corporation, one of the pioneers in Internet phone calls. companies: traditional equipment makers like Lucent, Ericsson A.B., Siemens A.G. and Northern Telecom; data networking companies like the 3Com Corporation and Ascend Communications Inc. (which has agreed to be acquired by Lucent); and upstarts like Vocaltec Communications Ltd. and the Clarent Corporation.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Lucent, Cisco's biggest and most important competitor, is also hard at work developing Internet telephony products, but its executives naturally have a different view of traditional phone systems. ''There isn't anything in the industry that provides the reliability, the scalability and the feature functions'' of the traditional office phone system, said William T.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: O'Shea, who runs Lucent's office systems group. ''There plain isn't another answer today.'' But right now the bigger carriers appear to lean toward equipment made by the smaller companies vying for Internet telephony leadership.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: While AT&T is testing Lucent's I.P. enhancement for existing telephone switches, the biggest carrier using Lucent's stand-alone Internet phone system is probably Vocall Communications, a private company based in Philadelphia.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Meanwhile, Cisco's biggest Internet telephony client is ICG Communications Inc., a medium-sized communications carrier.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Still, many carriers believe the traditional telephone equipment companies will continue to have an advantage simply because they have more experience designing reliability into their systems.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Among that group is Noam Bardin, chief technology officer for Delta 3, the Internet telephone unit of RSL Communications, one of the world's biggest Internet telephony carriers.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Cisco, he said, has ''a huge hurdle to conquer when you think about how people pick up the phone and expect to get a dial tone no matter what. ''The telecom companies,'' he added, ''already have experience in those challenges.'' Delta 3 mostly uses equipment from Ericsson, while IDT, tellingly perhaps, mostly designs its own equipment.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: IDT has also evaluated equipment from Siemens, which in turn has also worked closely with a small carrier called USA Global Link.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But the German giant Deutsche Telekom is among the international phone companies that have used equipment from tiny Vocaltec, and when Sprint wanted to evaluate an Internet phone system, it tried products from Clarent, a private company based in Redwood City, Calif.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Sprint decided against introducing a voice-over-Internet product, but Neil J.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Grenfell, an engineering vice president at Sprint, said the decision would not have been different if another company's technology had been used.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: AT&T has been perhaps the most eclectic carrier of all.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The company refused to discuss its suppliers, but senior data networking executives and executives close to AT&T said the company initially used modems from U.S.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Robotics and other equipment from 3Com, the company that acquired U.S.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: AT&T has also, however, used significant amounts of Internet telephony equipment from Clarent, the executives said, adding that 3Com is trying to negotiate a new Internet telephony deal with AT&T.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Perhaps the biggest roadblock for Internet telephony is that different companies' systems almost never work with one another.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Each wants to dictate the standard and is hoping the others will blink. ''In ideal conditions it's acceptable,'' Sprint's Mr.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Grenfell said of I.P. telephony. ''But I think it's just going to be a novelty for a while.

title: Hello, Operator? Get Me The Internet
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: We're really looking for a total integrated solution that is interoperable between vendors and works with what we already have.'' Perhaps even with dinosaurs.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Inside PARC (which stands for Palo Alto Research Center), the offices are comfortable, almost domestic in scale (not stark, arid cubicles) and tastefully decorated in a style more reminiscent of subdued northern California ranch-style homes than of high-tech corporations.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: In the lobby, Rich Gold, who is not a scientist or engineer but an artist, greets a visitor and leads the way through several halls, past conference rooms furnished with oversize beanbag chairs to a small kitchenette to pick up coffee before sitting down in his office to talk.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Like the PARC building and its surroundings, Mr.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: He began as an artist, studying at the State University of New York at Albany and the California Institute of the Arts, then got his master's of fine arts in the contemporary-music department at Mills College in Oakland.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: He worked for Mattel toys, among other places, designing electronic computer games, and eventually landed a job with Xerox PARC in 1991 as part of its Ubiquitous Computing Project, a branch of the company that focuses on computation embedded in everyday objects.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Gold, with help from his colleagues, started PAIR, the PARC Artists-in-Residence Program, under which innovative Bay Area artists worked in teams with about a dozen scientists at Xerox PARC.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Gold, knowing both the contemporary-art world and the high-tech corporate world, believed that there were compelling intellectual and creative points of contact between contemporary artists working with new media and cutting-edge scientists.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: In order to explore and encourage this cross-pollination, he approached the management at PARC with a proposed series of partnerships that would join artists with scientists in an effort to encourage various personal exchanges.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Pure research, rather than specific product development, was the goal that both Mr.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Gold and the management had in mind. (A rather unusual idea in a traditional corporate profit-making structure.) Two committees were formed to select the artists.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: The first was made up of Xerox PARC scientists; the second, according to Mr.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Gold, consisted of ''Bay Area art curators, gallery owners, heads of art departments, as well as people from Theater Artaud and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, all in an effort to get as much of a range as we could.'' One requirement for the participating artists was that they be well versed in new technology so that they could begin working on an equal footing with their scientist partners.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: The PAIR project has a well-known historical precedent.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: In the mid-1960's, Billy Kluver, an engineer of Swedish origin working at Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., became interested in the New York art world and in particular the work of Pop artists.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: He started a program in which engineers from Bell met with artists like Jean Tinguely, Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, Merce Cunningham, John Cage, Andy Warhol and many others.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Through these collaborative pairings, Mr.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Rauschenberg, Fred Waldhauer and Robert Whitman started a program called Experiments in Art and Technology, or E.A.T., in 1966.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: SOME of the results of the E.A.T. collaborations, like Warhol's floating silver pillows and Mr.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Rauschenberg's robots, were included in World Expo '70 in Osaka, Japan.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Kluver, now in his 70's, has become something of a celebrity.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: He is on the international lecture circuit discussing more than 40 projects he completed with E.A.T.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Kluver is organizing the E.A.T. archives, stored in his home in   Berkeley Heights, N.J.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: These massive files offer a glimpse of the birth of the Art and Technology movement during the 1960's and 1970's.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: The San Jose Museum of Art in California is currently working on an interactive CD-ROM on the history of this period.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Gold thought of setting up a program linking artists and scientists at Xerox, he called Mr.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Gold from undertaking the pairings, saying that artists and scientists were perhaps too similar in nature to be able to work productively together.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: He thought the only workable match would be between artists and engineers, seeing the engineers as the facilitators of the artists' work.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Gold, ''Kluver believed that artists needed engineers to help build their stuff.'' The artists were initially invited to work at PARC for several months to a year.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: However, it soon became apparent that this was not a realistic time frame.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Most of the artists ended up close friends with the scientists and stayed in contact and worked with them for three to four years.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Judy Malloy was one of the first artists to work in PAIR.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: She started in November 1993 with an office at PARC and access to the computer science labs.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Malloy, a Bay Area hypertext writer, worked with the scientist Pavel Curtis on a project called ''Brown House Kitchen,'' a narrative written by Ms.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Malloy to accompany a text-based virtual-reality site created at PARC by Mr.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Malloy, this was a rare opportunity to create ''public literature'' in a virtual community. ''Unlike the Web,'' she says, ''which is basically an information-delivery system, MUDS -- the Multi-User Dungeons we used -- are cohesive text-based universes that exist parallel to life, where stories that occur daily are usually observed only by the participants, just as they are in real life.'' Ms.

author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Malloy also worked with Cathy Marshal, a hypertext researcher, on a project called ''Forward Anywhere.'' Ms.

author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Marshal's relationship started via E-mail as a way of getting to know each other.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Both women had been using hypertext, which, according to Ms.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Malloy, is the ''way in which the reader navigates information on the Web by following/choosing links rather than moving sequentially.'' ''This way of reading,'' she continues, ''allows for choices that determine the way the story unfolds, allowing each reader to see a different narrative.'' During more than four years working together, Ms.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Somehow they found that ''face-to-face meetings diluted the mystery and anticipation'' of their collaborative relationship.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Even though the participating artists and scientists came from very different backgrounds, they usually had strands of similar interests that drew them together.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: For example, the collaborative artist team of Jeanne C.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Muse recall that ''at Xerox PARC we were paired with members of the Work Practice and Technology area, W.P.T., a small group of anthropologists lead by Lucy Suchman, and computer scientists who study work and the practices by which workers take up technologies in creative and necessarily unpredictable ways.'' They said, in writing: ''W.P.T. also uses video and interview-observation in their research.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: We shared not only technologies but also a concern for the ethical implications of using them to create and distribute images, texts and stories.'' SINCE 1994, Margaret Crane and Jon Winet, another artist team, have been paired with the computer scientists Scott Minneman and Dale MacDonald.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: This collaboration, perhaps the most prolific of all of the PAIR groupings, lasted more than four years and perhaps influenced Mr.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: MacDonald's decision to enter the M.F.A. studio-art program at the University of California at Berkeley.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Crane says, involved ''exploring the intersection of art and technology and the impact of the Internet and interactive media on public space.'' Among their many projects together, this team, working under the name C.M.M.W., produced ''Nightfall,'' a hypertextual multimedia installation that was shown at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Crane explains, ''examines personal relationships against the backdrop of social malaise and psychic unrest in the waning moments of the 20th century.'' The team also made ''Sunset,'' an interactive narrative that was displayed on two Sony Jumbotrons on Sunset Boulevard in Hollywood as part of Siggraph 97's Electronic Garden.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: In 1994, Paul DeMarinis, a multimedia electronic artist, started working with several different research groups at PARC.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: His project ''Dinner at Ernie's'' involved the production of four spinning turntables playing low-resolution music.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: He also worked on a project involving an electronic stringed instrument resembling a lyre that created a circuit between the viewer's body and the flesh of an orange.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Pamela Z, a performance and sound artist, was paired with the researchers Michael Black and David Levy.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Through their conversations, three audio works emerged.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Z made ''Geekspeak,'' a section of ''Parts of   Speech,'' a larger piece. ''Geekspeak'' was constructed through the use, in part, of Mr.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Black's voice, which was then played back to him on the speakers in his office.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Levy's discussions often revolved around the idea of copies.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Z's sound and installation works titled ''Copies'' uses a short audio text written by Mr.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: The private relationships forged between two or three people at a time by the PAIR project is now getting a much more public face.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Press (Leonardo Books) released ''Art and Innovation: The Xerox PARC Artist-in-Residence Program,'' edited by Craig Harris of Leonardo Electronic Almanac.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: The PAIR project is continuing but always evolving.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: It is currently working with a graphic novelist -- once called a cartoonist -- on the future of reading.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: PAIR is ultimately an investigation into the nature of art and technology as a series of personal exchanges as well as more formal cultural systems.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: Even though, for the most part, the teams have produced little tangible work (read ''product''), they have always been immersed in something that has in many ways beenmore lasting.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: They have been given the space and time to think, talk and learn from one another.

title: A Bucolic Honeymoon for Art and Science
author: ANNA NOVAKOV
chunk: In an age that values speed and transience, such an opportunity is always precious and increasingly hard to find.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: 1,601 words 14 June 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 -- The implications of the malicious software program that wove its way around the globe last week struck home for Bernardo Huberman, a physicist at Xerox, in the form of a terse voice mail he received at work on Thursday. ''Our computer system administrators sent me a message saying, 'The worm has hit Xerox, but we've hunted it down and killed it,' '' he recalled.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Huberman, who has studied computer networks for more than a decade, the biological allusions were an apt reminder that the explosive growth of the Internet has numerous parallels to natural systems -- and many are not reassuring. ''I believe that we are indeed living in a computational ecosystem which is more and more globally cross-linked,'' he said.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Or to put it more simply, ''It's an amazing system, and it's very vulnerable.'' In a world where computers, once isolated work tools, are increasingly the very engine driving modern business life, computer researchers say they are detecting an ominous trend toward programs that mimic viruses and pestilence in the physical world.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The latest focus of concern is a program known among computer researchers as a worm.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The one last week was apparently conceived in Israel and quickly spread to Europe and the United States, mailing itself from computer to computer and destroying its victims' files along the way.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Called Explore.exe -- for the name of the file it contained that set off the damage -- the worm has affected thousands of computers worldwide and forced a number of corporations to abruptly shut their E-mail systems, in a frantic effort to control the spread of the infection.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Like biological diseases, which exploit the most basic mechanism of life -- the power of DNA to replicate itself -- a subculture of modern virus-writing now manipulates that same power of replication within the world of interconnected computers.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: And while the dominance of a single environment -- the one powered by Microsoft software and Intel chips -offers the benefits of compatibility among machines, some say it may share the vulnerabilities of fields planted with just one crop. ''The analogies are extremely close,'' said Richard Dawkins, a biologist at Oxford University. ''When you make machines that are capable of obeying instructions slavishly, and among those instructions are 'duplicate me' instructions, then of course the system is wide open to exploitation by parasites.'' Indeed, some computer scientists believe that in the rise of theInternet and the World Wide Web, society has struck a Faustian bargain -- gaining the potential of robotic software agents, which can flit from computer to computer to do their masters' bidding almost intelligently, but accepting as well the darker prospect of software infections that can spur cybernetic plagues. ''This may simply be the price you will have to pay for having the flexibility, adaptability, autonomy of this new networked world,'' said Kevin Kelly, author of ''Out of Control: The New Biology of Machines, Social Systems and the Economic World'' (Addison Wesley, 1994).

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: To be sure, biological metaphors used to describe the hostile software are only that, and the analogies do break down because the so-called computer viruses are manmade, not natural, and are frequently designed to be destructive.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: But some researchers assert that such diseases are a direct outgrowth of the remarkable complexity emerging in the realm of networked computers.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Increasingly, they say, Internet viral issues will come to resemble the modern world's perpetual public health crisis. ''You need to look at this the way the Centers for Disease Control approach things,'' said Vernor Vinge, a computer scientist at San Diego State University. ''There are always new problems on their threat board.'' In fact, computer scientists have known about these risks since the first worm programs were written by researchers at the Xerox Corporation's Palo Alto Research Center in the early 1970's.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Experimenting with the power of networked computers, scientists fashioned a wide variety of helpful programs, ranging from ''vampire'' worms that kept the network's computers laboring late at night to ''diagnostic'' worms that spread software repairs around the research center.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: But a software error in one of the lab's early worms caused the program to run amok, crashing computers everywhere in the building.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Today computer researchers debate what distinguishes worms from viruses, both metaphors drawn from science fiction.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The term ''worm'' first appeared in John Brunner's 1975 novel ''Shockwave Rider'' (Del Rey Books) while ''virus'' first appeared in a computer context in David Gerrold's ''When Harley Was One'' (Ballantine, 1972).

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Traditionally, the term ''virus'' has been used to describe software codes that infect computers by attaching themselves to documents or programs that are passed along.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: A ''worm,'' by contrast, has been self-propelling, that is, a program sent within the attachment that can then send itself along without any action by the person who receives it.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: But the most recent generation of malicious programs -- like the Melissa virus, which spread rapidly around the world in late March, and Explore.exe, the worm that emerged in Israel last Monday -- blend aspects of both types.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The world of computer networks has not yet produced the most telling biological analogy -- evolution.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: But a particular class of hostile programs known as polymorphic viruses has been designed since 1993, with the ability to mutate to evade the pattern detection capabilities of modern antivirus scanning programs.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: And antivirus researchers are also turning to ''biological'' solutions to face down hostile software codes.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: For example, last month the Intel Corporation, I.B.M. and the Symantec Corporation jointly released new antivirus software they call a ''Digital Immune System.'' Just as a biological immune system offers a systemic approach to illness, the new software shifts the antivirus response from the PC to an entire corporation's network, automatically relaying suspect programs for inspection and directly immunizing individual computers.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: There have been other attempts to build systems that are immune from security threats.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: For example, the original intent of the Java programming language was to prohibit the kind of file havoc wreaked last week by creating a ''sandbox'' that limits a program's destructive capabilities.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Strikingly, the rapid spread of last week's outbreak was made possible because most of the world's users of personal computers now run Microsoft software.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The worm was written to destroy documents written in Microsoft applications like Word, Excel and Power Point and certain programming files. ''This is the classic result of a computer monoculture,'' said W.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Daniel Hillis, a computer scientist at Walt Disney's Imagineering unit.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Like agricultural ecologies that become unstable relying on only one or a few crops, so the computer world is vulnerable to the degree it relies on Microsoft software.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Noting that the worm had attacked large American military contractors, including Boeing and General Electric, Art Amolsch, editor of FTC Watch, a Washington policy newsletter, suggested that the Government should insure software diversity among its agencies and contractors. ''I propose that no Government agency be allowed to run more than 34 percent of its personal computers on one proprietary operating system by a date certain,'' he said.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Hillis, who in the 1980's experimented with advances in software programs using ''evolutionary'' techniques in which the programs adapt to their environment, a transition is under way in which computers will be viewed less like mechanical devices and more like organisms, which better accommodate imprecision and failure. ''Today we have the fragility of an engineered system where every part works'' but the system itself can fail, he said. ''But in the future we're going to engineer systems with the expectation that everything is broken all the time.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: That's how we treat biological systems today.'' have varied characteristics.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Here are five types of infections and some prominent examples of each.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Many have characteristics of more than one type.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: MACRO -- Preys on documents like spreadsheets and data bases.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Concept (1995) -- Proved more than programs could be infected.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Contained code that read And that's enough to prove my point.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Melissa (1999) -- Tried to send itself to first 50 e-mail addresses found in victim's files; turned Word documents into templates.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: TROJAN HORSE -- Initially seems benign; may act as any type of infection thereafter.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Happy99.exe (1999) -- Displayed a window titled Happy New Year 1999!! while showing fireworks to disguise the fact that it was copying itself over the Internet.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Explore.exe (1999) -- Arrives attached to an e-mail, seemingly sent by an acquaintance.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: It is also a worm that, when launched, seeks to e-mail itself to other PC's and to destroy certain Microsoft Office and programmer file types.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: BOOT SECTOR -- Affects startup sector of floppy or hard disks.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Stoned (1989) -- Every eighth time a PC was started from an infected 5.25 inch floppy, Your PC is now Stoned! appeared on screen.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Michelangelo (1992) -- If a PC was started on March 6, the artist's birthday, it destroyed the hard disk.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: EXECUTABLE FILE -- Affects program files, not the files created by them.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Friday the 13th (1987) -- Deleted any program launched on a Friday that fell on the 13th of the month.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Chernobyl (1999) -Erased hard drive and ROM BIOS (basic input/output system).

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: WORM -- Self-propelled; can move and replicate through a network.

title: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Internet (1988) -- Exploited flawed network security to rapidly copy itself onto computers linked to the Internet, overloading thousands of computers with copies of itself. (Source: ICSA Inc.)    Money and Business/Financial Desk; Section 3

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: 3,177 words 19 September 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company SINGAPORE -- WITH no hinterland or natural resources, Singapore's Government has long cultivated this island-state's stability as corporate pastureland, leaving citizens to reap what they call the five C's: a car, a condo, credit cards, cash and a career with a multinational.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: He was running the global computer systems for a 150-year-old British bank and earning $300,000 a year.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Then, in April, he did something that seemed contrary to everything Singapore Inc. stood for: he quit.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Not to join another multinational company for more money, but to start a tiny high-technology company here with three other entrepreneurs -- a college buddy, a Japanese paraglider and a digital tinkerer who had helped authorities put urine detectors in Singapore's elevators.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Even stranger, the Government -- notorious for central planning and ironclad control -- wishes there were more people here like Mr.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Singapore is already a center for making high-technology hardware -- it is, for example, the world's largest producer of computer disk drives.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: And through the 90's, the Government has been plotting to make it an ''intelligent island,'' a networked city that would be Asia's Silicon Valley.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: But now, Singapore is peering into the Internet age and facing a quandary.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: On one hand, less-developed neighbors with cheaper labor are taking away high-tech manufacturing jobs, even as virtual communities and borderless trade are eroding the advantages of geography and infrastructure that helped create cities like Singapore in the first place.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: On the other, experts say, the creative germ that Singapore needs in order to compete in the information economy has been suffocated by the traditional Confucian culture and heavy Government control that form the bedrock of the city-state's society.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: So the Government that for 34 years has micromanaged the economy, censored the media and brooked no dissent has now embarked on a far-reaching program to enliven Singapore, largely in the hope of encouraging independent-minded business people like Mr.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
