title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: But something seems fundamentally different this time.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: It apparently relates to the increased speed and efficiency that information technology advances -- including the Internet -- is finally bringing to the mundane day-to-day tasks of millions of businesses.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: The question, posed by economists, is whether the higher productivity growth averaging about 2 percent in the last three years, roughly double the pace from 1973 to 1995, is the long-awaited confirmation that the nation's steadily rising investment in computers and communications is finally paying off.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: The evidence is starting to point in that direction. ''My beliefs are shifting on this subject,'' Mr.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Solow said. ''I am still far from certain.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: But the story always was that it took a long time for people to use information technology and truly become more efficient.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: That story sounds a lot more convincing today than it did a year or two ago.'' Another pillar in the pessimist camp was Daniel E.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Sichel, an economist at the Federal Reserve.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: His work, along with another Fed economist, Stephen D.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Oliner, in 1994, and on his own in 1997, found that computers contributed little to economic growth.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Sichel ran similar calculations for the last few years and came to a different conclusion.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: In a paper that has just been published in the quarterly Business Economics, he wrote that his new work points to ''a striking step up in the contribution of computers to output growth.'' And the nation's improved productivity performance, he noted, is ''raising the possibility that businesses are finally reaping the benefits of information technology.'' Wanted: New Way To Measure Economy The impact of information technology on the economy is more than an academic debate.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: If, as some experts assert, the technology dividend is a key reason for the nation's extraordinary run of high growth, rising wages and low inflation, there are significant policy implications.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: If the recent gains are not just a temporary blip, it   suggests that the Federal Reserve can be less fearful of inflation and keep interest rates stable rather than be forced to raise them to cool off what would otherwise be considered an overheated economy.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, and the other Fed governors are scheduled to hear presentations on information technology's effect on the economy from several academics during a private meeting in Washington tomorrow.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Greenspan, for one, seems to believe a fundamental change is under way in the economy.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: He told Congress in January that the economy is enjoying ''higher, technology-driven productivity growth.'' The Fed governors will hear a forceful case for technological optimism from Erik Brynjolfsson, an associate professor at the M.I.T.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Brynjolfsson asserts that the economic value of speed, quality improvements, customer service and new products are often not captured by Government statistics. ''These are the competitive advantages of information technology,'' he said. ''We need a broader definition of output in this new economy, which goes beyond the industrial-era concept of widgets coming off the assembly line.'' The Government, after years of defending its figures, conceded two weeks ago that productivity growth may be understated.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: The core of the problem, Government economists say, is the increasingly complex challenge of defining and measuring output in much of the economy's fast-growing service sector, which includes the vast reaches of banking, finance, health care and education.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: According to the official statistics, for instance, a bank today is no more productive than a bank was two decades ago.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Yet that seems to take scant account of, say, 24-hour automated teller machines, which clearly benefit customers who no longer have to wait in lines to be served by human tellers during regular ''bankers' hours.'' Edwin R.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Dean, chief of the productivity division of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, wrote in a recent research paper that the agency is increasingly concerned that its measurements do not ''fully reflect changes in the quality of goods and services'' or ''capture the full impact of new technology on economic performance.'' Still, the Government's methods of measurement will not be overhauled anytime soon. ''These are tough, tough questions and we are not going to get instant solutions,'' Mr.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Revolution Unfolds In the Back Offices American corporations long ago made up their minds, voting for technology with their dollars.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Investment in information technology -- computing and telecommunications gear -- has quadrupled over the last decade, rising as a share of all business spending on equipment to 53 percent from 29 percent, according to the Commerce Department.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: There have been surges in corporate spending on software, consulting, technical support and training related to the field. ''The payoff from information technology is unquestionably there with individual companies and we're seeing it over and over again,'' said Chuck Rieger, a senior consultant at I.B.M.'s services division.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Of course, anecdotal evidence from individual companies is no proof of broad-based benefits in an $8.5 trillion economy.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: But what many experts find encouraging is that the rapid introduction of low-cost Internet technology means most companies can now afford to set up electronic links with customers and suppliers.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: For example, a recent survey of 2,500 manufacturing companies, conducted by PricewaterhouseCoopers, found that the number of factories with Internet links to customers and suppliers doubled last year.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: At more and more companies, these Internet-based networks are already streamlining the mundane chores of business life like invoicing, purchasing and inventory control.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: This is not the glamorous side of Internet commerce, occupied by Amazon.com and others selling consumer products.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Yet if a technology dividend in productivity is at hand, the place to look is in the back offices of business. ''That is where it will be,'' Mr.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Solow, the M.I.T economist, said, ''in the wholesale automation of corporate transactions.'' This business-to-business commerce over the Internet is projected to jump from $48 billion in 1998 to $1.5 trillion by 2003, according to Forrester Research Inc.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: During the same period, the research firm estimates that consumer sales over the Internet will rise from $3.9 billion to $108 billion.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Looking for Clues In the Service Sector The service sector of the economy is where productivity gains appear to have been especially sluggish and where experts are looking most closely for evidence of an efficiency payoff from technology.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: In Chicago, Michael Rushmore, a banker, said Internet computing has ''fundamentally changed the way we do business'' over the last three or four years.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: An example of this is the way corporate loans are syndicated among many banks, said Mr.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Rushmore, who is a managing director of Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities, the securities arm of the BankAmerica Corporation.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Until about two years ago, syndicating a large corporate bank loan meant distributing a lengthy offering document, often running more than 200 pages, to 50 to 100 banks.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Rushmore recalled, a nightmarish, inefficient process that involved waves of overnight mail, constant faxing and armies of messengers.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Today, much of that process is handled over the Internet on bank Web sites that other banks tap into to read and download the offering document, ask questions and exchange views.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Rushmore estimates that the Internet-based system trims 25 percent from the time it takes to close a deal, not just improving the ease of the transaction but also saving an immense amount of work.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: The rapid spread of Internet-based computing, experts say, promises to compress the time it takes for any new technology to enhance economic welfare in general.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: The classic study of the phenomenon, ''The Dynamo and the Computer: An Historical Perspective on the Modern Productivity Paradox,'' by Paul David, an economic historian at Stanford University, was published in 1990.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: David noted, was introduced in the early 1880's but did not generate discernible productivity gains until the 1920's.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: It took that long, he wrote, not only for the technology to be widely diffused but also for businesses to reorganize work around the industrial production line, the efficiency breakthrough of its day. ''The process takes longer than people think, but I still believe that we will get a revival of productivity growth led by the spread of computing,'' Mr.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Techno-Pessimists See an 'Arms Race' His is a misplaced faith, according to the dwindling band of techno-pessimists whose own beliefs remain unshaken.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Sure, they concede, there has been surprisingly strong productivity growth for the last three years.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Could this represent a break in the trend?

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Possibly, they grudgingly admit, but only a tiny shift at best.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: The real problem, they say, lies in the composition of the nation's vast service economy.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: More than half of all white-collar workers are what they term ''knowledge workers'' -- managers, executives and professionals like doctors, lawyers, teachers, even economists. ''The work they do does not lend itself to technology-driven improvements in productivity, and any gains are really difficult to eke out and are glacial,'' said Stephen S.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. ''Paul David's electrical motor has nothing to do with the knowledge-intensive process of work in a service economy.'' A leading technology cynic at the Fed meeting tomorrow will be Paul Strassmann, a former chief information officer of Xerox and the Pentagon.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Strassmann, author of ''The Squandered Computer,'' published in 1997, believes that much of corporate America's spending spree on information technology amounts to an ''economic arms race,'' fueled by misguided management theories.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: The recent improvement in productivity, according to Mr.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Strassmann, is mainly attributable to the lower cost of capital because of low interest rates.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: His summary view, though at odds with those of technology optimists like Mr.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Brynjolfsson of M.I.T., may also be received warmly by the Fed. ''The explanation for the productivity improvement is interest rates, not information technology,'' Mr.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Strassmann said. ''The hero here is not Bill Gates.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: Strassmann finds the technology undeniably useful, if not a productivity elixir.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do
author: WAYNE ARNOLD
chunk: When asked a detailed question, he replied: ''Just look it up on my Web site.

title: Where the Start-Up Dance Is Still Hard to Do

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: 1,356 words 9 October 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 -- For more than three decades, it has been an unshakable principle of the computer industry: every 18 months, the number of transistors that will fit on a silicon chip doubles.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The phenomenon, known as Moore's Law for the semiconductor pioneer who first observed it, has been the basic force underlying the computer revolution and the rise of the Internet.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: As transistors have been scaled ever smaller, computing performance has risen exponentially while the cost of that power has been driven down.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: And it has been assumed in the industry that the rate of progress would hold for at least another 10 to 15 years.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: But now a researcher at Intel, the world's leading chip company, has reported glimpsing a potentially insurmountable barrier to the advance of Moore's Law much closer at hand, perhaps early in the coming decade.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: In an article in the journal Science, the Intel scientist, Paul A.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Packan, says it is not clear whether the most common type of silicon transistor can be scaled down beyond the generation of chips that will begin to appear next year, because semiconductor engineers have not found ways around basic physical limits. ''These fundamental issues have not previously limited the scaling of transistors,'' he wrote in the Sept. 24 issue. ''There are currently no known solutions to these problems,'' he added, calling it ''the most difficult challenge the semiconductor industry has ever faced.'' Dennis Allison, a Silicon Valley physicist and computer designer, said: ''The fact that this warning comes from Intel's process group is really significant.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: This says that they see actual limits.'' The report by the Intel scientist will be echoed by researchers from the University of Glasgow in a paper to be presented in December at a conference in Washington.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Without further advances in the miniaturization of silicon-based transistors, hopes for continued progress would have to be based on technologies that are promising but unproved: new materials, new transistor designs and advances like molecular computing, in which single molecules act as digital on-off switches.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: To be sure, such dire warnings have been made periodically in the past -- an article in Scientific American in 1987 said Moore's Law was unlikely to be maintained through the 1990's -- and each time semiconductor designers have shown remarkable ingenuity to surmount seemingly impossible barriers.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Indeed, Moore's Law -- first stated in 1965 by Gordon Moore, an Intel co-founder -- proved to be understated; Moore had to revise his initial prediction of 24 months for each doubling of chip capacity.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: And while it is not an actual physical law, his observation has taken on an almost mystical quality as the clearest expression of the power of human science and engineering and many industry executives have come to see it as a self-fulfilling prophecy.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: In the last decade the advances described by Moore's Law have had an accelerating impact on the personal computer industry, driving the cost of desktop machines down from $3,000 to as low as $500 while increasing their power.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The inventors of the original semiconductor design technology are for the most part still bullish about extending that progress, whatever the immediate hurdles.    ''Historically the economic incentives to find new methods for device improvement have regularly overcome the predicted scaling limits,'' said John Moussouris, a physicist and semiconductor designer. ''The physical challenges may be getting harder, but the people and financial resources to surmount them are also growing each year.'' But for the first time the global semiconductor industry is grappling with transistors so small that the placement of individual atoms will soon become crucial.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: For example, in the current generation of semiconductors, the wires that interconnect transistors are etched as fine as 0.18 micron -- one five-hundredth the width of a human hair -- and the individual insulating layers that are inside a transistor may be only four or five atoms thick.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Semiconductor factories in Japan plan to begin mass production of chips based on widths of 0.13 micron early next year, and such chips should be in widespread use within two years.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: But beyond that generation, the industry's leading researchers acknowledge there remain far more questions than answers.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The next step would be widths of 0.10 micron, a milestone that in the Moore's Law progression would be expected three to five years from now.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Packan writes, transistors will be composed of fewer than 100 atoms, and statistical variations in this Lilliputian world are beyond the ability of semiconductor engineers to control.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Packan said he had written the Science article to challenge the industry and academia to focus on areas where breakthroughs are needed. ''For the last 30 years we've been engineering the device, and now what's required is fundamental science,'' he said in a telephone interview today.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Intel executives cautioned against reading too much gloom into their technical papers, saying that while they did not yet have precise engineering solutions for breaking the 0.10 micron barrier, they were confident that answers would be found.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: They suggested that part of the reason for Intel's recent pessimism might have more to do with the need for corporate secrecy than the arrival of fundamental technical limits. ''We face serious challenges,'' said Mark Bohr, an Intel technology development director and the co-author of an internal Intel technical paper that enumerates the company's unsolved problems. ''We all have ideas to address some of these problems and admittedly they are iffy and not fully developed, and you don't want to tip your cards too soon.'' And Carver Mead, a physicist and a pioneer in semiconductor design, says he still adheres to what has been the conventional industry wisdom, suggesting that Moore's Law will continue to account for the pace of silicon technology advances until at least 2014. ''There are still some open issues,'' he said. ''and so the Chicken Little sky-is-falling articles are a recurring theme.'' But James Heath, a chemistry professor at the University of California at Los Angeles who is a co-inventor of the carbon 60 molecule known as the Buckyball, said the industry might be overly optimistic because it had such a vast investment in today's silicon technology.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Heath has developed a prototype memory cell the size of a single molecule that operates on different principles from today's semiconductors. ''I think their optimism for being able to continue until 2014 is not very realistic,'' he said. ''When you get to very, very small sizes, you are limited by relying on only a handful of electrons to describe the difference between on and off.'' Executives at I.B.M., which along with Intel and Motorola is one of the nation's dominant chip makers, acknowledged that it might be accurate to warn of an impending limit to the shrinking of today's dominant chips, known as C.M.O.'s, or complimentary metal oxide semiconductors.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: But they said they believed they had found an alternative approach, known as silicon-on-insulator, that held great promise at dimensions of 0.10 micron and smaller. ''This paper is quite consistent with work we've published,'' said Randall Isaac, vice president for systems technology and science at I.B.M.'s Watson Laboratory in Yorktown Heights, N.Y. ''But when a given technology saturates, it is usually replaced by a new one.''   computer chips should double every 18 months.

chunk: C14)    Telecommunications Powerhouse Business/Financial Desk; Section C Goldman Sachs Rules as Industry Is Transformed in Europe 1,954 words 13 December 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company For a brief period last month, it seemed that the Goldman Sachs Group might become a victim of its own international success.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Mannesmann, the German telecommunications giant, had filed a conflict-of-interest suit in London, arguing that Goldman should be barred from advising the British wireless company Vodafone AirTouch.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Because Goldman had advised an investor in Orange of Britain, a wireless company Mannesmann itself wanted.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: But the court called the suit hopeless, refusing to censure Goldman for having too many of a good thing -- clients.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: In the end, the episode underscored what investment bankers had known all along: Goldman Sachs had become a dominant force in the redrawing of Europe's telecommunications map.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Chalk it up to the appetites of acquisition-hungry Europeans eager to expand their network empires -- and to Goldman's years of positioning itself to direct and underwrite that action.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: This year, Goldman has been an adviser on $239 billion of telecommunications mergers in Europe.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: That represents an almost fourfold increase over 1998, according to Thompson Financial Securities Data, and enough to propel it from No. 11 to No. 1 on the list of bankers in European telecommunications mergers.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Not only is Goldman the lead adviser for the voracious Vodafone, Britain's largest wireless concern, but it acts as counsel to other giants, most notably Deutsche Telekom, which Goldman took public in 1996.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: This rise to prominence has come at the expense of European investment bankers like Lazard Freres & Company and Schroders, Britain's largest independent investment bank.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: They have not only fallen behind Goldman on their own turf but know that its most formidable opponent in the region is another American firm, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: But the European bankers face more than bad luck.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: In a year when American-style corporate takeovers are overrunning the traditions of economic nationalism in Europe -- a few years ago, a hostile bid by a British company for a German telecommunications company would have been unthinkable -- the contestants need the American banks that know best how to play the game. ''They've outmuscled all of us because of their single-minded focus on winning,'' an investment banker at a European firm said of Goldman.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: To illustrate his point, he began humming the theme song from ''The A Team,'' a 1980's television show about a group of rebels who brandished weapons to defeat their enemies. ''Goldman's like the A Team.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: They're a real shoot-'em-up group.'' Goldman began its march into Europe more than a decade ago when, anticipating a wave of privatization in telecommunications, the firm began calling on government agencies to help them sell stakes in state-owned telephone concerns.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Scott Mead, a Cambridge-educated American, was one of the core team to set up shop in 1988 in London, where he is now co-head of Goldman's global communications, media and entertainment group.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: His counterpart is another American, Robert S.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Harrison, a longtime Goldman partner who teamed up with Mr.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Mead early this year and is based in New York.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: One of the group's first deals was a public offering by Telefonica S.A., Spain's biggest telecommunications company, in the late 80's.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Other stock underwriting assignments followed, including one by Britain's Cable and Wireless in 1989 and another by TeleDanmark of Denmark in 1994.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: But Goldman's big break came when it was picked by the German government to sell a $13 billion stake in Deutsche Telekom in a stock offering in 1996.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The assignment became the cornerstone of Goldman's campaign to court top-tier European telecommunications players. ''It was the franchising of our German office,'' Mr.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Mead said. ''People could see the German government had faith in us and this was a good thing.'' Wooing Deutsche Telekom required a protracted courtship.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Goldman bankers from both London and Frankfurt had approached the German company in 1990 about the prospects of a sale.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: They held regular strategy sessions with executives along with several smaller meetings, Mr.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Top executives from New York made regular visits and in 1994, a Goldman associate began working from an office in Deutsche Telekom headquarters.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Its established relationships with European telephone companies helped Goldman to pounce as new businesses like wireless communications and Internet access have spun out of the telephone industry. ''The Goldman strategy is if it was owned by the government, take it private,'' said Howard Anderson, chairman of the Yankee Group, a telecommunications research firm. ''If it is private, take it public.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: They are a transaction machine.'' Consider the case of Spain's Terra Networks S.A., a provider of Internet access and content in Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking countries, which Goldman took public last month and whose market value reached $13.9 billion as of last Friday.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Terra Networks is a unit of Goldman's oldest European telecom client, Telefonica.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Goldman's European base has also enabled the firm to enhance client relationships in the United States.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: In 1998, for instance, Goldman advised the Ameritech Corporation, the Chicago-based telephone company, on its purchase of a 34.4 percent stake in another Goldman client, Denmark's state-owned TeleDanmark, for $3.1 billion.

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier
author: JOHN MARKOFF

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier

title: Chip Progress Forecast to Hit A Big Barrier

Goldman leaped into action, dispatching teams from both Europe and the United States to begin working up a strategy with Vodafone, resulting in the AirTouch and Bell Atlantic forays and the ongoing effort to take control of Mannesmann.

''We are looking for the next Global Crossing, huge users of capital that require high-yield financing,'' Mr.

chunk: 883 words 27 January 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A senior executive of the Microsoft Corporation testified today that his company tried to convince its main rival in the Internet software market to become less of a head-on competitor.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Paul Maritz, the highest-ranking executive appearing as a witness at the Microsoft antitrust trial, portrayed the discussions with the Netscape Communications Corporation in 1995 as mainly an effort to find ''common ground'' between the two companies.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But the Government maintains that a June 1995 meeting was a crucial episode in its sweeping antitrust case.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: After Netscape rejected Microsoft's proposal, the Government contends, Microsoft embarked on what the prosecution regards as a pattern of practices intended to thwart competition.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: David Boies, the Justice Department's lead trial lawyer, presented several Microsoft E-mails written shortly before the Netscape meeting saying that Microsoft wanted to make sure Netscape's software for browsing the World Wide Web did not become a technology ''platform'' for which software programmers would write applications -making it a potential alternative to Microsoft's industry-standard Windows operating system.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: In a June 1, 1995, E-mail, one Microsoft executive identified key goals as ''move Netscape out'' of Internet browser software for future versions of Windows and to ''avoid a cold or hot war with Netscape,'' adding, ''Keep them from sabotaging our platform evolution.'' When asked to comment on this E-mail and others, Mr.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Maritz replied, ''We clearly had an agenda for making certain technologies common in the industry.'' But in some of the sharpest questioning since the trial began last October, Mr.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Maritz about the implications of Microsoft's proposal.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: If Netscape had agreed to shift its focus away from software that Microsoft deemed mainstream to its strategic interests, he asked, would Netscape have become a ''less significant platform threat?'' That, Mr.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Maritz conceded, was partly true. ''At one level, yes,'' he said.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But he noted Microsoft was mainly trying to get Netscape to agree to Microsoft's preferred set of basic Internet technologies and nothing in their talks would have prevented Netscape from competing in other Internet-related software, including multimedia software, groupware and Java, an Internet programming language.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The result, he said, could have been that Netscape would have become an even more formidable rival.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: If Netscape had focused less on the browser and more on software and services that compete less directly with Microsoft, for example, Mr.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Maritz said Netscape might have a ''much more entrenched position within large corporations today.'' In short, Mr.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Maritz said the result of Microsoft's proposal might have been to reduce competition in certain niches of the software business, but not to diminish competition overall.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Neukom, Microsoft's senior vice president for law and corporate affairs, said words matter less than actions in antitrust law. ''After that meeting,'' he said, ''there was full-fledged competition between Microsoft and Netscape.''    Yet the Government replies that the head-to-head competition occurred only after Netscape rejected Microsoft's proposal.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Boies said, ''It is significant for our case that Microsoft has admitted seeking to persuade Netscape not to engage in platform competition.'' In the morning, the Government tried to raise questions about the credibility of Microsoft's current legal stance by accusing the company of engaging in a ''concerted effort'' to alter the words used to describe Internet software internally and in its public statements to suit the company's legal stance.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The Government pointed to company E-mail from early last year that said Microsoft had to make sure that the word ''browser'' was no longer used in referring to its Internet browsing software and that the ''legal staff'' be brought in to check the language.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The wording plays a role in the case because the Government contends that the software maker bundled its Internet Explorer browser into its Windows operating system to thwart competition in the Internet software market.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Microsoft replies that since the rise of the Internet the company had always planned to fold the software used to browse the World Wide Web into its operating system.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The browser, Microsoft insists, is merely a feature of the operating system and not a stand-alone product.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: In an E-mail in February 1998, a Microsoft executive, wrote that ''saying 'put the browser in the OS' is already a statement that is prejudicial to us,'' and went on, ''The name 'browser' suggests a separate thing.'' (OS stands for operating system.) In another E-mail in February 1998, a Microsoft executive reported ''good progress'' in cleaning up the wording used on the company's Web site. ''We don't refer to it as a product or even a browser,'' he wrote. ''It's browsing software.'' antitrust consent decree.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Maritz emphasized that the change in the approved corporate vernacular was mainly to clearly explain the consumer benefits of tightly integrating the browser with the operating system.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Maritz said the legal environment also played a role, necessitating the use of ''more precise language'' as ''this set of events was heating up.'' chunk: Next Stage of the Cellular Tour Business/Financial Desk; Section C Forced to Compete, Japan Becomes a Global Power 1,822 words 27 July 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company TOKYO, July 26 -- One of the nicest things the United States ever did for Japan, it seems, was to force it, kicking and screaming, to open its market for cellular phones.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: At the time, Japan was aghast at the idea of freeing up a market that was a groggy backwater.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Japanese citizens were not even allowed to own cellular phones -- just rent them -- and Japanese companies were afraid that they were going to lose business to American rivals like Motorola.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Yet Japan buckled, and now, under the pressure of competition, it has leap-frogged to the front of the global pack.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The country now has a higher concentration of cellular telephones -- including ones colored pink, pale blue or tea-green -- than does the United States.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: More astonishing, Japan has caught up with Europe, the early pace setter, and plans to move ahead in 2001 by introducing the ''third generation'' of cellular phone technology, which promises much greater clarity and ability to transmit data and video.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Already, Japanese cell phones, which used to be second-rate and expensive, have been transformed into devices to buy and sell stocks, reserve tickets for trains and airplanes, transfer funds between bank accounts and send and receive text messages and simple drawings.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Moreover, as in Europe, they have leaped into the digital era under the umbrella of compatibility -- unlike in the United States, where competing technologies have actually stifled the advance of seamless and ubiquitous communication.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The latest mobile phone to draw oohs and aahs here has a tiny camera that sends a shaky TV-style color image to a small screen on the other party's telephone -- assuming that it too is a video phone.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: That cellular video phone, made by the Kyocera Corporation, will be introduced this month, for about $335, and it is as tiny as any other mobile phone, easily fitting into a shirt pocket.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Meanwhile, Epson has merged phones with functions of a personal digital assistant like the Palm Pilot, creating a unit that is both phone and diary, and that can also send color images.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: So, as Japan's economy still staggers along, one of the brightest opportunities in this country of 126 million people is a shimmering milky way of 50 million twinkling and tinkling portable phones.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Trials have already begun on an advanced wideband wireless transmission technology, and some say that Japan may drive the global standard and become a leader in the next generation of mobile phones. ''In Japan, we are at a turning point,'' said Jun Murai, a professor at Keio University and the leading cheerleader here for the Internet.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Japan lags behind the United States significantly in information technology, he said, but with regard to potential technical power, ''Japanese companies are not behind.'' In many ways, at stake is Japan's pride at being a leader in a pivotal technology -- enormously important in a nation that has been economically wounded for the entire decade.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Japan is betting that mobile phones will enjoy explosive growth as they become a key accessory, as common as wrist watches, that people take when they leave home.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Japanese companies are betting that mobile phones, rather than computers, will connect people here to E-commerce on the Internet.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Indeed, Japanese researchers are collaborating with American companies, like Sun Microsystems, so that they may also become a major link in controlling home appliances.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Their goal, ultimately, is to transform mobile phones into the crucial digital device of the future.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: They see a big market not just in the industrialized world but also in nations like China, where many consumers' first phone is cellular.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Japan's gamble, though, is by no means a sure bet. ''The next question is whether they take it from a cell phone to a full PC or whether it makes sense to browse the Net on the phone, for simple point-and-clicking,'' said Vinton G.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Cerf, senior vice president for Internet architecture and technology at MCI Worldcom. ''Japan is good at size, power and bringing the cost down.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: There's no better country to do it than Japan.'' One big problem, though, is that few Japanese are plugged into the computing world.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: As recently as a few years ago, Japan was in the personal-computing dark ages, a nation where corporate offices were big rooms filled with paper-laden desks and where desktop computers were rare.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Even now, on average, only one person in four here uses a personal computer.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: And so far, only about 14 percent of Japan's population is plugged into the Internet, compared with 40 percent in the United States.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Personal computers have not been a bigger hit in Japan for several reasons.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: For one thing, keyboards intimidate many middle-aged Japanese, and tapping in the Japanese language -- with two alphabets and several thousand Chinese characters -- requires combinations of strokes that are far more complex than in English.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Another is that many homes are cramped, and PC's take up a fair amount of space.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But that aversion to bulky computers and keyboards may actually serve to spur the development of mobile phones as a more compatible alternative.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: At the same time, the high cost of traditional phone services may help advance cell phone technology even more.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Hefty telephone costs, including a mandatory $580 start-up fee for a telephone and charges that add up by the minute, currently make Internet surfing very expensive.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Initial costs for cell phones are so much cheaper than for a regular phone line that young Japanese, especially students, often have only a cell phone in their apartments.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: And the prospect of a transformation in mobile-phone technology, along with the hope of a new kind of gateway to the Web, is beginning to create a sense of optimism that Japan may be able to catch up in the Internet revolution. ''There's a huge penetration of mobile telephones in Japan,'' said Junichi Saeki, director of systems solutions at the International Data Corporation in Tokyo. ''This will lead to the next generation of information technology.'' The push has been driven by NTT's Mobile Communications Network, known as NTT DoCoMo, a cellular operator that commands more than 50 percent of the market in Japan.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: NTT DoCoMo is now working with American and Japanese companies to develop a new wireless transmission technology, called wideband C.D.M.A. -- short for code division multiple access -- that is supposed to ultimately enable people around the world to transmit data and video rapidly through a cell phone.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Many mobile phone operators here now use a fairly narrow band, which can send data at speeds as fast as 32 kilobits a second, faster than Europe's first-generation digital phones but slower than the interim standard expected next year.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: True wide band offers much more space and speed -- a potential of as fast as 2 megabits a second, 65 times the capability of existing phones.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Negotiators from around the world have settled on a format to move toward a wideband C.D.M.A. for the next generation of telephones, so that the same cellular phone could be used in almost any country.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But carriers in the United States are still fighting over standards.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: For now, the latest craze in Japan is a cell phone called the I-mode, which NTT DoCoMo started selling in February.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: As many as 10,000 of the phones are sold every day; already 779,000 owners use them to send E-mail, check news headlines, buy stocks, make bank transfers or plane reservations.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: They can gain access to specially formatted World Wide Web sites and even see simple graphics.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: NTT DoCoMo is betting that Japanese consumers will get hooked on electronic commerce through I-mode phones, which rely on current technology.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Once they get used to E-commerce, then the new wide band C.D.M.A. should begin, scheduled to commence in Japan in March 2001, probably several years before it will arrive in the United States and at least a few months ahead of Europe. ''I-mode is like black-and-white TV,'' said Keiichi Enoki, a director at DoCoMo who spearheaded the I-mode project. ''C.D.M.A. is like color TV.'' Kyocera is working on a competing product that would let users gain access to the Internet through a different Web protocol.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: In the meantime, Kyocera is promoting the notion that telephone partners will want to see each other.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Video phones have flopped in the past, and Kyocera officials admit they have not yet figured out how to market the new model.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Still, when they introduced the product in May, they got some unexpected responses.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: A professional matchmaker inquired about using the phones for clients on first-time dates, and a security company asked how the phones could be used to keep tabs on where its guards were patrolling.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The idea of a mobile ''spy phone,'' though, is precisely what may scare off customers, even those directly involved in the business.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The video phone is one of the pet projects of Kazuo Inamori, Kyocera's iconoclastic chairman.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But at a marketing strategy session this winter, not one in a crowd of 60 employees raised his hand when asked who would buy one.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: No one wanted to talk to the boss on a video phone.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Kyocera went ahead anyway with the product, mainly to keep up with the competition.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Masahiro Inoue, Kyocera's director of product development for the phone, is crossing his fingers that the public will respond. ''If it is inside the home, a lady might not want to use it is because she might not have her make-up on yet and she wouldn't want to reveal her naked face,'' Mr.

title: Microsoft Official Says Company Sought Cooperation
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Inoue said. ''But if she's outside, she's well prepared to be seen.

chunk: AT&T's earnings beat estimates by a penny a share, but the company's overall profit declined largely because of a dilution of its stock caused by the acquisition of Tele-Communications Inc., the cable TV giant.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Strong growth in the AT&T units that provide wireless phone service and that serve the complex communication needs of big businesses was largely offset by continued declines in the company's core consumer long-distance business.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Over all, AT&T demonstrated healthy revenue growth, especially compared with anemic revenue performance in recent years.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But it was not able to maintain the pace of revenue growth it established in the second quarter, and the company still appears to be growing less quickly than the rest of the telecommunications industry, which is surging amid deregulation and the rise of the Internet.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: A big problem AT&T has in keeping pace with the rest of the industry is that its finances are still largely tied to standard long-distance phone service, a market in which it remains No. 1.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But AT&T's share of the long-distance market has steadily fallen for at least 15 years, and the financial erosion caused by that process recently accelerated as a price war broke out among the leading long-distance carriers.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: That squeezed long-distance profit margins thinner than a strand of optical fiber.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: In terms of sheer growth, the hot areas for AT&T are its wireless unit and its outsourcing business, known as AT&T Solutions, which seeks to serve large businesses.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: And the company has made progress in earnings growth by cutting billions in costs. ''Today's results are all about delivering on our commitments to investors by growing top-line revenues, meeting earnings targets and reducing our costs,'' C.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Michael Armstrong, AT&T's chairman, said in a statement. ''Our strong third-quarter performance also reflects the benefits of our investments in growth areas such as wireless and outsourcing services, where revenues were up by more than 40 percent each.'' Counting the effect of AT&T's acquisition of I.B.M.'s network unit, the AT&T Solutions business more than tripled its revenue, to $983 million in the quarter, up from $285 million in the period a year earlier.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The wireless unit reported revenue growth of 44.2 percent, to about $2.1 billion.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Excluding the effect of the acquisition of Vanguard Cellular and the sale of AT&T's paging unit, revenue in the group grew 40.9 percent compared with a year earlier.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But all was not well in the wireless unit.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The company added 269,000 customers in the quarter, down 17.4 percent from the period a year earlier.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: AT&T said it had reined in its wireless marketing efforts because of ''network capacity challenges in some markets and a supply shortage of digital multinetwork phones.'' It did not identify the shortage with any particular equipment vendor.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Only last year, AT&T's business services unit, which is separate from the AT&T Solutions operation, surpassed the consumer long-distance business in revenue.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Now, the business unit is almost 12 percent bigger, having increased its revenue in the quarter, to $6.3 billion, 5 percent higher than in the period a year earlier.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: At the same time, the consumer unit shrank 4.7 percent, to about $5.6 billion in revenue.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Excluding the effect of acquiring Tele-Communications Inc. and of the I.B.M. network unit, AT&T's revenue for the quarter grew 5.3 percent compared with the period a year earlier.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Accounting as if TCI and the I.B.M. unit had already been a part of AT&T lifts the company's revenue growth for the quarter 5.6 percent, to $16.3 billion from $15.44 billion.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: That is an improvement for AT&T over years past, but it is less impressive than the 6.7 percent growth in the second quarter, to $15.8 billion from $14.8 billion.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But even as the TCI and I.B.M. unit acquisitions help increase revenue growth, the TCI deal especially has been a killer for AT&T's earnings.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Excluding the two deals, operating earnings were 81 cents a diluted share, compared with 68 cents a share in the period a year earlier.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But including the effect of the two deals, operating earnings were $1.75 billion, or 54 cents a share, down from $1.84 billion, or 68 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Analysts had expected the company to earn 53 cents a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial, which tracks company earnings.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Shares of AT&T rose $1.6875, to $44.6875, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Including all special charges and the effect of all its deals, AT&T officially reported earnings of $1.6 billion, or 50 cents a share, down from $2 billion, or 78 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Demonstrating the effect of the deals, revenue for the quarter was $16.3 billion, up from $13.7 billion.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: PRACTICAL TRAVELER Travel Desk; Section 5 Hotels Mobbed, But a Bit Less So 1,566 words 5 December 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company IF you've tried to book a hotel room in a major American city lately, you may have trouble believing this.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The latest figures from the hotel industry, covering the first nine months of this year, show that occupancy rates are still in decline, continuing a trend that began in 1997.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: In fact, occupancy through September 1999 was down from the same period last year in 17 of the nation's 25 biggest markets, according to Smith Travel Research, the scorekeeper for the United States hotel industry.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: And industry analysts project falling occupancy for each of the next two years.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But don't be lulled into thinking that it is now easier to book the room of your choice at the last minute, or that room rates will plummet to reflect lower demand.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The nine-month occupancy rate, 65.2 percent, is still slightly above the 25-year industry average of 65 percent.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: And unless you are willing to stay in the boondocks or at the Hotel Last Resort, city-center hotels, luxury and full service hotels may be as tough as ever to get into, while room rates, which have averaged $81.06 so far in 1999, are likely to continue rising.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: To understand why, consider this: while occupancy rates have slipped this year in New York, Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, Miami-Hialeah, Minneapolis-St.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Paul, New Orleans, Philadelphia, San Francisco, San Diego and Washington, occupancy in all those markets remains in the 70-percent range.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Furthermore, the slippage in those cities has ranged from less than 2 percent in Minneapolis-St.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Paul (1.7 percent, to be exact) to a minuscule 0.1 percent in Philadelphia.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: And in most of those cities, rooms that are centrally situated or in trendy outlying neighborhoods are still scarce unless booked well in advance. (There is another possibility for reserving a desirable hotel on short notice, but you'll have to read on to learn how.) In fact, occupancy rates have been virtually flat in the most expensive markets -- those with average room rates over $100 a night -- so the pattern is much the same as in each of the past several years.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: For example, occupancy is down only 0.6 percent in New York, where the average room rate is a whopping $178.60; 0.4 percent in San Francisco ($135.01 a room); 1.0 percent in Boston ($131.36), 0.4 percent in New Orleans ($113.94), 1.0 percent in Chicago ($109.51), 1.6 percent on Oahu ($107.54), 0.9 percent in Miami-Hialeah ($107.40) and 0.5 percent in San Diego ($103.23).

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: So far this year, only Washington has had room rates averaging above $100 ($108.90) as well as increased occupancy (up 1.5 percent).

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: More Rooms, Higher Rates Largely because of a glut of new hotels, after seven consecutive years of good financial news for the industry, even hotels in cities with big drops in occupancy this year have raised room rates modestly.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: These include Houston (a drop of 5.4 percent), Dallas (down 5.3 percent) Seattle (5.3) and Orlando (3.4).

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: A notable exception is Denver, where occupancy has fallen 3.8 percent this year, to 69 percent, but where room rates have also declined a smidgen, to $78.68 from $78.80. where rates dropped 1.6 percent, to $98.35, and occupancy fell 4.1 percent, to 62.9; and Oahu, where despite a slight rise in occupancy, room rates fell 4.1 percent, to $107.54.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: While Phoenix was affected by a 10.3 percent increase in available rooms, Oahu's prices were driven down largely by the perception that too many of its hotels are overpriced and in need of refurbishment.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The industry expects a boost in occupancy and room rates in the fourth quarter, a period that includes multitudes in search of fall foliage, the Thanksgiving holiday, legions of fans following college and professional football teams, as well as the runup to Christmas and New Year.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: In fact, room rates nationwide have risen each year since 1995, when the average was $66.11, to $81.06 through this September, and according to a forecast two months ago by PricewaterhouseCoopers, rates will rise to $84.15 next year and to $87.25 in 2001.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But even hotels in cities outside the top 25 markets -- including Cleveland, Raleigh-Durham, N.C., and Providence, R.I. -- are having banner years.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: A recent survey by PKF Consulting in San Francisco turned up occupancy rates above 70 percent this year in Austin, Tex.; Baton Rouge, La.; Nashville; Boise, Idaho; Colorado Springs; Portland, Ore.; Santa Fe, N.M., and Sacramento.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Salt Lake City's occupancy is 71 percent for this year so far, 4.1 percent less than the 74 percent over the same period last year.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: A Room in Brooklyn One of the more interesting occupancy rates is at a single hotel, the New York Marriott Brooklyn.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: When it opened in July 1997, it was the first new hotel in Brooklyn in almost 70 years, and the hotel, which has 376 rooms, had an occupancy rate of almost 83 percent during the first six months of this year.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Marriott expects it to hit 85 percent by year-end, driven by the high holiday demand in New York and the fact that it is the only notable hotel in the borough.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: This year's overall occupancy rate of 65.2 percent is all the more significant (especially to hotel owners) in view of the PricewaterhouseCoopers finding that United States hotels had achieved a record low break-even occupancy rate, the rate at which expenses and revenues are equal.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: From a 62.6 break-even rate in 1992, it is now down to 55.5 percent.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: That lower rate, according to Bjorn Hanson, chairman of the lodging and gaming group of PricewaterhouseCoopers, is attributable to the rising room rates, lower debt and equity costs for the industry, and more emphasis on revenue from rooms than from low-margin food and beverage operations.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Many travelers are likely to be surprised to hear ''low margin'' used to describe hotel food and beverage, especially in view of the trend even in upscale restaurants toward breakfast and lunch buffets, which require far less labor than traditional menus.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: And anyone who has eaten in luxury hotel restaurants, or ordered room service, is almost sure to regard ''low margin'' with suspicion.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Hanson said that at the same time that top chefs with celebrity status are in greater demand than ever at luxury hotels, the food and beverage share of overall hotel revenue has fallen from as much as 50 percent in 1960 to about 20 percent today.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: And after subtracting the cost of credit card commissions, insurance, energy, marketing and other expenses, he said, ''food and beverage operations usually result in a financial loss for hotels.'' Stanley Turkel, a hotel consultant in New York, also said that hotels lose money on food and beverages, except for banquets. ''Even Las Vegas, where they used to practically give rooms and food away, is now trying to make food and beverage profitable,'' he said. (Las Vegas, the No. 1 hotel market in the United States, is not included in Smith Travel Research reports because of its unique attractions and reliance on gambling, but its 120,444 rooms, the most of any city, have averaged a torrid 89.2 percent occupancy so far this year.) The rise of the Internet is having a growing impact on hotel bookings, especially in enabling potential guests and travel agents to view guest rooms, lobbies and hotel exteriors.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Hotel Reservations Network, a Dallas-based consolidator that sells discount rooms in 38 cities worldwide, said that it derived more than 85 percent of its revenues from the 1.2 million room nights a year that it books on the Web, and Priceline.com and some other Web discounters are sprouting up.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Internet bookings are poised to soar -- to some $3.1 billion in revenues by the year 2002 from less than $100 million in 1997, according to a forecast by Bear, Stearns & Company. ''The introduction of toll-free telephone service in the 1960's was the last great technology innovation to greatly affect the economics of hotel booking, and that's nothing compared with the mighty punch of the Internet,'' said Jason Ader, who heads the Bear, Stearns hotel, gaming and leisure research group.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Still, so far the Internet has had little overall impact on room rates or availability.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Finally, about booking a hotel room on short notice: the surest way is to plan your stay for Sunday night, because it is the slowest day of the week.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Try for an upscale chain hotel, the segment with the biggest falloff in occupancy on Sunday, according to Smith Travel Research.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The drawback is that you will probably have to vacate your room   the next morning; but you might get a break on the price, which gives a thrifty traveler a chance to enjoy a different lodging experience.

title: AT&T Profits Ease but Still Beat Forecasts
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: EDWIN McDOWELL, a business reporter for The Times, covers the travel industry.
