title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: 1,187 words 29 September 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 28 -- Hoping to insure that the nation's spies have the latest information technology in the rapidly changing Internet age, the Central Intelligence Agency has established a venture capital company to nurture high-tech companies, company executives and former C.I.A. officials said.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The C.I.A. has chosen a veteran Silicon Valley software executive to head the effort, which has an office in Washington with eight employees and will have a second office in Silicon Valley.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: With a nod to nostalgia for the mythic gadget-laden spycraft of the James Bond era, the agency has named its new nonprofit venture In-Q-It, in a reference to Major Boothroyd, a.k.a.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Q, the master technologist whose basement laboratory develops advanced gadgets for the fictional British super-agent.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: It will be headed by Gilman Louie, an executive in the Hasbro toy company's on-line business group.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The decision by the nation's spy agency to turn to Silicon Valley for technology assistance underscores the growing diversity of high-tech companies and the accelerated development of computer technologies.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Unlike in the cold war, when the most advanced technologies trickled down from a handful of supercomputer companies, the most powerful technologies are increasingly being developed first by consumer electronics companies that now have vast markets to finance the developments of powerful systems and applications.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: In-Q-It is being financed with $28 million appropriated last year by Congress as part of the C.I.A.'s budget, which is classified.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The company will seek joint projects and investments in crucial technology areas. ''There is a tremendous information explosion today,'' said John McMahon, former deputy director of the C.I.A. and an In-Q-It board member. ''As a result, the agency was always one step behind.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The agency got the idea that maybe what it needed was something that would not only appreciate its needs but be an umbilical cord that was plugged in to the brightest minds in the Valley.'' Mr.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Louie said today that the purpose of the new company would be to move information technology to the agency more quickly than traditional Government procurement processes allow.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The agency, he said, was struggling with many of the same aspects of the Internet that are vexing to other Web surfers, including privacy and security. ''The current model isn't working,'' Mr.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Louie said. ''The technology world has totally changed, and one day the C.I.A. woke up and realized they needed to go through the same change.'' The new company will supply venture capital in some cases, and in others it will hire contractors or partner with entrepreneurs in four areas: integrating Internet technology and applications into the C.I.A.'s work; developing new security and privacy technologies; nurturing data mining technologies to take better advantage of the agency's vast storehouses of records, and modernizing the agency's computer systems.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Louie said that none of In-Q-It's work would be classified and that the organization would not be limited to the four areas he outlined.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: In contrast to many of its other activities, he said, the agency was taking pains to make the activities of In-Q-It highly visible and public.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: That stands in striking contrast to the agency's past approach to high-tech projects.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: For many years there have been reports that the United States intelligence community created shell companies when it had a particular high-technology problem to solve.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Indeed, the C.I.A. worked secretly with Howard Hughes during the 1970's when it needed to develop specialized salvage technology to retrieve a sunken Soviet nuclear submarine in the Pacific Ocean.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: While In-Q-It will operate on a nonprofit basis, Mr.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Louie said his intention was to invest in such a way as to make the organization self-sustaining.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Smith, the new company's legal counsel and former general counsel to the C.I.A., said, ''The Government will have the opportunity to use the intellectual property developed by In-Q-It for Governmental purposes, but In-Q-It will own and have the ability to use the technology it develops for commercial purposes.'' Mr.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Louie said that while this was not the first effort to find innovative ways to move new technologies quickly to the Government's needs, he believed it was the first time a Government agency had adopted a venture financing effort that mimicked a private sector model.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Venture capitalists said today that the problem the C.I.A. faces is a challenge faced every day by large organizations: attempting to keep up with the nimble pace of the Valley's technology start-up companies.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: A number of large multinational companies have in recent years set up investment funds in the valley in an effort to tap into the entrepreneurial spirit of the region. ''There are a number of models on which the jury is still out,'' said James Breyer, managing partner of Accel Partners, a venture firm in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Companies like Lucent Technologies and the AT&T Corporation have become venture investors in the valley in recent years, he noted, and SRI Research International had less success in trying to spin out its research projects with an internal venture arm. ''The most important aspect is to have an outstanding outside management effort overseeing the process,'' he said. ''It appears in this effort the C.I.A. has chosen well.'' Previous Government efforts at financing technology have been highly focused efforts to promote the development of specific technologies either needed to keep the nation competitive or to meet national security needs.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: For example, during the 1970's through 90's various military research agencies like the Defense Advanced Research Projects agency and the Office of Naval Research financed academic and corporate projects not as investments but as contract research.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: In the early 1990's, the Government financed the Sematech computer consortium in an effort to maintain an independent semiconductor equipment industry in the United States, which was being threatened by Japanese and European competitors.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Louie, 39, said today that he would work on both coasts and was now looking for an office in Silicon Valley.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: He said he had become involved in the new company after meeting a headhunter from Heidrick & Struggles at a mock-aerial dogfighting contest this year.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Louie is a lifelong computer gaming aficionado who a year ago sold his computer gaming company, Microprose, to Hasbro.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: He has been a widely known figure in the Silicon Valley software world since creating his first computer gaming company while he was a student at San Francisco State University in the early 1980's.

title: High-Tech Advances Push C.I.A. Into New Company
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Among the new company's board members are John Seeley Brown, director of the Xerox Corporation's Palo Alto Research Center; Lee Ault, director of Equifax Alex Brown; Stephen Friedman of Goldman Sachs; Norm Augustine, chairman of Lockheed Martin, and William Perry, former Secretary of Defense.

title: Nortel Is Ready to Fire New Salvo in Internet Telephony War
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: 583 words 8 June 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company Firing the latest volley in the battle to transmit phone calls using Internet technology, the Nortel Networks Corporation of Canada plans to announce today that it is developing almost a dozen new products to help corporate customers integrate their phone and data communications networks.

title: Nortel Is Ready to Fire New Salvo in Internet Telephony War
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Nortel, formerly called Northern Telecom, is North America's second-largest maker of traditional telecommunications equipment, behind Lucent Technologies Inc.

title: Nortel Is Ready to Fire New Salvo in Internet Telephony War
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Nortel and Lucent are locked in battle not only with each other but also with leaders in data networking, including Cisco Systems Inc., to develop technology for unified voice and data networks.

title: Nortel Is Ready to Fire New Salvo in Internet Telephony War
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Such unified networks could allow companies to reduce the amount they spend maintaining separate voice and data systems, and could even open the door to new sorts of services, such as phones that communicate with address book software.

title: Nortel Is Ready to Fire New Salvo in Internet Telephony War
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Developing so-called Internet telephony technology requires big engineering commitments, and Nortel has recently appeared to lag in that effort behind Lucent, Cisco and small Internet telephony start-ups like Vocaltec Communications Ltd. and the Clarent Corporation.

title: Nortel Is Ready to Fire New Salvo in Internet Telephony War
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Some of the products that Nortel intends to introduce today will not be commercially available for another year or so, but the announcement seems sure to add momentum to Nortel's efforts to become a leader in Internet telephony.

title: Nortel Is Ready to Fire New Salvo in Internet Telephony War
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: While data networking companies like Cisco have appeared more aggressive in encouraging customers to anticipate scrapping their traditional phone networks in favor of more advanced Internet-based systems, older companies like Lucent and Nortel have encouraged a more evolutionary approach.

title: Nortel Is Ready to Fire New Salvo in Internet Telephony War
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: That approach is geared to appeal to companies that could be concerned about the reliability and capabilities of Internet phone systems. ''The fact is that most alternatives offered to customers for telephony over I.P. have been very primitive in the features they offer,'' said James R.

title: Nortel Is Ready to Fire New Salvo in Internet Telephony War
author: SETH SCHIESEL

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: It adds up to a detailed and convincing portrait, Mr.

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Judge Jackson must then comb through the mountains of evidence to try to answer one essential question: What are the appropriate legal restraints on the behavior of a powerful company in a dynamic high-technology industry?

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The issue extends well beyond the Microsoft case, and the stakes are high.

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The ruling could set ground rules for competition in the modern economy, affecting companies and consumers alike for decades.

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The legal guideposts to help Judge Jackson reach his decision, antitrust experts say, are not clear-cut.

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The major antitrust rulings over the last two decades are few, and they mostly involve mundane businesses including ski resorts in Colorado, a rural Ohio newspaper, a bowling alley in New Jersey and an egg processor in Indiana.

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: In some ways, the plaintiffs brought a very traditional antitrust suit.

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Microsoft, according to the Government, used exclusionary contracts and threats to defend its monopoly product -- the Windows operating system, the software that serves as the central nervous system of 90 percent of the personal computers sold today.   ''It is mainly an old-fashioned contract case,'' said Herbert Hovenkamp, a professor at the University of Iowa law school and leading antitrust scholar, who is advising the Government. ''There is nothing novel about the practices.

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The one thing that is novel is that the case is in the software industry.'' Yet the industry context is a crucial consideration.

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The software business is regarded as the forerunner of what has been called ''the new economy'' -- a fluid environment in which market leadership can be fleeting, but technology can also hasten the concentration of market power and the creation of monopolies.

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: In short, new-economy theories can cut both ways in antitrust cases.

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The fact that the Microsoft case focuses on a fast-moving, technically complex industry complicates the legal judgment the court must make. ''It makes the toughest issues that courts have to deal with in antitrust cases -determining market power, evaluating the significance of conduct and designing remedies -- far more difficult,'' said William Kovacic, a professor at the George Washington University law school.

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions
author: STEVE LOHR

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions

title: As Testimony Ends, Microsoft's Judge Waits for Motions

title: Cisco to Offer More Details On Wireless Technology
author: JOHN MARKOFF

title: Cisco to Offer More Details On Wireless Technology
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: The technology is meant to be a nonmobile -- or fixed -- wireless alternative to the telephone industry's high-speed digital phone lines and cable television industry's Internet modems.

title: Cisco to Offer More Details On Wireless Technology
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Cisco's briefing will be the first detailed plans to follow an announcement last month by the company, Motorola and 10 other equipment makers and service providers who said they would create an industry-standard format for sending Internet data over a long-existing, little-used set of microwave frequencies.

title: Cisco to Offer More Details On Wireless Technology
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: That frequency band, known as multichannel multipoint distribution services, or M.M.D.S., was set aside years ago for a form of wireless subscription television that was meant to compete with cable television but never really caught on.

title: Cisco to Offer More Details On Wireless Technology
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: More recently, M.M.D.S. has been seen as a way for telecommunications giants like Sprint and MCI Worldcom to compete with the regional Bell operating companies to provide direct connections to local telephone customers.

title: Cisco to Offer More Details On Wireless Technology
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Now Cisco and other equipment makers are trying to push M.M.D.S. into a full-blown voice and Internet-access technology.

title: Cisco to Offer More Details On Wireless Technology
author: JOHN MARKOFF
chunk: Use of the M.M.D.S. frequencies requires licenses from the Federal Communications Commission.

author: JOHN MARKOFF

title: Cisco to Offer More Details On Wireless Technology

title: Cisco to Offer More Details On Wireless Technology

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: 971 words 30 September 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company BY early next year, computing and communications devices will begin showing up on the market with a communications technology called Bluetooth built into them.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Their arrival, the companies supporting the Bluetooth technology say, will signal the beginning of the personal-area network.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Bluetooth, which is the creation of a consortium of computer and communications companies -- Ericsson, I.B.M., Toshiba, Nokia and Intel -- was conceived two years ago as a way to eliminate the tangle of cables that plague device-happy computer users.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: It has since evolved from a way to reduce last-minute trips to Radio Shack for that missing nine-pin serial connector into a technology for a broad range of wireless applications.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Bluetooth works by allowing high-speed communication among devices that are within 33 feet of one another.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: While some current mobile devices can communicate through infrared signals, those signals must have a clear, straight path from one device to the other.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Bluetooth, in contrast, operates on a radio frequency, so its signals can penetrate walls and briefcases.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: That means an electronic organizer in your pocket could transmit a phone number to the cell phone in your briefcase and initiate a phone call -- all part of your personal-area network.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: With Bluetooth, your digital camera could send a photo straight to your printer.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Or seconds after you snapped a photo from a ski lift, the digital camera could send the image to the cell phone in your pocket, which could then send the photo as an E-mail attachment to friends back home.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Consider slightly more far-out scenarios, too: You arrive at the airport and buy a ticket simply by walking past a wireless terminal, which confirms your identity, issues an electronic ticket and bills your credit card.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: And a flight attendant would no longer ask passengers to turn off their electronic devices.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: The plane's master Bluetooth device would shut them all down automatically for takeoff and landing.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: The rather mystifying name Bluetooth for this blend of hardware and software was the inspiration of a group of engineers from Intel and Ericsson who are admirers of King Harald Bluetooth, who ruled Denmark from 940 to 985 and is known for unifying the country.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Such seamless integration is Bluetooth's goal as well, said Per-Erik Svensson, the Bluetooth marketing manager at Ericsson Mobile Communications. introduce a wireless cell phone headset.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: The headset will come with a small clip-on adapter for the phone with a Bluetooth chip in it.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: In the first half of 2000, PC cards with Bluetooth chips will be introduced; high-end cell phones and laptop computers will begin to appear in the second half of the year.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Peripherals, digital cameras and personal digital assistants won't be far behind. ''Bluetooth will be in virtually every product within three to four years,'' Mr.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Bluetooth's 2.4-gigahertz frequency (a gigahertz is a billion cycles per second), which also happens to be the frequency for microwaves and a new generation of cordless phones, does not mean that a Bluetooth device will start your oven or make your phone ring, said Brent Miller, a senior engineer who specializes in Bluetooth at International Business Machines.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Bluetooth uses spread-spectrum technology, which means that the signals are sent over a wide range of frequencies and jump from one frequency to another.   ''It's the frequency hopping, the hopping pattern and hopping speed that mitigates any interference problems,'' Mr.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Miller added that technical safeguards insured that a cluster of Bluetooth devices in, say, an airport lounge would not suddenly start talking to one another.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Initially, the add-on cost to manufacturers for incorporating Bluetooth into devices will be around $25.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: That will drop to about $5 as volumes increase.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: The cost to the consumer will, of course, be still higher.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: That added cost has given some manufacturers pause. ''Bluetooth is an interesting technology that everybody is taking a serious look at,'' said Mark Lowenstein, a senior vice president at the Yankee Group, a technology research company in Boston. ''But there has not yet been a solid commitment because the economics for deployment are not quite there yet.'' Still, more than 1,000 companies have signed on as Bluetooth adopters, which means that they are interested in incorporating the technology into their products and services.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Once Bluetooth gains widespread acceptance, said John Patrick, vice president for Internet technology at I.B.M., ''you won't buy a product without it.'' ''Would you buy a Sony Walkman without Dolby?'' he added. ''I'm dying to have it, personally.'' Despite creative efforts at hiding them, Mr.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Patrick said, cables run rampant in his office at home, connecting his computer to an MP3 player, label printer, fax-printer, Audible player, palm-size device and business card scanner.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: When he travels, his briefcase is filled with mobile devices and their attendant cables and cradles and often weighs more than his suitcase.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Bluetooth will allow people to be more inventive with the communications.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: You might be wearing a piece of jewelry, for instance, that was actually a wireless headset for your cell phone.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Or you might shake someone's hand and exchange electronic business cards via your Bluetooth shoes.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Patrick would rather not emphasize those futuristic applications. ''Frankly, I think that stuff turns people off a bit, where we're irrelevant and we're all just a carcass, carrying a computer,'' he said. ''But the idea of cleaning up the cable mess and simplifying your personal productivity environment -- now, that's a big deal.'' title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Some employees may leaf through plan summaries or peruse health-care provider directories to make their choices, but at an increasing number of companies, employees are doing things differently.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: These tasks are, or soon will be, completed electronically, from the desktop at the click of a mouse, and by the people getting the benefits, not by human resource departments.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: At the Oracle Corporation, the Boeing Company and Charles Schwab & Company, for example, workers surf internal corporate computer networks and Web sites set up by benefit providers to check their 401(k) account balances, switch health-care plans or update W-4 forms, all tasks that were once exclusively the job of human resources employees.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Other companies, like the Marriott Corporation and Anheuser-Busch Companies, are using self-service call-in centers that link employees with benefits data; many of these systems present employees with a series of menus that enable them to make benefit choices.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Known in the industry as employee self-service, this self-help notion is quickly sweeping the workplace, as companies use technology to shift the responsibility for many benefits-related tasks directly to employees.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Employers embrace the notion as a way to automate their human resources departments, cutting costs and increasing efficiency.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Some find it empowering to be able to see their files and change their choices.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: But others find it frustrating to be left to sort out the merits of an insurance plan on their own, trying to decipher the coverage limits described on an insurer's Web site without the benefit of a human being to help explain them.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: That inherent tension leads some observers to question whether low-tech human assistance is better than high-tech self-help in the area of employee benefits, or in at least some parts of the benefits process.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: And experts and users seem divided on whether self-service systems guarantee employees the depth of information they need to make timely benefits decisions. ''I've seen corporations try to replace the human touch with technology, and it doesn't always work,'' said Donna Malinak, president and chief executive of Forward Mobility, a management consulting company in Bernardsville, N.J. ''I don't believe that one can completely replace the other.'' But one thing is certain: companies are quickly moving in that direction.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Automating benefits through Web-based technology, called virtual H.R. (for human resources), is growing fast.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Fifty percent of 466 companies surveyed now conduct at least some human resources transactions over the Web, nearly double the rate in 1997, according to a survey conducted last year by Watson Wyatt Worldwide, a consulting company in Bethesda, Md.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: The use of Web-based applications outpaces other methods, like interactive voice-response systems and free-standing kiosks that offer workers access to their files, the survey showed. ''It's very, very clear that this is where companies are going,'' said Steve McCormick, the virtual H.R. consultant at Watson Wyatt. ''To the extent that it has a network and PC's, I think every company intends to move toward some type of self-service of its H.R. functions.'' Cost savings are driving the trend.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: McCormick cited a large pharmaceutical company that had moved parts of its benefits information on line through a local corporate network after figuring that it spent $16.40 each time it had   to process an address change filed on paper.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: When the company multiplied that times its estimated 100,000 address changes a year, ''the cost savings become just so obvious,'' he said.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Moving data on line can also give employees easier access to their benefits files so they do not have to wait for a paper statement.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Schlumberger Ltd., an oil-field services company based in New York, offers its 16,000 employees in the United States 24-hour access to personal benefits information through its interactive Web-based system.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Employees can conduct investment research, change 401(k) contribution rates or send E-mail to their benefits administrator. ''The biggest gain is that employees can have access when they need to make a decision,'' said Lillian Petty, Schlumberger's benefits manager for North America. ''There's a difference between pushing information to employees or letting them pull out what they want.'' The site, called the Schlumberger Automated Benefits Link, has received an average of 320 visits per day since it opened in May.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Next up: full benefits enrollment on line this year. ''Our goal is to have paperless benefits administration,'' Ms.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: That is an attractive goal for any business, but can it work for every employee at every company, even those who do not have daily access to personal computers or phones at work?

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Such a shift can present a classic divide between haves and have-nots, people who have studied the trend say: employees with computers have access to information that those on the shop floor do not.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: In that case, companies must take a different approach.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: At Schlumberger, for example, 52 self-service kiosks at its manufacturing centers give employees without computers access to the information that is available to other workers on line.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: A similar approach is being taken by Hard Rock Cafe International, a restaurant chain based in Orlando, Fla.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: It plans to introduce an interactive CD this month that will carry information on all company benefits, including its 401(k) and health plans.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: The CD's will be sent to its 45 restaurants and played at publicly available monitors in break rooms.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Kitchen training is already conducted via interactive CD's at all the restaurants.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: The videos are interactive; by using touch screens, Hard Rock employees will be able to learn about their benefits programs and monitor the growth of their retirement-plan contributions. ''We told ourselves that we could continue to do it with our current method -- shipping at least 6,000 benefits kits to employees, holding two to three meetings a year with each restaurant and traveling to and from -- or we could look at our own motto, 'Save the Planet,' and put a stop to all this paper,'' said Anthony Amato, director of compensation and benefits.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Amato estimated that the company used six tons of paper, at a cost of 20 cents per page, to inform employees about benefits each year. ''When we added up how much we were spending,'' he said, ''it was clear what we needed to do.'' Employees will be able to get answers to benefits questions by entering a personal identification number and password, Mr.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: The concept of self-service benefits for employees is not new, but its acceptance has been slowed somewhat by a persistent image problem, Year 2000 compliance problems and by the need for companies to invest in Internet technology. ''We have more than enough technology to bring this about,'' said Joel Lapointe, vice president for management consulting at the Hunter Group in Baltimore.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: He said he coined the self-service phrase and developed the concept in the 1980's, and many of his peers in the industry agree with that. ''The roadblock continues to be a culture-acceptance problem,'' he added.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: On one hand, employees who are comfortable with technology enjoy having access to their own information and control over it, and they want more of it, Mr.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Lapointe said. ''Employees know that companies have these sets of data about them,'' he said, ''but the source of the data is always the employee -- it all belongs to them.'' On the other hand, some workers may think that the trend shifts to the employee an unwanted chore that used to be management's job, say consultants who have worked on the new systems.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: One person who has studied management and employee benefits is Richard Hadden, president of Corporate Education Systems in Jacksonville, Fla., and co-author of ''Contented Cows Give Better Milk: The Plain Truth About Employee Relations and Your Bottom Line'' (Saltillo Press, 1998).

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Employees tend to see this newfound empowerment as either ''enablement or abandonment,'' Mr.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: Hadden said. ''If it enables them to do better things, that's good.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: In 1995, Marriott, based in Bethesda, Md., began a telephone benefits-enrollment system called Marriott Telephone Information and Enrollments, or Martie.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER
chunk: But the company's system also lets workers bypass the voice-response system and reach a person at any time during the call, said Maureen Brookbank, vice president for benefits planning at Marriott. ''It's nice to know that a person is available if I need one, but it's also nice not to have to go through them as a required part of getting the job done,'' said Laura Paugh, 44, vice president for investor relations at Marriott, who joined the company in 1980, when benefits enrollment was handled on paper by the human resources department.

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti
author: KATIE HAFNER

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti

title: Promising an End to Cable Spaghetti

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: 2,309 words 12 October 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company Thirty years ago, on Oct. 29, the inaugural message was sent over the first thin reed of what was to become the Internet.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: It was nothing so portentous as ''What hath God wrought,'' the words christening the telegraph in 1844.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: It was just the simple word ''login.'' There were only two nodes on what was then known as the Arpanet, the precursor to the Internet built by the Defense Department's Advanced Research Projects Agency.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: As the story has become enshrined in the folklore, a U.C.L.A. student named Charley Kline tapped out the letters ''l'' and ''o,'' which were dutifully echoed back by a computer at the Stanford Research Institute, a center about 300 miles northwest in what was not yet Silicon Valley.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: When he typed the third letter, ''g,'' the S.R.I. computer was supposed to recognize and complete the full command.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Instead, the letters caused a memory buffer to overflow, bringing down the system.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: But it was an exceedingly minor crash, said Bill Duvall, who was tweaking the connection on the Stanford end.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: The buffer size was increased and the first connection was flawlessly made. ''I guess that I really don't care to be known as 'The First Guy to Crash the Internet,' '' Mr.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: What sticks in his mind is the satisfying feeling of getting the pieces of the complex system to mesh.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: The S.R.I. computer had to be fooled into thinking it was talking to a regular old teletype machine, a ''virtual user,'' which might as well have been in the same room.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Stanford had practiced for the occasion by running simulations of the network connection.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: But there is no substitute for the real thing. ''Quite a bit of thought went into debugging the initial network connection,'' Mr.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Duvall recalled. ''When the S.R.I. end came up, I was pretty happy.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: I guess that it is a bit like a symphony -- it's the last note that is remembered, not all of the stuff in between.'' No one apparently thought to take a picture.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: And no one recalls what messages followed. ''It seems like it should have been 'Watson, come here!

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Duvall said, referring to Alexander Graham Bell's first, urgent telephonic command (he had just spilled battery acid). ''That would not have been out of character.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: But, alas, I really don't remember.'' And so the revolution quietly began.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: With one scarcely noticed milestone after another, the planetary nervous system envisioned in the early 60's -- cyber rhetoric is as old as a Beatles tune -- unceremoniously began insinuating itself into society.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: A strange amalgam of Defense Department money, engineering expertise, and even a dab of countercultural idealism, slowly brought on the Net we know today.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: There was no big ribbon-cutting a month later when a third node was installed at the University of California at Santa Barbara, or the following month, when the reach extended outside California to the University of Utah.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: No golden spike was hammered into the ground to commemorate the joining of the coasts with a link to Cambridge, Mass., where a small consulting company called Bolt Beranek & Newman had won the contract to build and run the Arpanet.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: What was emerging would be barely recognizable today.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: There were no @ signs, no dot coms, no World Wide Web, nothing called E-mail.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: The main purpose was to let university-based researchers for the Defense Department agency share computer resources, allowing someone in, say, California to run a program on a machine in Massachusetts.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Many system administrators were reluctant.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: But from very early on, a handful of visionaries realized the synergistic power that would come from someday putting a computer on everybody's desk, then gradually weaving them into one great matrix.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: In an age when computers were still identified in the public mind with punch cards and spinning reels of tape, some of the early fomenters of the information age showed stunning prescience.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: As long ago as 1945, in The Atlantic Monthly, Dr.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Vannevar Bush, the engineer, educator and government research adviser, came up with the basic idea of the personal computer, a device he called the memex -- a mechanical extension of human memory.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Never mind that it was as big as a desk and that it stored all your documents, including encyclopedias and reference libraries, on super-fine-grained microfilm shuffled by nimble mechanical fingers and projected onto translucent screens.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Though embodied in the clunky technologies of the time, the memex would work something like an associative memory -- or, less grandiosely, a relational database.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: A user researching the history of the bow and arrow might start by calling up an encyclopedia article.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: When he found another relevant passage in a book, he would link the documents with a few keystrokes, encoding them with crude hyperlinks, and even add his own annotations. ''Thus he builds a trail of his interest through the maze of materials available to him,'' Bush wrote.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: To his credit, Bush also speculated that going beyond ''dry photography,'' the data might be stored as magnetized dots on metallic sheets using the technology that already existed for recording voices on spools of wire.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: And for entering data, he even envisioned the scanner, an outgrowth of the radio facsimile machines that already existed in his day.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: The big thing Bush missed was electronic networking.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: He imagined the researcher conferring with someone a few years later who wanted to incorporate the bow-and-arrow material into his own study on technology. ''He sets a reproducer in action, photographs the whole trail out and passes it to his friend for insertion in his own memex,'' he wrote, ''there to be linked into the more general trail.'' He had invented the World Wide Web with messengers on bicycles in place of high-speed digital T-3 lines.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Licklider, one of the most visionary computer scientists of his day, took another leap with his predictions of a ''Galactic Network'' linking everyone to a universe of information.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: In a later paper titled ''The Computer as a Communication Device,'' he and Robert W.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Taylor, who would go on to direct the Arpanet project, imagined nothing less than ''a labile network of networks, ever-changing in both content and configuration.'' ''What will go on inside?'' they asked. ''Eventually, every informational transaction of sufficient consequence to warrant the cost.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Each secretary's typewriter, each data-gathering instrument, each dictation machine, will feed into the network.'' There would be no need for letters, telegrams, telephone calls or even business trips.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: People would simply link their computers.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Dictionaries, encyclopedias, investment advice, tax counseling, advanced scientific modeling programs -- all would be available within the Net.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: On-line communities would form with people selected ''more by commonality of interests and goals than by accidents of proximity.'' And, more ominously, the two researchers speculated, those denied the benefits of this ''intelligence amplification'' might be relegated to an information-deprived underclass.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Both the bright and dark sides of today's Internet were anticipated years before the first message was sent.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: For all the grandiosity of the vision, the Internet developed haltingly.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: To make Licklider's Galactic Net a reality, scientists and engineers had to design a communications system that operated like none that had come before.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: The obvious example to emulate might have been the telephone network, in which long-distance calls from one small town to another were routed like airline flights through one or more central hubs.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: But in the early 1960's, researchers began to realize that a computer network would be much less vulnerable to failure if it was more widely spread out -- less like the air travel system than like the network of back roads weaving together every municipality in the country.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Each point is connected to its nearest neighbors by several redundant paths.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: If a connecting node between A and B fails, it is easy to find an alternative route.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: But there was an even more radical difference between the networks of old and the one that was about to take root.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: In an ordinary telephone system, two phones were linked by forming a temporary circuit, a dedicated physical channel through which the electrified voices flowed.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: The telegraph used a different technology called message switching: each telegram was given an electronic address, then sent into the Net, where it would be relayed, node by node, to its destination.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Paul Baran at the RAND Corporation and Donald Watts Davies at the British National Physical Laboratory independently saw the advantages of taking this ''store and forward'' model a step further.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: A message from one computer to another would be chopped up into many little packets, which would be sent swarming through the network to find their way.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Some would take this route, some would take that.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Each would carry a destination label along with instructions for where the packet fit inside the overall message.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: No matter in what sequence the pieces arrived, they could be reassembled.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: In this system, called packet switching, there would be no need to tie up a circuit for a single transmission.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: And since the messages were broken into smaller fragments, the flow would be smoother.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Finally, if a packet got corrupted, one could just resend it and not the whole transmission.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Leonard Kleinrock, who would preside over the establishment of the first node at U.C.L.A., was using a mathematical tool called queuing theory to understand how data would flow in a packet-switched network.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: By 1966, with these and other basic ideas in place, Lawrence Roberts, recruited by ARPA from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, mapped out the plan.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Two years after the first transmission, the number of host computers grew to 23.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: The @ symbol was invented in 1972, and a year later 75 percent of the Arpanet traffic was E-mail.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Before long, other organizations, like the National Science Foundation, wanted their own networks.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Vinton Cerf of ARPA were putting the finishing touches on the lingua franca, inelegantly called TCP/IP, that would weave the patches into the electronic quilt called the Internet.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: And that is just a fraction of the contributions.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: No one stands in relation to the Internet as Bell to the telephone or Morse to the telegraph.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: There was no single moment when it all came together.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: From the beginning, it was a continuous collaboration.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: And any attempt to recite the history in less than a book must be notable for its omissions.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: It was not until 1984, when the Net had grown to include 1,000 host computers, that the domain name system was established that lets Amazon.com be Amazon.com and not 208.216.182.15.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: And in 1991 came the World Wide Web followed by Mosaic, the graphical interface, or browser, that inspired Netscape and Explorer.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: The number of Internet hosts quickly exceeded a million, and this year that number multiplied fiftyfold.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Before long the barbarians were at the gates.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Scientists on the Net were suddenly getting E-mail from journalists, then from their own parents, and then from children asking for help with their homework.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: The Pentagon was sharing the Web with pacifist groups, cyberspace mirroring the conflicts of the physical world.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Simply by typing ''Watson, come here'' into a search engine, one can now find a scanned image of Bell's original notebook pages at the Library of Congress.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: There on the yellowed paper, in his own handwriting, is what he really said (slightly different from what's often quoted): ''Mr.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Watson -come here -- I want to see you.'' Sitting up in the futurist's perch, where Licklider put himself almost half a century ago, today's visionaries talk about the arrival in the first decades of the coming millennium of ''ubiquitous computing.'' Hand-held computers will merge with cell phones, talking to computers hidden in the office walls and the trunks of cars, all linked into a pervasive net.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: With a spoken command, a person will have instant access to the invisible ether of information.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Writing in 1960, Licklider called this kind of technobiological mind meld ''man-computer symbiosis'' and ventured that bringing it together might take 15 years. ''The 15 may be 10 or 500,'' he added more realistically, ''but those years should be intellectually the most creative and exciting in the history of mankind.'' As the Internet inevitably recedes into the background, it can almost be taken for granted -- the ultimate compliment.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: It has become the platform on which its successor will rise.

title: From Two Small Nodes, a Mighty Web Has Grown
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: When the 40th anniversary or the 50th rolls around, it will be even harder to untangle the individual contributions to something so much bigger than its inventors.
