title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: 1,126 words 12 January 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Microsoft Corporation began its defense in the Government's antitrust lawsuit today with an economist from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology bearing a massive tome of written testimony with a simple message: Microsoft's business practices are good for consumers, and any Government meddling with the software industry would likely do more harm than good.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Schmalensee of M.I.T. is a sweeping rebuttal to the Justice Department's two-and-a-half-month attempt to prove that Microsoft used its monopoly in personal computer operating system software to thwart competitive challenges posed by therise of the Internet.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Schmalensee wrote in his direct testimony, amounts to ''speculation'' based on a ''morass of E-mails'' from Microsoft executives that at first glance may seem damaging, but are not.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Forget the atmospherics, he tells the court, and focus on the outcome -- what he insists is a lack of measurable harm, current or future, to consumers from Microsoft's business practices. ''Proper economic inquiry into whether a company is engaged in anticompetitive conduct should end if it concludes that consumers have not been harmed by the conduct at issue and are not likely to be harmed in the future,'' Mr.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: High and rising product prices are typically the litmus test of whether a monopolist has the power to punish competitors and gouge consumers.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The Government's evidence shows that Microsoft has increased the price it charges personal computer makers for its Windows operating system in recent years, even as the prices of other components of computer systems have declined.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Still, the cost of Windows accounts for less than 5 percent of the price of a typical personal computer -- not really evidence of the kind of price-gouging normally associated with a monopolist, as some economists have noted.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But the Government's case is focused as much on the future as on the recent past.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: If Microsoft is allowed to continue to thwart competition, the Justice Department says, consumers will surely suffer from less product choice, less innovation and higher prices in the long run.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The case will be decided by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson in this nonjury trial based on his determination of which side the ''preponderance of the evidence'' favors.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Microsoft's objective is to convince the court that there are enough flaws in the Government's case that the balance should tip toward the company.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Schmalensee describes the suit by the Justice Department and 19 states as ''fundamentally inconsistent.'' The Government asserts, he notes, that Microsoft has an enduring monopoly because its Windows operating system controls the basic operations on more than 90 percent of personal computers sold, and that barriers to entry in that market are high.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: On the other hand, he adds, the Government says that Microsoft invested hundreds of millions of dollars because it was scared of losing its dominance to an upstart maker of Internet browser software, the Netscape Communications Corporation. ''What is striking about the late-night E-mails and the almost frantic concern over competitive threats is that they show that Microsoft itself was extremely insecure about its leadership in operating systems,'' Mr.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: David Boies, the Justice Department's lead trial lawyer, replies that Microsoft was indeed deeply worried and ''did work to improve its software, but it also had its thumb on the scale.'' The Government has made several allegations against Microsoft, but a central one is that the company used its market power to prod personal computer makers, Internet service suppliers and Internet programmers to enter into ''exclusionary'' contracts that limited the distribution and promotion of Netscape's rival browsing software.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The Microsoft defense, again, is that the outcome in the marketplace shows that Netscape could and did widely distribute many millions of copies of its browser despite Microsoft's purportedly anticompetitive business practices.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Schmalensee notes, Netscape has gained an additional 14 million users of its browsing software.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But to gain these 14 million users, the Government replies, Netscape distributed about 200 million copies of its browsing software at considerable extra cost, even as Microsoft gave away its browser for free and bundled it with Windows.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Such Microsoft tactics, the Justice Department asserts, are part of a pattern of predatory practices intended to stifle competition.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Schmalensee counters that Microsoft's contracts requiring personal computer makers to ship the company's browser with Windows ''offer more choices to consumers'' and are ''therefore pro-competitive.'' His testimony is an advocate's brief, so Mr.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Schmalensee, like the 12 prosecution witnesses, seems to interpret the evidence to suit his argument.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: For example, when the experience of America Online Inc. supports the Justice Department, Mr.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Schmalensee refers to the leading on-line services company as ''Microsoft's fickle partner and bitter rival.'' But roughly 200 pages later in his testimony, Mr.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Schmalensee cites America Online's success against Microsoft's MSN on-line service as proof that bundled placement on the Windows desktop screen -- an advantage MSN enjoyed since 1995 -- does not thwart rival products from being distributed.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Schmalensee writes, ''skillfully exploited the many distribution channels open to it (or any other competitor) to beat MSN.'' Far from being the most valuable real estate in cyberspace, Mr.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Schmalensee declares, the Windows desktop is not an ''even particularly important channel of distribution'' -- a view not held by Microsoft executives, according to several internal E-mail messages in evidence.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Schmalensee also attacks the Government's case for trying to apply outdated ''textbook models of competition'' and ''chalk board theories'' to the fast-changing facts of the software industry.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The Government replies that the economist's stance amounts to trying to get an antitrust exemption for Microsoft and the software business. ''He is very close to saying you should never intervene in dynamic, high-technology industries,'' said Daniel Rubinfeld, a senior economic adviser to the Justice Department's antitrust division.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: In courtroom action today, Judge Jackson closed the trial to the news media and public while he heard testimony from Franklin M.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Fisher, an economist and Government witness, about the prices Microsoft charges personal computer makers for Windows.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The company-by-company pricing data, the judge explained, was ''confidential, sensitive, commercial information.'' Lawyers for several media organizations appealed.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But they only asked that the closed sessions be as limited as possible and that the judge consider releasing transcripts with the sensitive price data redacted.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The judge reopened the courtroom in the afternoon, and Mr.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Fisher continued his testimony, which is expected to end Tuesday.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Circuits; Section G Parents Log On to Campus Life 1,131 words 11 February 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company IT'S no secret that college campuses today are wired, with high-speed Internet hookups in dormitory rooms, on-line applications and distance-learning programs.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: But Gettysburg College (www.gettysburg.edu), a private liberal arts college with 2,200 students in Gettysburg, Pa., has taken the electronic campus a step further by allowing students and parents access to an interactive Web-based system that tracks and links many aspects of college life.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The system, called the College Navigation Project, was started about a year ago as a way to link students to one another and to a wide array of campus information, like financial records, grades and course descriptions.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: A version for parents was added at the end of October.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Students can customize the College Navigation Project to meet their own needs.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Don Redman, a Web programmer and analyst with the project, compares the system to a ''giant puzzle builder.'' Students can feed the system different bits of information about themselves, their studies, career goals or personal interests to create a student profile, he said.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: That dossier is then matched with information about courses, campus events, faculty members, internships -- and even other students.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The system can even act as a counselor, analyzing the courses a student has done well in and suggesting ways to build on academic and career strengths. ''We made the conceptual jump from basic Web pages to a smart machine,'' said Mike Martys, vice provost for information resources at Gettysburg.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Gettysburg programmers say that customization sets the College Navigation Project apart from Web systems at other colleges. ''Other schools are publishing information on the Net,'' Mr.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Redman said, ''but as far as we know, we're about the only ones taking it to the next step by making it personally useful.'' For example, students who need rides out of town for the weekend can tell the system where they want to go, when they want to leave and how close they need to get to their destinations.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The system will try to find them rides, sending E-mail to notify students of matches.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The project also makes available course archives.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The college maintains an annotated record of the 600 courses offered each semester.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Through the project site, visitors can pull up a vivid description of what a class was like 3, 5 or even 12 years ago, complete with its syllabus, the students who took it and comments from students or teachers. ''It's really a snapshot in time,'' Mr.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The College Navigation Project was designed and built in the past three years at a cost of about $250,000 and is used regularly by 78 percent of enrolled students, Mr.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Ninety percent of the students have active system accounts, he said.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Many other colleges and universities are taking steps to use Internet technology to link systems, students and former students.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Cornell University (www.cornell.edu), for example, is in the process of changing its Bear Access campus network software into Web-enabled software that will expand the system's offerings and access, said Steven Worona, an assistant to the vice president for information technologies at Cornell, which has 20,000 students.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The school already gives all new students a personal E-mail address, which they can keep and use for life.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Bear Access was created with tools from Project Mandarin (www.mandarin.org), a software consortium of 32 colleges.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Many consortium members have collaborated to create their own electronic campus information   services, like Pennsylvania State University's Oasis (Open Access to Student Information Systems), the University of Arizona's UAInfo, the University of Michigan's Wolverine Access and Washington State University's WSU Infonet.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: At Gettysburg, parents were invited to set up College Navigation Project accounts because students were giving their personal log-on names and passwords to their families. ''We would see an on-campus sign-on, and then minutes later, the same ID would be signing on from another location far away,'' Mr.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Martys said. ''Our security system would flag it each time.'' The parents' version of the system was introduced at a family weekend at the campus last fall.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: School officials say they have 132 active parent accounts and more than 200 applications for accounts from interested parents.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: There is one caveat: parents cannot get access at all unless their children agree to it.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Parents and children have to agree on exactly what parents have access to.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Federal law protects the privacy of student education records, including many of those that can be viewed through the College Navigation Project.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: While the Federal Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act gives parents certain rights with respect to their children's education records, those rights transfer to the student when the student reaches age 18 or attends any post-secondary school.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Martys said students' privacy had been an important issue in the development of the system.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Students can regulate what information concerning them that others can see by turning various menus on or off -- and they can change their choices daily.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Students have generally chosen to be very open with one another but wary of giving outsiders full access to personal information, Mr.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: The idea of parents' peering into their children's lives on campus also raises some interesting questions, Gettysburg officials and others concede. ''We are wondering if there are battles brewing over who gets to see what,'' Mr.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: One Gettysburg parent, David Frohlich of Rochester, called the college's system ''a great aid to communication.'' His 18-year-old son, Michael, is a freshman majoring in political science at Gettysburg and is in the college's choir.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: To get details about a holiday concert on campus, Mr.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Frohlich and his wife, Laraine, were able to tap into the College Navigation Project. ''It gives us the ability to check on things ourselves without having to bug him,'' Mr.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Frohlich said. ''We're five and a half hours away.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: We want to be involved, but we don't want to be intrusive.'' Course descriptions in the system are much more comprehensive than the small paragraphs typically found in class-schedule directories, Mr.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Frohlich added. ''There's a tremendous amount of detail, so it allows us to have input on what he may be choosing,'' he said. ''I think Gettysburg recognized the desire on the part of people other than just students wanting this information and that giving it to a much larger audience would be a wise trend,'' Mr.

title: Microsoft Puts Its First Witness On the Stand
author: STEVE LOHR
chunk: Frohlich added. ''I think it's going to turn out to be a tremendous tool.'' The New York Times)    Business/Financial Desk; Section C

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: 711 words 9 December 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company Bidding to stay on top of the fast-changing optical communications market, the Nortel Networks Corporation is nearing a deal to acquire the Qtera Corporation for $2.5 billion to $3.5 billion in stock, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The executives said a deal could be announced within a week but cautioned that the negotiations could still fall apart.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: One person close to the talks said there was an 85 percent chance that the two companies would complete a deal.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Another person close to the negotiations estimated that chance at 90 percent.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Spokesmen at Nortel, which is based in the Toronto suburb of Brampton, Ontario, and Qtera, which is based in Boca Raton, Fla., declined to comment.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Qtera, which is underwritten by venture capitalists, is among a group of young, little-known companies that are developing the next generation of optical communications technology.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Along with deregulation and therise of the Internet, the quick pace of optical development has been a main factor in the communications revolution, allowing glass fibers thinner than a human hair to carry billions of bits of digital information each second.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Big communications equipment companies like Nortel and Lucent Technologies, the former equipment unit of AT&T, spend billions of dollars each year on research and development.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But because there are so many technologies to pursue, the big players often find themselves acquiring start-up companies that have focused on niche areas that end up becoming important.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Qtera is developing technology that allows fiber optic lines to carry signals farther than they usually do now without regeneration.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Generally, optic signals that are carrying billions of bits a second must now be regenerated every 250 to 375 miles, analysts said.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: When the optical signals are regenerated, they are usually converted into electrical signals, then amplified and reconverted into pulses of light.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The need for such regeneration adds cost and complexity to the construction and operation of continent-spanning fiber optic networks.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Along with other companies like the Corvis Corporation, Qtera is developing a system meant to allow signals to travel as far as 2,000 miles without such regeneration. ''If you can kill electrical regeneration, you eliminate a huge cost element; it's a huge cost advantage,'' Sender Cohen, an analyst for Lehman Brothers, said yesterday. ''Qtera has the right solution to carry very high bandwidth traffic over very long distances cost effectively, more cost effectively than just about anything on the market today.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The only other company that has a comparable solution is Corvis.'' Both Qtera and Corvis, which is based in Columbia, Md., have tested their systems with Qwest Communications International Inc., the upstart long-distance communications carrier that has agreed to acquire U S West Inc., the regional Bell company.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Qwest also happens to use a lot of Nortel's optical transmission gear.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Nortel is considered the world leader in equipment that can transmit 10 billion digital bits a second on a single optical fiber.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: It would appear logical that Nortel would want to maintain its optical leadership by integrating Qtera's technology into its optical communications products.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But some analysts wondered yesterday whether Nortel's pursuit of Qtera bespoke a Nortel weakness.   ''The thing that grabs me is, why is Nortel Networks making this investment in a space that you would think they would own?'' said Frank Dzubeck, president of Communications Network Architects, a networking analysis and consulting firm in Washington.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Referring to the prominence of Cisco Systems in the market for Internet switches and of Lucent in the market for traditional phone systems, Mr.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Dzubeck added: ''It's like Cisco making an investment in a routing company.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: It's like Lucent making an investment in a telephone switch.'' Qtera has yet to ship its product in significant quantities, but the communications equipment market has become so heated that a $3 billion valuation would not appear unreasonable, analysts said.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Sycamore Networks Inc., for example, another new optical communications company -- albeit one in a different segment from Qtera -- had revenue of only $11 million in its last fiscal year but has a market capitalization of almost $20 billion.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: CORRECTED BY THE NEW YORK TIMES WEDNESDAY JUNE 09, 1999 An emerging category of World Wide Web software that blocks advertising is challenging the Web industry and rankling the nerves of some Internet executives.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Known by such names as At Guard, Internet Junkbuster Proxy, Intermute and Web Washer, these programs work by blocking ads before they appear on the user's screen.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: For Web users, ad-blocking software can mean faster performance, because files that contain ads laden with graphics and animation take far longer to load than files with text.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: For Web site operators, though, ad blocking is anything but a benefit.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Many executives of Web-based businesses contend that ad blocking, were it to catch on significantly, could clog their revenue stream and challenge the fundamental structure of the emerging Internet industry.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Invariably, industry officials draw a comparison to television: If users want free Web content they, like network television viewers, will need to put up with the advertising that pays for it. ''If ad blocking is freely available how will everyone's needs be met?'' said Scott Mathias, managing editor at ITVWorld.com, a producer of on-line programming.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: He said that widespread adoption of ad blocking would seriously damage his small but growing business. ''The audience already allows overt advertising in mainstream media,'' he said, ''so they must be tolerant in the context of the on-line model as well.'' Last month, in the wake of complaints of that sort, the multimedia software company Real Networks canceled plans to continue distributing another company's ad blocker, At Guard.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Real Networks' primary customers, which operate Web sites that employ its software for transmitting audio and video material, complained that Real Networks had no business promoting a product like At Guard that could threaten their advertising revenue.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Last year, advertisers spent nearly $2 billion to reach on-line audiences.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Most of that spending was for so-called banner advertisements -- ads, often flashing or otherwise animated, that appear at various spots on Web pages and beckon users to click for further information.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: By next year, barring a mass adoption of ad-blocking software, the Internet research firm Jupiter Communications expects banner ads to represent $4.4 billion a year in Web advertising revenue.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Ad-blocking programs have been available for several years.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But only recently have significant numbers of people begun using them as a way to speed up their Web surfing.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: While market analysts have yet to begin tracking sales of ad blockers, individual companies report sales are on the rise lately.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Siemens A.G., the German electronics giant that produces Web Washer, estimates that roughly a million people have begun using the program since it   was released in December.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: And Internet Mute Inc., the Cambridge, Mass., company that makes Intermute, has had rising sales in the same period.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The numbers may still be small, compared with the estimated 67 million Web surfers in the United States.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But producers of ad-blocking software predict that more people will adopt their products, driven by the increasingly frenetic tactics of the advertisers themselves.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Surveys show that the number of people who click on banner ads has dropped steeply in the last year, indicating that people are becoming desensitized to the ads.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Nielsen-Netratings, which tracks Internet advertising, says the click rate is now about half the level of 1.35 percent that surveys measured a year ago, meaning people on average now click on a particular ad fewer than once in 100 viewings.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Advertisers nonetheless contend that ad banners help them build brand awareness, even when consumers do not actually click on them.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But Web site operators complain that when an ad is blocked it is not downloaded from the advertising server computer, which means they do not get paid for ''serving'' an ad to that visitor to the site.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Clamoring for the attention of these increasingly jaded consumers, advertisers are adding more graphics and sound to their Web ads -- which, in turn, means that Web surfers end up waiting longer and longer for the ad-supported pages to appear on their screens. ''There is a war going on for surfers' attention; it's spoiling the Web experience,'' said Jason Catlett, founder and president of Junkbusters Inc.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Although his company's main revenue source is consulting fees for helping companies and individuals find ways to filter out junk E-mail, the company also offers an ad-blocking program called Internet Junkbuster Proxy.

title: Nortel Is Said To Be Seeking Deal on Optics
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Like many other providers of ad-blocking software, Junkbusters offers its program free for downloading from its Web site.

chunk: 640 words 20 January 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company In a challenge to makers of traditional communications gear, Cisco Systems Inc., the No. 1 maker of Internet equipment, says it is close to introducing a device that will allow communications carriers to route voice, video and data traffic on a single system, and at a fraction of current costs.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The device, which Cisco calls a virtual switch controller, is based on Internet technology and is meant to augment or replace existing communications switches made by companies including Northern Telecom Ltd. of Canada and Ericsson A.B. of Sweden.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But it is Lucent Technologies Inc., invigorated by its recent $20 billion deal to acquire Ascend Communications Inc., that Cisco has identified as its main competition.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: And it is Lucent, North America's No. 1 maker of traditional switching gear, that is the main target of Cisco's new product; Cisco said yesterday that the virtual switch controller would give it inroads into an $8 billion chunk of Lucent's business.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Much of the business of companies like Lucent and Northern Telecom is based on equipment that uses ''circuit switch'' technology, which gives each voice conversation its own communications lane.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Some communications experts believe that circuit-switch technology will eventually be replaced by systems that can perform more efficiently by breaking down communications into small pieces.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Those pieces, known as packets, can then share a common communications pipeline, only to be reassembled into intelligible messages at their destination.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: By agreeing to buy Ascend, Cisco's closest competitor in the data communications market, Lucent took a big step to beef up its Internet-based offerings. ''The real significance is that circuit-switching is a very limited technology and a proprietary technology,'' Donald J.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Listwin, a Cisco executive vice president who manages the company's relationship with big communications carriers, said yesterday in an interview. ''This allows us to move voice over onto high-speed data infrastructures and it's opening it up to offer competition and innovation.'' When phone companies that use switches from companies like Lucent or Northern Telecom want to add new services, such as call forwarding or Caller ID, they must often purchase that software from the company that made the switch.

chunk: Cisco says its new product, which it intends to formally announce by the end of the quarter, will incorporate open standards that allow carriers to buy new software from a variety of vendors.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: All that, Cisco says, will come at a price as little as 10 percent of that charged by its older competitors.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Still, Cisco will have to overcome the traditional providers' deep pockets, deep reputation for reliability and deep relationships with big communications carriers. ''From the standpoint of service providers, over all the thing that's really driving them is quality of service,'' said Daniel C.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Stanzione, the president of Lucent's Bell Laboratories unit, speaking generally about Lucent's strategic outlook. ''They want to be able to offer reliability beyond what you currently see in Internet switching.'' Mr.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Stanzione added that with Ascend under its belt, Lucent intended to keep up with new technical standards and to set new ones. ''We have our own very very strong developments in new switching technologies,'' he said.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But Some communications behemoths have already thrown in with Cisco.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Marty Kaplan, the chief technology officer at the Sprint Corporation, the No. 3 long-distance carrier, said yesterday that Sprint intended to deploy Cisco's virtual switch controller as soon as this summer. ''It is a very efficient play that allows carriers to converge all of their services on a single platform,'' Mr.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Kaplan said, using communications jargon for a integrated suite of technologies. ''It would allow voice traffic over a data structure at a high degree of reliability and at a lower cost.''    Magazine Desk; Section 6 I'm O.K., You're Selfish 2,264 words 17 October 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company America's mythic sense of self rings out from the very words ''rugged individual.'' Think of the Deerslayer, Davy Crockett, Amelia Earhart, Clint Eastwood.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: At times, though, the stereotype has failed to ring true; in truth, individualism has run in pronounced cycles.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Just in the last 50 years, it was precisely the lack of individualism that prompted William H.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Whyte's ''Organization Man'' and David Riesman's ''Lonely Crowd,'' best sellers articulating public concern about the dangers of conformity.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Americans, it was feared, had become too worried about fitting in, too afraid to be independent. ''Do not fold, spindle or mutilate,'' the instruction on computer punch cards, became a slogan against docile regimentation.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Now, to judge by new evidence, the cycle has swung back again to individualism, indeed swung past self all the way to selfish.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The evidence comes from a New York Times survey conducted for this special issue.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The selfishness is not shameless; in fact, the public seems somewhat conflicted.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: People bemoan the self-centeredness they see around them.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: They regret that family ties are weakening.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: They complain that they can't trust most people.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But at the same time, they express starkly individualistic views.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: When presented with a list of basic values, they strongly identify with personal responsibility, self-sufficiency and self-expression.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: And not many see the contradiction -- that if everyone puts highest priority on one's own interests, then family and community ties may weaken further.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The watchword has evolved from Rugged Individual to I'm O.K., You're Selfish.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Individualism may feel like a natural condition, but many of its aspects did not develop until the last thousand years.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Surnames, for example, did not emerge until the mid-1300's.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Before then men typically were identified only by the names of their fathers -- John, son of Henry; Martin, Peter's son -- and women took the names of their fathers or husbands.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: In eastern Europe, Jews typically did not have last names until the early 1800's, and in America, far into the 19th century, slaves were not permitted to have surnames unless given one by their owners.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: As for the idea of personal space, it was not until the 1700's in England that corridors were first included in the homes of the well-to-do.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Until then, to get from room A to room E, one had to walk through all the rooms in between.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The newest aspect of individualism is that more people can aspire to it.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: A rising standard of living has freed most Americans from having to spend every waking hour satisfying basic needs.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Middle-class affluence has also reduced the need to rely on parents or children and has enabled many more people to go it alone.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: A hundred years ago, few people lived by themselves; today 1 out of 4 households contains only one person.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Meanwhile, the character of individualism has changed.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The older style, echoing Franklin and Emerson, turned on self-reliance, achievement --what sociologists call utilitarian individualism.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But a newer style has blossomed in recent decades, what is called expressive individualism.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: That is about emotional gratification, self-help, getting in touch with feelings, expressing personal needs.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Utilitarian individualism is going West, on Horace Greeley's advice, to find your fortune.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Expressive individualism is going to the forest, on Robert Bly's advice, to find your inner essence.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Expressive individualism has flourished as prosperity has given more Americans the time and money to cultivate their own emotional gardens.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: It was not always so: if my grandparents had been asked about the importance of communicating their feelings, they might not have understood the question.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: They were too busy running a grocery store, raising 10 children and trying to survive the Great Depression.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The responses to The Times's survey display both styles of individualism, as well as Americans' ambivalence about them.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The survey asked people how much importance they attach to each of 15 values.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: What's notable is   how, comparatively, people rate each value.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Old favorites like being involved in your community or having a lot of friends fare poorly, relative to the others.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The value rated as ''very important'' by the highest percentage of people was ''being responsible for your own actions.'' It is utilitarian individualism in its pure form.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: More than 95 percent call this very important, in every major category -- white, black and Hispanic; women and men, poor and rich, liberal and conservative.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: In fact, three of the four highest-rated values reflect personal responsibility and self-expression. ''Being able to stand up for yourself'' came next at 89 percent and ''being able to communicate your feelings,'' which is sheer expressive individualism, followed at 78 percent, just ahead of -- remarkably -having faith in God,'' at 75 percent.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Yet the survey also suggests that Americans are uneasy about the extent to which they have pursued the individualistic dream.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Many responses reflect the ''I'm O.K., you're selfish'' pattern.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Only 17 percent say they are overly concerned with themselves but 60 percent think that most people are overly concerned with themselves.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Only 12 percent say that the people they know personally would take advantage of others, but 37 percent think that most people would do so.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Asked whether ''most people are just looking out for themselves,'' only 17 percent say that applies to their own acquaintances, but 43 percent say it applies to most people.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: In other words, there are lots of self-centered people in America, but nobody seems to know them.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Maybe these answers mean that Americans imagine society generally to be worse than the world they inhabit in real life.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: When people are asked questions like these by a poll taker, I suspect they're projecting their anxieties about themselves onto others.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: And often they don't like what they see. ''Most people are selfish,'' in the view of Rachel Davis, a 21-year-old student from Helena, Ark., interviewed after the poll. ''If they're volunteering, they're doing it to clean up their resume, not because they really want to help.'' She then adds: ''Sometimes I'm overly concerned with myself.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Everything is focused on what you can accomplish, what you can do and how far you can go. '' The survey also shows a declining level of trust.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: When asked, ''Generally speaking, would you say that most people can be trusted, or that you can't be too careful in dealing with people,'' only 35 percent say that most people can be trusted.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: That's somewhat lower than responses in surveys from the 1970's and 1980's.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The people least likely to trust others are the poor and near-poor, whose daily encounters have left them distressed.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Beverly Webster, a 25-year-old unemployed housekeeper from Dallas, says: ''I don't think you can be too careful with people who aren't either your family or people real close to you.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: If they know that you're easygoing, they will try to mistreat you and misuse you.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Most people are just looking out for themselves.'' The responses to questions about family life also show the tensions in Americans' sense of self.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: When asked, ''What aspect of your life is most fulfilling or satisfying,'' more than half mention family, children or marriage -- far more than any other aspect of life.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: And yet most people (77 percent) agreed that ''because of such things as divorce, more working mothers, single parents, etc., family ties in the U.S. are breaking down.'' Americans also view religion in an individualistic way.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Although 75 percent agree that having faith in God is important, far fewer (56 percent) agree that being religious is very important.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The difference is that ''being religious'' implies actively participating in worship, fellowship and other aspects of organized religious life.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Most Americans don't think religious participation is as important as one's faith and moral code. ''Religion to me means belonging to a specific congregation or denomination, and that is not very important to me,'' says Beth Parth, a 42-year-old hair-salon owner from Empire, Mich. ''Faith means something I found myself, not something I learned in grade school or something someone told me I had.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: It's very much a personal thing.'' In fact, other surveys have shown that most people don't have a great deal of confidence in the people running organized religion.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The sociologist Alan Wolfe, who interviewed middle-class Americans in eight suburbs, wrote of their ''quiet faith'': many don't worship regularly and most are tolerant of the religious beliefs of others.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: One in five people in The Times's survey say they have had an encounter with an angel or a devil or some other kind of supernatural experience.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: This wariness of organized religion and lack of interpersonal trust could be taken as evidence of a broader change in Americans' sense of self: declining involvement in civic groups, neighborhoods and communities.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Alexis de Tocqueville thought that American democracy worked, in part, because of the many local citizens' groups that could influence government and counter its power.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But over the past few decades, membership in groups like the League of Women Voters and the Masons has plummeted.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: In their place, advocacy groups like the American Association of Retired Persons and the Children's Defense Fund have proliferated.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Americans mainly contribute to these groups not by attending meetings but by writing checks.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The Times's survey reflects this shift. ''Being involved in the community'' ranked No. 13 on the list of 15 values, well behind ''having enough time for yourself.'' And 35 percent said that, in recent years, they had increased the amount they give to charity, compared with 10 percent who say they have decreased the amount.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: In an influential 1995 article, ''Bowling Alone: America's Declining Social Capital,'' the political scientist Robert Putnam warned of the consequences for democracy of the decline in civic engagement. (More people than ever are bowling, Putnam reported; but far fewer are bowling in leagues.) Other commentators suggest that the picture isn't so bleak.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The sociologist Robert Wuthnow argues that Americans are forming ''loose connections'' that can compensate somewhat for the decline in other forms of civic life.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: For instance, despite the declining membership in service clubs, more Americans are volunteering for service projects now than a few decades ago.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Most volunteer projects are short-term and focused, like spending a few hours a week at a food pantry; but they serve nevertheless to create social ties.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The rise of the Internet also helps: it provides E-mail links among family and friends, and bulletin boards connect people with common interests.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Let us grant Wuthnow's point that Americans are not turning into a nation of self-involved stay-at-homes.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: It nevertheless seems clear that the fabric of public life has frayed.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The reasons may include changes in the economy since midcentury.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: One notable change is the loss of job security, which uproots workers and undermines community.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Another is the infusion of many more women into the work force, meaning more two-earner families and more employed single parents. ''Between work and taking care of my children, who are 3 and 5, I don't have much time for community involvement,'' says Delisa Hunter, a 23-year-old cashier from Norfolk, Va.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: As The Times's survey shows, Americans like to lament their individualistic bent, all the while pursuing it.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: They also care about commitments to others, all the while changing partners, jobs and neighborhoods.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: Both sentiments -- individualism and commitment -are genuine, and both have a long history in this country and in Europe.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But the most fundamental quality of the American sense of self, suggests the sociologist John Hewitt, is neither individualism nor commitment but rather our continuing ambivalence as we steer a life course between them.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: The higher living standard of advanced capitalism has reduced the need for support from others and thus for strong lifetime commitments.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: It has allowed more Americans to steer toward individualism.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: They relish the levels of personal achievement and emotional gratification that they have attained as a result.

title: Cisco Planning an Alternative To Traditional Switch Systems
author: SETH SCHIESEL
chunk: But as is clear from their complaints about others and their anxieties about themselves, they're beginning to recognize the price.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: 3,273 words 18 April 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company WHEN Leonard Riggio was a night student at New York University, he coped with the droning tedium of business lectures by snatching a strategic seat behind a student with a broad back and, he says, losing himself in the pages of the ''History of the Peloponnesian War.'' He found the classes in business policy and management so dull, in fact, that he dropped out in 1965.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Riggio's $3 billion company -- engaged in its own battles -- is a case study for first-year M.B.A. students at N.Y.U.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: The graduate students are pondering the rise of Mr.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Riggio, a Brooklyn-bred entrepreneur, from bored student to chief executive of Barnes & Noble, the nation's largest bookselling chain.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: And for their final exam this month, they will try to answer the very question that confronts the complex and restless Mr.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Riggio: In an industry roiled by technological advances, with bookselling reduced to bits and bytes and two-day delivery and profits a distant concern for the company's most worrisome competitor, what exactly is Barnes & Noble's future?

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: As he searches for answers, the chief executive may want to crib the students' notes. ''For the first time in my lifetime, I can't see five years ahead the way I used to,'' Mr.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Riggio said, both of the book business and retailing in general. ''I can't see it clearly.'' At 58, with salt-and-pepper hair and Brooklyn still in his voice, Mr.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Riggio has presided over so many transformations in his 30 years of bookselling that it seems no surprise that he says one of his favorite books is ''The Metamorphosis'' by Franz Kafka.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Riggio was largely responsible for the book industry's last metamorphosis -- the advent of the superstore, which in the 90's has come to dominate the literary landscape with airy temples of titles, comfortable chairs and the fragrance of espresso.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Riggio is navigating his New York-based company through another metamorphosis.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: A pioneer among big, traditional retailers, he is taking his on-line business, Barnesandnoble.com, public, as Amazon.com and the Internet spin their web around eager investors and growing numbers of book customers.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: This time, the challenges and risks are greater than ever for a man who considers himself at his core a shopkeeper -- albeit one with a private jet, a de Kooning bronze on the three-acre lawn of his Hamptons estate and a Picasso displayed in his Manhattan townhouse.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Riggio is hedging his bets, anticipating that customers will feel equally comfortable lingering in superstores to scan the latest hardcovers, or shopping for exotic titles on line or downloading a bestseller from a home computer into a 22-ounce electronic reader.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: As in many of his transforming acts, he is building on others' early work -- in this case Amazon's, much as he did before by following Borders Group with a cafe or expanding on Bookstop's development of the superstores. ''There was a period at the beginning of the Internet where I didn't get it.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Riggio said in one of a series of interviews over the last few months. ''I came to it at first slowly, and then very, very quickly.''   Ultimately, he said, ''we jumped into the Internet business head first; we made big investments in capital, big investments in organization, big personal commitments to the business.'' Man of Metamorphoses His first transformation came almost 35 years ago, when, as a 24-year-old dropout, he invested $5,000 of borrowed money in a bookstore called Student Book Exchange near the N.Y.U. campus.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Six years later, in 1971, he bought Barnes & Noble, then a floundering bookstore in Manhattan's Flatiron district.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Riggio expanded into popular books, buying the B.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: And today, his more than 520 superstores plus 500 mall stores are so much a part of the landscape -- and seen as so threatening by independent booksellers -- that the conflict provided the story line for the recent movie, ''You've Got Mail.'' Not that Mr.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: There's little spare time in his life for movies or the novel that he's been promising to write for some 10 years.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: He dutifully clears his schedule for his 15-year-old daughter's basketball games, but his chip shot is languishing.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Instead, his mind is on the hazy tomorrow. ''It's not just the changes in the book business, it's the changes in retail, the changes in the way we live,'' Mr.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: With the Internet revolution, he said, sometimes ''I wake up and say that any business created before 1997 is going to be a fossil by the year 2010.'' An avid collector of late 20th-century art, Mr.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Riggio compares the fluid future to a Fred Sandback art installation -- two strings suspended from ceiling to floor.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: The gap between them is like everything that existed before and after the Internet, Mr.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Riggio said; successful people will understand intuitively, he said, that the space is ''real and not imaginary, yet be able to walk through it, whole, on the other side.'' Skeptics may look at the strings and see just strings.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Riggio is trying to lead his company on both sides of the divide, steadily building new superstores into a chain that he expects could eventually number 1,000 (though the expansion has slowed to about 50 this year from about 90 a year) while investing heavily in the Internet.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Last month, the company said that it would make a $200 million initial public offering of shares in Barnesandnoble.com; an offering announced in September was postponed because Bertelsmann A.G. bought a 50 percent stake in the electronic venture.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: The intent is to spend much of the proceeds to market the Web site, which had on-line sales of $70.2 million for the year, versus $610 million at Amazon.com and $4.6 million at Borders. (Barnes & Noble has a business tie to The New York Times, selling books through links from the newspaper's Web site.) The trouble, of course, is that Amazon unabashedly declares that it loses money on every sale as it grabs market share from Barnes & Noble and other traditional bookstores.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Some analysts estimate that by the end of this year, on-line sales will account for about 5 percent of the popular book market.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: And while it is still not clear what percentage of customers are shifting their purchases to the Internet, projections show sales growth online far exceeding gains at superstores over the next few years.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: For industry experts that raises the question of whether Mr.

title: Another Metamorphosis For Barnes & Noble Chief
author: DOREEN CARVAJAL
chunk: Riggio's electronic offspring will only speed the process, cannibalizing sales from his bricks-and-mortar outlets -- a scenario that could place some of his superstores in the same jeopardy as the independent bookstores forced to close when they could no longer compete.
