title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: 2,031 words 9 February 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company The letter, dated Christmas Day 1998 and addressed to a professor at the Niels Bohr Institute in Copenhagen, began portentously: ''Nowadays, we seek to comprehend our comprehensions and call that comprehensiveness knowledge in the mistaken belief that as a science it is immortal.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Such omniscience diffuses like Helium-3 into the penetralia mentis of omnipotent impotency within any God-head such that any caveat actor is saved. . . . '' Within a few sentences, the writer was holding forth on Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle and ''the concept of nothing'' as the empty set, before launching into speculations involving number theory: ''It's enough to make me conjecture that infinity's prime and Riemann's Zeta function accounts for fractional charge subatomically just for the Higg's boson with an involucral matrix of ogdoad parity as midwife!'' The letter was typed single-spaced with the tiniest of margins and embellished with hand-drawn diagrams and colored annotations.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Copies were sent to a list that included the linguist Noam Chomsky, the physicists John Archibald Wheeler, David Deutsch and Stephen Hawking, and the mathematician John Casti. ''It has all the hallmarks of a crank,'' said Dr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Casti, who is affiliated with the Technical University of Vienna and the Santa Fe Institute in New Mexico. ''It's amazing all the stuff you can get onto a single piece of paper.'' But was it not just possible that couched in the obscure mix of mathematics, physics and Egyptian mysticism (''ogdoad parity'' refers to four pairs of gods with names like Darkness, Absence and Endlessness), there lay an important insight?

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Didn't two Cambridge University mathematicians dismiss the great self-taught Indian number theorist Srinvasa Ramanujan as a crackpot when he sent them long eccentric letters from India early in this century?

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Hardy had the foresight to recognize Ramanujan as a genius.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: And didn't the great German mathematician Carl Friedrich Gauss foolishly throw away unread a groundbreaking paper from his young Norwegian colleague Niels Heinrik Abel, calling it ''another of those monstrosities''?

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Casti was not too worried about the possibility.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Though the stories of Ramanujan and Abel may linger in the backs of mathematicians' minds as they aim the latest unsolicited epistle toward the wastebasket, most become quickly jaded. ''After several hundred of these things you get into that mode,'' said Dr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Ian Stewart, a mathematician at Warwick University in England. ''It has to do with your self-preservation. ''The writers of these letters range from pretty good amateur mathematicians who have made a mistake somewhere or skipped over an important step to people who are completely mad,'' he said. ''You get very strange mail in 17 different fonts and 14 colors and with an idiosyncratic grammar.'' Many of the correspondents are intelligent, well-meaning, indefatigable souls who, in their untrained way, share the fascination mathematicians feel for the invisible world of numbers.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: The equipment necessary for discovering a subatomic particle in your own home costs too much and would never fit inside a basement laboratory or even a very large backyard.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: But with nothing more than a pencil and paper, and maybe a compass and straightedge, even an amateur can explore the mathematical nether world, stumbling across important new truths.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: That, anyway, is the dream or obsession that drives would-be Ramanujans all over the world to send mathematicians letter after letter crammed full of diagrams and equations promising answers to unsolved   problems ranging from squaring the circle or proving (in a simpler way) Fermat's Last Theorem to revealing, through the wonders of mathematics, the meaning of life.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Physicists get their share of mail from amateurs attempting to reconcile quantum mechanics and general relativity or to show that Einstein was wrong.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: But the greater ease with which one can speculate about numbers has caused the mathematical crank to become enshrined in academic folklore.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: The phenomenon is even documented in a book called ''Mathematical Cranks'' (Mathematical Association of America, 1992), by Dr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Underwood Dudley, a mathematician at DePauw University in Indiana. ''I've been at this for a decade and still can't pin down exactly what it is that makes a crank a crank,'' said Dr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Dudley, who has met a few in person. ''They are usually men, old men,'' he said. ''All are humorless.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: None of them are fat,'' a characteristic he attributes to their obsessive personalities. ''It's like obscenity -- you can tell a crank when you see one.'' With recent films like ''Good Will Hunting'' and ''Pi'' giving mathematics a romantic sheen and popular new biographies romanticizing the lives of the mathematicians Paul Erdos and John Nash, the flow of crank mail will only increase, predicted Dr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: John Allen Paulos, a mathematician at Temple University in Philadelphia.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Add millennial anxiety, including the Y2K problem, Dr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Paulos speculated, and the time he and his colleagues spend opening and discarding letters peppered with strange symbols and grand claims is bound to increase. ''Popular mathematics used to be an oxymoron,'' he said, ''but happily that's not true anymore.'' The celebrity, though, has its price. ''It's a real dilemma,'' said Dr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Reuben Hersh, professor emeritus of mathematics at the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque. ''Who is going to stroll through pages and pages of stuff that is very hard to understand when you don't have to do it?

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: From the point of view of these guys, we are arrogant, unwilling to reconsider ideas.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: And why shouldn't they expect a responsible scientist to look carefully at some new idea that might be important? ''You can't just say Ramanujan was a genius and these other guys were cranks,'' Dr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Hersh said. ''With a superficial look, there is hardly any visible difference.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: There is not always a sharp line between eccentric mathematicians and intelligent but maybe obsessed amateurs.'' Until recently much of the mail contained supposed proofs of Fermat's Last Theorem.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Andrew Wiles of Princeton University recently proved this famous puzzle and number theory, Dr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Paulos said, the focus has shifted to disproving Dr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Another favorite diversion is Goldbach's Conjecture, which holds that all even numbers are the sum of two primes.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Though no one has found a counter example, this would-be theorem remains unproven, unless the solution has been crumpled up in a math department wastebasket somewhere.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Mathematicians are especially impatient with letters claiming to have solved one of the three classical problems of Greek mathematics: trisecting an angle (dividing it into three equal parts), doubling a cube, or squaring a circle (constructing a square with the exact same area as a circle) using only a compass and an unmarked straightedge.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: The reason for imposing these restrictions was to see how much mathematics could be derived from two basic concepts, the line and the circle.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Solving the three classic problems this way has been proved impossible.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: In 1882, for example, the German mathematician Ferdinand Lindemann established that trying to square the circle was hopeless.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: The reason is that pi, the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter, is not only irrational (its infinitely long string of decimal places never repeats) but transcendental (it is not a solution of any polynomial equation with whole number coefficients).

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Amateur attempts at squaring the circle generally amount to rounding off pi to a close approximation like 22/7 or 355/113.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: At best the result is a square that is very close but never exactly the size of the circle. ''These people don't know what impossible means,'' Dr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Dudley lamented. ''They think it just means very hard.'' Or the writers do not believe the impossibility proofs. ''They start by saying they know there is a theorem that says it is impossible but they've done it anyway, so there must be something wrong with the theorem,'' Dr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Stewart said. ''They are operating in a conceptual vacuum.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: It leads to strange things.'' One of the rules mathematicians soon learn is never to answer a possible crank.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: The mail often comes with cover letters assuring that the work has been ''endorsed'' by a certain Harvard or Stanford professor, say, or even a member of the United States Senate.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: The attached letters are usually no more than polite brushoffs: ''Thank you   for your interesting letter. . . .'' A mathematician who makes a perfunctory reply can count on its being stapled to the next round of mailings.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Hersh replied to a letter from an amateur mathematician in India. ''This guy wrote very well,'' he said, ''in a good expository style.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: What he said made enough sense that I thought I would try to explain and straighten him out.'' Over several years, Dr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Hersh finally wrote back in exasperation: ''I've done all I can for you.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: I can't do anymore.'' The writer answered that he did not consider himself Dr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Cyberspace maps are being produced by geographers, cartographers, artists and computer scientists.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: They range from glorious depictions of globe-spanning communications networks to maps of Web information.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Many have no geographic references, instead turning to nature, the cosmos or neuroscience for spatial models.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: They stretch the definition of a map in their effort to capture, sometimes fancifully, what is sometimes referred to as the ''common mental geography'' that lies beyond computer screens.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: The maps hold the potential to change, subtly or perhaps more directly, the relationship of the average person to cyberspace, the world of electronic communication that includes but is not limited to the Internet.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: How people envision the on-line landscape influences their behavior there, experts say. ''We need maps not just to navigate but to define and control new territory,'' said Martin Dodge, a researcher in the Center for Advanced Spatial Analysis at University College London. ''Simply having a map allows a new perspective, a new way to orient yourself.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Relationships otherwise obscure may be revealed.'' The largest collection of maps can be found at Mr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Dodge's Web site, An Atlas of Cyberspaces (cybergeography.com).

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: The dozens of examples there include many that arise from science and instrumentation, while others are more products of imagination. ''We are in the very early stage of map making -- these maps are far from perfect at the moment,'' Mr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Dodge said. ''Most have been produced outside traditional cartography by people such as data visualization researchers who may not even call their results a map.'' Maps of cyberspace fall into two categories: those depicting the physical structure and information traffic patterns of global networks, and those addressing the content and social spaces of the electronic world.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Structural maps, although seemingly straightforward, have proved quite thorny to create.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Since the National Science Foundation relinquished its stewardship of the Internet in 1995, there has been no central source of information about the Net's backbone networks and traffic.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Instead, there is a jumble of networks owned by phone companies and Internet service providers, some of which do not share information, for competitive reasons.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: The Cooperative Association for Internet Data Analysis, or Caida, at the University of California at San Diego develops tools to collect and analyze data about the Net, like the specific paths a test packet of information may follow. ''We are not at a point yet where we are drawing maps with any compelling utility for any particular community,'' said K.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Claffy, a researcher with the association, via E-mail. ''Though at the same time I contend we are doing 'state of the art' stuff at the frontier of this field.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: I just think the field's pretty young right now.'' Useful or not, the Internet analysis group's maps can be quite beautiful.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Others have brightly colored grids and globe-spanning arches, suggesting a world that is deeply, even inescapably, interconnected.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Connectivity, not necessarily geography or distance, is the primary parameter of a cyberspace map, said Gregory C.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Staple, president of Telegeography, a company in Washington that provides statistics and maps of the   telecommunications industry.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: His company has produced maps of ''telecontinents,'' redrawing countries and coastlines to show how the flow of communications has created a new economic geography.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: At a glance, these maps reveal areas that are the telecommunications haves and have-nots, which Mr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Staple calls ''the deep-water ports and teledeserts'' of the information age (there are many more deserts than ports).

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Telegeography also offers maps of the Internet through its Peacock Maps subsidiary (peacockmaps.com).

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Geography is completely shunned by some mappers, like William Cheswick, a researcher at Lucent Technologies' Bell Laboratories. ''I want to take the Net on its own terms -- it's its own space,'' Mr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Cheswick argued. ''Geographical maps I've seen have not worked very well.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: They're very blobby.'' His maps, like those from the Cooperative Association for Internet Data Analysis, are based on information probes sent to tens of thousands of destinations on the Net.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Maps resulting from such probes are featured on his Web site (www.cs.bell-labs.com/who/ches/map/index.html).

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: They look something like promiscuously propagating sea ferns, with countless feathery vines.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Although his maps may inspire awe because of their complexity, Mr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Cheswick explains that until such maps are interactive, allowing access to the database that created them, they are more powerful as symbols, perhaps, than as maps.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Most so-called content maps are interactive and are focused on the portion of cyberspace now most populated: the Web.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Staple said, ''the equivalent of land-use maps in the traditional cartographic world.'' A new site called Newsmaps.com (newsmaps.com) creates ''visual information landscapes'' -- grid-based topographical maps -- of Web-based news articles and on-line discussion groups on topics like fears of year 2000 computer problems.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON

''Mapping and diagramming is basic to the kind of art that I do,'' Mr.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Boot has chosen on his theme of teen-age happiness.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Boot's map was included in an on-line exhibition titled Omnizone: Mapping Perspectives of Digital Culture (www.plexus.org/omnizone), in which artists were asked to contribute ''artworks that function (however obtusely) as maps of digital space and culture,'' a guideline to which most contributors religiously adhered.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Another on-line exhibition, an ongoing effort by the Guggenheim Museum called Cyberatlas, set its sites a little broader by not limiting the maps included to those dealing with cultural content (cyberatlas .guggenheim.org/home/index.html).

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON

''We need to find representations of cyberspace that encourage us to see advantages we can exploit -- ways we can bend and stretch the metaphor of space into new possibilities,'' said Jon Ippolito, the assistant curator of media arts for the Guggenheim and organizer of the Cyberatlas project. ''We don't want to be stuck in older geometries.'' Is a map of cyberspace, particularly the Web, needed at all?

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Still, some people see it as something close to a moral imperative to develop cyberspace maps.

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: Bruce Sterling, a science fiction author and self-described pop-science journalist, says that such maps could alter our experience of the on-line world. title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON

title: Genius or Gibberish? The Strange World of the Math Crank
author: GEORGE JOHNSON
chunk: A picture of the Earth from space did more for environmental awareness than any number of ecological urban legends.'' The era of personal maps that can provide that sort of perspective is approaching.

author: GEORGE JOHNSON

title: AT&T Conjures Up Its Vision For Cable, but Can It Deliver?

title: AT&T Conjures Up Its Vision For Cable, but Can It Deliver?

chunk: But traditional cable networks are built to transmit information in only one direction: from the company toward the user, and not the reverse.

title: AT&T Conjures Up Its Vision For Cable, but Can It Deliver?
author: SETH SCHIESEL

title: AT&T Conjures Up Its Vision For Cable, but Can It Deliver?

title: AT&T Conjures Up Its Vision For Cable, but Can It Deliver?

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Roughly once a decade, as some emerging technology reaches critical mass, start-up companies rush to cash in on the ensuing enthusiasm by selling their stock to the public.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: On Wall Street, where nothing succeeds like excess, investment bankers take a Darwinian view of these frenzies, pushing as many companies as possible through the financing process while the public's appetite is whetted but before it is sated.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: The eager Internet start-ups are so numerous that investment banks tell of having to turn away potential clients while some companies have resorted to trying creative methods to whisk their documents through regulatory approvals.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: A company might list itself in the transportation industry, for example, if it plans to sell airline tickets over the Internet.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Barring a midsummer market collapse, more than 100 newly public companies might be competing for the attention of investors before the usual August break of investment bankers, finance professionals say. ''We've certainly seen other booms, but we've never seen anything like this,'' said Kenneth R.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Fitzsimmons, director of capital markets at BancBoston Robertson Stephens, the San Francisco firm that has been one of the biggest underwriters of Internet stock offerings in the last six months. ''The market is far more frenetic, and companies are getting higher absolute valuations than ever before.'' The bankers typically scrutinize a company's financial condition and business plan, and they promise to provide coverage of the stock once trading starts.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Compared with past frenzies, this one is extreme in several ways.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Internet-related businesses already account for a bigger portion of the total number of new issues than biotechnology companies ever did, and these new stocks are rising higher and faster than anything in recent memory.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: While individual investors and day traders are contributing to the activity, institutional investors like mutual and pension funds are also eagerly chasing companies that many of them would have previously dismissed as speculative.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: And those big investors, ever mindful of investors' high expectations, are holding onto their shares longer, dampening supply and reinforcing the upward rise of many Internet stocks.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: All this interest is putting some strains on the initial-offering system, which usually steers the public's money only to the most promising companies.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Jesus Cabrera, who oversees the State Street Emerging Growth fund, says so many Internet companies are jockeying to go public that he cannot make it to all the ''road shows,'' the presentations at which company managers and their bankers use to describe the company's prospects.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: His solution: Watch some of the road shows over the Internet, on a service called Netroadshow.com. ''I place value in meeting companies in person so I can see the whites of their eyes,'' Mr.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Cabrera said. ''But if I tried to go to them all, I wouldn't have a life,'' or much time to manage a $100 million mutual fund.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Portfolio managers might take comfort in knowing that it has been hard to lose money investing in an Internet public offering in the last year.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: The point was driven home again on Friday, when shares of USInternetworking,   iTurf and Extreme Networks each jumped more than 100 percent from their offering prices in their first day of trading.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Such leaps are typical of the more than two dozen Internet-related companies that have completed initial offerings so far in 1999, and an improvement over the performance of similar offerings last year.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Fitzsimmons said his research shows that Internet offerings jumped nearly 70 percent, on average, in their first day of trading last year.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: It is not surprising, then, that Internet-related deals seem to be pushing other offerings aside.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: According to Thomson Financial Securities Data, almost a quarter of the initial public offerings so far this year have been for Internet-related companies, up from less than 10 percent last year.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: In 1991, when biotechnology companies were all the rage, those concerns represented about 20 percent of new issues.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: The $9.4 billion raised in all types of new public offerings in the first quarter of this year was a record, leading many on Wall Street to believe that 1999 could follow the path set in 1991, when a hot market for biotechnology offerings led to a record year for underwriters.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Investors, meanwhile, have shrugged at high-profile deals that in past years would have dominated headlines.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Consider the two biggest companies to complete recent initial public offerings -- Pepsi Bottling Group and Delphi Automotive Systems.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: On March 30, Pepsi Bottling, the largest bottler and seller of Pepsi products, completed the largest initial public offering this year by selling $2.3 billion of its shares at $23 apiece.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: The shares sank more than a point their first day of trading and have since fallen further, closing at $21.4375 on Friday.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Though the shares have spent most of their time at $18 or more, they have recently slipped to less than the offering price, closing at $17.4375 on Friday. ''The current I.P.O. market is significantly more concentrated in one sector than I've ever seen it,'' said Scott Sipprelle, a co-founder of the Midtown Research Group, which tracks initial offerings, and the former head of the equity capital markets division of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: That might be diverting money away from promising companies in other industries.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Global Markets Access, an insurer based in Hamilton, Bermuda, had planned to raise $244 million in an initial offering to be underwritten by Merrill Lynch & Company and Prudential Securities but withdrew its offering on March 31, citing market conditions.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: It certainly is straining the lives of bankers, lawyers, accountants, printers and others who keep the I.P.O. machine running. ''We've never been this busy, and we're turning things down,'' said Mr.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Fitzsimmons of BancBoston Robertson Stephens.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: While the firm's committee that reviews underwritings has always rejected some deals because of poor quality, ''we're having to pick and choose the deals we do much more now,'' he said, citing the high volume.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Perhaps of greatest concern to investors, however, is the relative shortage of analysts who understand and can follow the Internet companies once they begin trading.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: There is an almost endless supply of potential Internet companies -- which are often little more than a business plan and some financial projections.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: But few analysts can make sense of both Internet technology and the economic models that will lead to success on the new medium.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: David Readerman, a software and Internet analyst at Thomas Weisel Partners, a San Francisco investment bank, notes that while nearly every investment bank has at least two or three bankers working on Internet-related offerings, they have one securities analyst, at most, to follow the companies once the stock is trading.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Analysts will play a far more important role in following Internet companies, Mr.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Readerman said, than they did in, say, the biotechnology boom,.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: In the Food and Drug Administration, biotechnology companies had, an outsider to rule on their products' ultimate success or failure.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: But determining the prospects of an Internet company is more prophesy and conjecture.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: People involved in bringing Internet companies to market also complain of a bottleneck at the Securities and Exchange Commission, which must review a company's disclosure documents before granting approval to sell shares.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Investment bankers say the initial review, which is supposed to be completed within 30 days, is taking closer to six weeks.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Chris Ullman, an S.E.C. spokesman, denied that backlog; he said that while the average time for review of a filing for initial public offerings had recently been 31 to 33 days, it has now returned to 30 days.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: In Silicon Valley there is talk that the fastest way to get an Internet business to market is to pretend it's not an Internet company.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: When companies register with the S.E.C., the documents are initially routed within the agency to industry experts based on the company's Standard Industrial Classification code, a four-digit number indicating the industry in which the company does business.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Investment bankers and other Wall Street professionals say that companies have recently been tweaking their industry codes to avoid the queues numbered in the 7370's, which denotes computer systems and software.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: That queue has been used by a wide variety of companies, including Priceline.com, which sells discounted airline tickets over the Internet.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: But two other companies in a similar business -- Lowestfare.com and Cheap Tickets Inc. -- used the codes for transportation services and general business services, respectively.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Ullman said that whatever code a company initially files under, the S.E.C. will determine the correct industry and route the filing accordingly.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: In other words, he advised companies, don't try it.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Companies still cannot get their offerings to the market quickly enough, in part because they fear missing the opportunity before the financing window closes.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Investment managers, on the other hand, cannot seem to buy quickly enough, showing little regard for the outsized valuations at which Internet companies are going public. ''I had lunch with a mutual fund manager the other day and asked if he'd played in these Internet I.P.O.'s,'' said L.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Keith Mullins, who tracks small companies at Salomon Smith Barney. ''He said he had, so I asked if he could give me a fundamental reason to own any of these stocks at these prices.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: But he added, 'That's what's working right now.' '' Indeed, George S.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Shirk 3d, managing editor of the New Issues newsletter, said his publication has recommended that investors ''flip,'' or sell on the first day of trading, nearly every Internet I.P.O. that has come to market this year -- provided that an investor can get shares at the initial offering price, as institutions can but individuals usually cannot. ''We're not seeing a lot that we would recommend for a long-term investor,'' he said, particularly after trading begins and the stock has already more than doubled.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Though individual investors may be left out of the earliest part of the game, institutions are jumping into deals that, in the not-so-distant past, would have drawn little enthusiasm. ''Demand by institutional investors has gotten much higher because those managers want to show these stocks in their portfolios at the end of each quarter,'' said Linda Killian, who herself manages a mutual fund that invests in new offerings, the IPO Plus Aftermarket fund.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Whether the quality of the companies coming public has deteriorated is a matter of opinion.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: A decade ago, only rarely could a company go public without a record of sales growth from three to five years and at least some profits.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: In 1997, though, about a third of the companies completing initial offerings were losing money, Ms.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Today, a similar portion have virtually no sales. ''So if you are simplistic about it and look at traditional measures, you'd have to say that the quality has plunged,'' she said. ''But if you look at it in a different way, maybe not.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Hindsight will be a great teacher.'' levels of biotechnology companies in the early and mid-1990's.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: But Internet stock offerings account for a larger percentage of all public offerings than biotechnology stocks ever did.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: C9)    Magazine Desk; Section 6 What Was War? 1,042 words 5 December 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company I know what you'll think when I suggest putting a peace symbol in the Times Capsule: that this is an act of mockery, a way to document the ditzy idealism of the 1960's for a presumably incredulous posterity.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: You probably expect me to throw in a picture of John and Yoko staging their ''bed-in for peace'' or of Yippies trying to levitate the Pentagon.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: But in fact I make this nomination in a post-ironic spirit.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: I think what will amaze people in 3000 A.D. about peace symbols is not their idealism but the fact that they were ever considered idealistic.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: The end of war between nations is a nearly certain achievement of the next millennium, if not the next century.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: The last time this sort of optimism was fashionable was during the giddy aftermath of the cold war, a decade ago.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Since then, of course, we've been sobered up, grimly reminded that bonds of ethnicity and nationality are lethal.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Conflicts in the Balkans, the Caucasus, Africa and so on are now taken as proof that a global village doesn't bring peace, that one-worldishness is just as nave in 1999 as it was in 1969 or 1989.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: But in truth these examples illustrate the opposite.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: To see what I mean, you have to first see that the link between the global village and world peace is not the one that John and Yoko might have envisioned: that global communication automatically brings mutual understanding, hence peace.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: If things were that simple, we wouldn't have many wars to begin with.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Fighting is typically preceded by talking, after all.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: No, another ingredient besides communication is necessary.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: The people doing the communicating have to have a strong interest in peace and understanding to begin with.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: The key thing about the information technology now enveloping the world is the way it strengthens that interest.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: All those optical fibers are helping create a fine-grained economic interdependence among states.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: This interdependence makes war less and less a zero-sum game, with a winner and a loser, and more and more a non-zero-sum game -- specifically, a lose-lose, or negative-sum, game: a game you win by not playing.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Fortunately for world peace, rising interdependence is a basic property of history.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Civilizations rise and fall, ''dark'' ages come and go, but in the long run, technological evolution moves in only one direction.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: From cuneiform to computer, from camel to Concorde, the division of economic labor gets more elaborate and more far-flung; people, and peoples, need one another more.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Today, in the highly globalized capitalist states on the edge of this trend, interdependence is felt more broadly than ever, by armies of businesspeople who communicate with their counterparts in other cultures.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: In some cases, hard economic interest even leads to a softer, John-and-Yokoish antiwar force: friendship.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: In this light, trouble spots in the Caucasus and Africa and the Balkans are understandable.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: After all, these places are underglobalized.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Sure, they have Nikes and Coca-Cola, but they haven't been intricately, organically penetrated by modern capitalism.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Even the more economically advanced of these areas, in the former Yugoslavia, missed much of the Industrial Revolution and then spent much of this century under a mild but still retarding form of Communism.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: And, anyway, note how much of the recent conflict is traceable to the end of the cold war, which for half a century kept artificial state borders intact around the world.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Some transitional reordering is not surprising, and there's probably more to come.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: When the dust settles, borders will be more rational, and the logic behind peace will keep growing.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: The economic rationale for war's extinction has been around for centuries.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Unfortunately, every time it gets trotted out, it seems to get discredited.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Immanuel Kant wrote in the late 18th century that ''the effects which an upheaval in any state produces upon all the others in our continent, where all are so closely linked by trade, are so perceptible that these other states are forced by their own insecurity to offer themselves as arbiters.'' Then came Napoleon.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Today, war among Germany, France and England, which only decades ago seemed a natural state of affairs, is inconceivable.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: So the fact that Kosovo and Serbia now seem like eternal enemies isn't cause for despair.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Just put U.N. troops along the border, keep tariffs low and check back in half a century.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: That the rising tide of economic progress is finally carrying the world through some threshold of dovishness is reflected in a subtle but momentous shift of mind-set: increasingly, we think of wars as things that poor states do and rich states try to stop.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: This is not the way the world used to work.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Go ahead, try to imagine a fairly affluent, high-tech, capitalist nation, like South Korea, going to war with a similarly advanced nation, like Taiwan.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Your war scenario needs a poorer, less-wired nation to serve as aggressor -- a North Korea.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Kant believed that the growing logic behind peace among European states suggested ''a great political body of the future, without precedent in the past.'' Here, too, he was on target.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: True, the E.U. is afflicted by petty nationalism.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Still, if 60 years ago you had predicted that France and Germany would someday have the same currency, the reply would have been: ''Oh?

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Which nation conquered which?'' If you ask me, the European Union is a harbinger of the whole world's future, of a day when peacekeeping has been so routinized, and so many functions of governance have migrated to the transnational level, that the nation-state starts to fade, and keeps fading.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: For now, all I am saying is give peace a chance.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Robert Wright is the author of ''The Moral Animal'' and ''Nonzero: The Logic of Human Destiny,'' which will be published next month.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce Business/Financial Desk; Section C To win and keep customers in a wired world, companies must provide value.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Most haven't figured that out, though. 1,090 words 18 January 1999 The New York Times NYTF English (c) 1999 New York Times Company IN the early days of the Internet's commercial ascendancy, back in 1996, Jeffrey P.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Bezos, founder and chairman of the Internet's retail whale, Amazon.com, made a simple observation that should have signaled problems ahead for technology companies that assumed that the information age would be business as usual. ''I hear a lot of people talking about business models, but I don't hear much about customer value,'' Mr.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: If value was indeed going to be the key, a lot of business models were going to have to change -- most notably the telecommunications industry's, on which the Internet was being built.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: But instead of clanging like a gong in the heads of telecommunications executives, the cautionary logic of those words apparently continues to fall on deaf ears.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Few industries have gorged themselves on digital commerce with greater appetite than the telecommunications companies.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: But the result has been a wired world that to many customers seems like a cross between the best-known works of Edvard Munch and Jean-Paul Sartre: we scream, but there is no exit.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Telephone services provide a sharp and unfortunate contrast to on-line retailers like Mr.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Bezos, who realized early on that keeping customers is a lot easier than losing them to substandard service and continually enticing new ones into the fold.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: It is a rare consumer today who has only one horror story to tell.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Some engage in regular battle with cellular telephone duopolies and their arcane and incomprehensible pricing structures, which sometimes even charge for calls that their own networks are incapable of delivering.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Others are continually confronted with pager services with sporadic delivery that charge by the alpha-numeric character and employ operators who apparently have no schooling in even the basics of abbreviation.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Still others are engaged in conflicts -- which now involve the Federal Communications Commission -- over so-called casual customer rates for long-distance calls, socking consumers with the functional equivalent of $28 for a $1 gallon of gasoline.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: What is more, the telephone is the most common bridge to cyberspace, and as Internet and other on-line service providers reach a broader and less sophisticated market, the Internet revolution is in danger of becoming a latter-day Boston Tea Party as customer complaints mount about responsiveness and overcharging.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Customer satisfaction rates for companies that were once blue chips in the telephone industry are sinking, said Nick Donatiello, president of the consumer research firm Odyssey L.P. ''AT&T's image, for example, has rebounded somewhat, but it had been declining steadily for the past few years,'' Mr.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: The phone giant was rated ''very good'' by 63 percent of United States households in 1994 but dropped sharply, to 37 percent, in 1997 in Odyssey's surveys before rebounding to 55 percent last year. ''Still, it's not nearly what it was,'' he added.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Why are these companies, so central to the continued growth of the digital universe, so apparently intractable about providing value to customers?   ''The problem,'' Mr.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Donatiello said, is that ''virtually everyone in the telecom industry has had the luxury of treating their customers like garbage for a very long time, first because they had a monopoly -- and some still do -- while others have geographic oligopolies.'' As a result, he says, they are in a position not to care very much whether customers are satisfied with the quality or value of the services they sign up for.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: One of the most profound differences between on-line retail and the business of providing telecommunications, for example, is that customers find it a simple task to compare the prices of a book from several vendors.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: In contrast, telecommunications providers -- cellular and long-distance, especially -- seem to take pride in making it almost impossible to do so, with complex rates that vary by day of week, time of day and sometimes, it seems, the phases of the moon.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: The ability to comparison shop is one reason consumers are moving to support the trend toward flat-rate services, Mr.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Donatiello said. ''Americans don't like to have the meter running on anything that has to do with entertainment, information or communication,'' he said. ''That's why we saw such a huge uptick in the adoption curve of on-line services when America Online went to its flat-rate model,'' now $21.95 a month.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: The single-price model may also account for the popularity of AT&T's Digital One plan, which offers customers in certain cities a flat rate of $90 a month for 600 minutes of cellular calls to or from anywhere in the United States.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: The popularity of that plan, in turn, is setting off a frenzy among other wireless providers to offer their own flat-rate plans.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: But consumer attitudes suggest that may not be enough.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Increasingly, people want to simplify the enormous complexity of their wired lives by buying all their telecommunications-- local phone service, long distance, cellular, cable television and Internet connections -- from a single provider.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: And though AT&T again says it is leading the charge with its purchase of the cable television giant Tele-Communications Inc., Mr.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Donatiello says consumers apparently do not hold out much hope that even moves this bold will make their lives easier to understand or manage. ''The bottom line is that consumers don't think any kind of company would do a good job'' providing a full range of services, he said. ''Their No. 1 choice was a long-distance company, and only 37 percent of U.S. households said they would do a good job.'' Local phone companies got a 36 percent confidence rating as potential one-stop providers, while cable television companies scored only 21 percent, and Internet service providers a paltry 17 percent.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: So in the end, consumer attitudes signal trouble ahead for acquisitive telecommunications companies like AT&T, despite the benefits it promises from its TCI merger and deals with high-speed Internet services like At Home. ''It's worse than the blind leading the deaf,'' Mr.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Donatiello said. ''The bad has married the ugly, and somehow they expect the children to be the good.

title: Feasting On a Banquet Of Internet Offerings
author: EDWARD WYATT
chunk: Lip service alone won't get you there -- the first thing they still have to prove is that they're worthy of their customers' business.''
